cards.title: General Visual Stimulation                                                                                            Under six weeks

Tasks.Action:
Hang a mobile to far right or far left of baby’s cr ib because his head will usually be turned to eithe r side. 
Mobile should be designed with a view toward what t he baby sees while lying on his/her back

Put your face 6-8 inches from child when talking or  singing to him/her. An infant of this age will att end more 
to a human face than to any other pattern.
Shift baby to other end of crib so that light can e xcite each eye.

Hang objects from side of crib or from stick placed  across crib. Young babies are attracted by bright,  
irregularly shaped or patterned objects.

cards.title: General Visual Stimulation                                                                                      Six weeks and older

Tasks.Action: Occasionally use a patterned sheet on child’s crib.
Move large, bright object or penlight slowly across  child’s line of vision.
Place child at various heights such as on the floor , on a sofa, or in playpen.
Show child his hands and feet. Move them together.
Place the child in different parts of each room. Le t him observe family at mealtime.
Place a toy in the child’s hands while he/she is no t looking.
Hold mirror over child’s head while in crib, about 7 or 8 inches from his eyes.

Fix a plexiglas sheet or tray across portion of bab y’s crib. Place colored objects on it such as bits of paper, 
ribbons and toys. Replace or move objects from time  to time.
Tie brightly colored ribbons together and hang over  child’s crib where he can see but not touch.

On the wall in child’s room or over crib, hang post ers, pictures, photographs or colored construction paper. 
Large sheets of colored paper, rotated from time to  time, can make stimulating color schemes.

cards.title: General Tactile Stimulation                                                                                          Under six weeks

Tasks.Action:
Touch and handle child in a loving, gentle manner. Newborns are very sensitive to sudden movement and 
rough or inappropriate handling.

Child may feel more secure if wrapped snuggly in a blanket. Likewise, a warm bottle, crib and clothing  
will add to child’s sense of wellbeing.
Some babies cry less when held in close contact ove r their mother’s hearts.
Pat body lotion on child, being sure that lotion is  not cold.
Hold baby while feeding him/her

cards.title: General Tactile Stimulation                                                                                    Six weeks and older

Tasks.Action:
Lay child on varied surfaces. Undress child in warm  room and put him/her on something smooth, soft, fl uffy, 
furry, etc.
Let child feel vibrations of cat purring, throat mo ving in speech, radio or television.
Puff powder over child using a cotton ball or powde r puff.
Provide cuddly, furry, cloth and plastic play anima ls and dolls.

cards.title: General Auditory stimulation                                                                                        Under six weeks

Tasks.Action: Sing to your baby or say poems or nursery rhymes.
Let baby hear a metronome or clock. This may heIp q uiet him/her when he’s fussy.
Vary voice tone when talking to child. Tone of voic e is more important than the words used.
Talk or sing to baby when you wash and dress him/he r and when you feed and rock him/her.

cards.title: General Auditory Stimulation                                                                                Six weeks and older

Tasks.Action: Tie a small bell to baby’s bootie.
Crumple paper next to his ear, switch sides.
Let him/her hear wind chimes.
Give him/her blocks with bells.
Put a lightweight rattle in his hand.
Talk to him/her or ring a bell from different place s of the room. See if he hears and follows with his  eyes.
Let him/her rustle tissue paper.
Play radio or record player but do not play music c onstantly.

cards.title: Sucks

Tasks.Action:
Stimulate child’s lips with your fingers by gently touching them. Lips can also be stimulated by touch ing 
them with a cold cloth.

Stimulate sucking by gently massaging the child’s c heeks while nipple is in his mouth, using a forward  – 
backward motion with fingers.

If child gets too much air and cannot suck efficien tly, try using a different shaped or larger nipple.  If breast-
feeding, press child’s mouth closer to breast to fo rm an air seal. It may also help to change child’s position 
by raising or lowering him/her.

cards.title: Moves head to side while lying on back

Tasks.Action: Extend one arm outward and bend other arm upward so  baby will turn to side of extended arm.
Display bright or shiny object 12-18 inches from ch ild. Display first on one side, then on the other.
Lay baby in different positions in bed or on exerci se mat.

Tie a stick across crib. Tie shiny object such as a  ball of aluminium foil to the far left side of the  crib. 
Wiggle it so it attracts child’s attention. Move ob ject to far right side of crib and do the same. Cha nge the 
object every few days.

Talk and call to baby from one side of crib and str oke or touch his/her arm or his/her side. If he doe sn’t 
turn his/her head, gently move it to the side and r eward him/her with a big smile and gentle praise.

cards.title: Opens mouth for bottle or breast when nipple  touches mouth

Tasks.Action: Touch edges of baby’s mouth with pinching motion re quiring him to open mouth.
Touch bottom lip before nipple is produced.
Tap child gently with fingertip under his/her chin.

cards.title: Indicates sensitivity to body contact by qui eting, crying, or body movement

Tasks.Action:
When baby cries, hold him/her snugly wrapped in lig ht blanket. Walk around the room with him/her in yo ur 
arms.
Gentle rocking motion of your arms may quiet baby.
Gentle rubbing of head may sooth.

It is not always necessary to pick up child. Try ge ntly patting or stroking him/her while you talk qui etly as 
child lies in crib.
Turn baby over and try to sooth him/her by rubbing his/her back or tummy.

cards.title: Turns head toward nipple when his cheek is t ouched

Tasks.Action: Hold baby in same position each time you initiate f eeding.
Tap cheek with finger, then touch nipple to mouth.
Tap under chin, then touch cheek.

If the child does not turn his head toward the nipp le gently turn his head toward it. Give the child a n 
opportunity to turn his head toward the nipple by h imself before assisting him in this way.

cards.title: Looks in direction of sound or changes body movement in respone to sound

Tasks.Action: Ring a bell 12-18 inches from baby.
Talk to the baby or say his name “ ---------------- -----------look”.
Clap hands or tap an object.
Squeeze a noice maker toy.
Blow a whistle.

Begin by making the above sounds only 12 to 18 inch es from the child. As the child attends to sounds v ery 
near him, increase the distance between the sound s ource and the child.
Initially the child may only become more active, bu t not look toward sound.
Help the child by turning his head in the direction  of the sound, if he does not do so on his own.
Use a wide variety of sounds with the child. Change  them often so they will be novel and attraction.

cards.title: Looks at person attempting to gain his atten tion by talking or moving

Tasks.Action:
Position yourself where child can see you. Call to him/her. If he does not look at you grasp his chin and 
move face toward you. Exaggerate actions and verbal ization so he continues to attend to you.
Hold colorful objects in front of child’s eyes so h e gains skill in focusing.

Say child’s name to him over and over. Change pitch  and inflection pattern as you do this until he loo ks 
at you.

Put your head down close to child’s face and move q uickly from his/her line of vision. Then move close  
again and say “hello” or “ peek-a-boo”. Repeat this  until child starts looking. Then stay in sight, sm ile 
and talk soothingly to baby.

cards.title: Quiets or changes body movement in response to presence of person

Tasks.Action: After comforting crying, move the child to a positi on near adult.
Move child in basket or infant seat from one area o f house to another as you work.
Place the child near the family at mealtime.

Put child on his back on a blanket in a room in whi ch you will be moving about. Occasionally go over a nd 
speak to child.

If the child is comforted only when the adult is ve ry near him/her, place the child only a short dista nce away. 
As child becomes accustomed to this gradually move him farther away. When child is quiet and content, 
attend to him periodically by walking over and patt ing him/her or speaking to him/her.

cards.title: Shows by body movements or cessation of cryi ng, response to adult voice

Tasks.Action:
When child is fussing, call to reasure him, but be sure to come into view and attend to him quickly. 
Gradually increase time between reassuring him and actually attending to him.

Whenever you approach the child, call him or speak to him. Follow this with some direct contact, place  a toy 
where he can see it, roll him over, tickle him or p ick him up.

When the child cries try talking to him in a soothi ng voice. Pat child as you talk. If he does not qui et, then   
Pick him up. Let the child associate your voice wit h your presence. Gradually he/she should be comfort ed by 
your voice alone.

cards.title: Lifts and momentarily supports head when hel d with head at shoulder

Tasks.Action:
Hold the baby upright and support his back with you r hand and gradully reduce the support. Keep your h and 
near his head but occasionally let baby support his  own head for a few seconds.

When holding baby upright have another person talk to him or make sounds with a toy at his eye level t o 
encourage him to maintain position.

Walk around house with baby held at shoulder to giv e him things to see or stand so that the baby can s ee 
himself in a mirror.

cards.title: Cries differentially due to different discom forts

Tasks.Action: Respond to his cry promptly by time appropriate act ivities.

Although individual children vary, usually a child’ s cries of pain are loud and shrill broken by whimp ering, 
his hunger cry is loud and shrill like a wail inter rupted by sucking movements, his cry of discomfort consists 
of low moans and whimpers and his sleepy cry is a w hining drawn out one.

Attend to the child’s cry as though it is a form of  communication. If it sounds like a hungry cry resp ond to it 
by feeding him. If it sounds like a cry of pain try  to discover the cause.
Listen to the cry and try to identify what the chil d is communicating as you go to comfort him.

cards.title: Falls asleep at appropriate times

Tasks.Action: Be sure child is fed, changed and warm.
Reduce noise and light stimulation when placing in bed.
Provide separate sleeping arrangements away from pa rent’s room.
Place a clock or metronome near child’s crib as low  frequency; rhythmic sounds tend to quiet an infant .

If child fusses a lot and is not wet or hungry, don ’t necessarily pick him up – instead gently stroke him or pat 
him on the back.

To induce relaxation in a crying, tense baby, shake  arms and legs gently and rhythmically; first arms,  then 
legs, until child’s body begins to relax.

cards.title: Thrusts arms about –no direction

Tasks.Action: Flex one arm at a time toward his face.
Put a bracelet on child’s wrist that’s made of jing le bells- alternative wrists.

Lie child back in crib. Tie one end of several feet  of elastic to child’s wrist. Tie a bell or other n oisemaker to 
opposite end. Put this end up over side of crib so that arm movements will cause bell to go up and dow n.

Very young infants are generally wrapped snugly in a blanket. Try to plan for times during the day whe n the 
child can be unwrapped and allowed to move his arms  freely. After diapering or while bathing would be 
natural times to encourage the infant to thrust his  arms about. Encourage him by alternately shaking h is arms 
and allowing him an opportunity to do it himself.

cards.title: Follows an object, visually, moved past midl ine of body

Tasks.Action: With child lying on back hold an object at midline,  move it slowly to right and to left.
Position yourself in child’s vision, talk to him an d gradually move to right and left.

Hang a mobile directly above child in crib. Make on e end of the mobile very shiny or bright so child i s 
interested in it. Start mobile in motion to see if child follows it as it crosses his line of vision

Prop child in an infant seat. Place a bright or shi ny toy on a blanket or pillow and starting from one  side, pull 
it slowly across the floor in front of him.

Begin by moving the object only a short distance t o either side of midline. When the child consistent ly 
follows the object a short distance increase the di stance you move it to either side of his midline.

cards.title: Smiles

Tasks.Action: Smile as you talk to baby, holding or placing him a t least 12 inches from your face.

a. Holding your finger in front of your face, turn your head from right to left. When you catch his ey e, drop 
your finger. See if he then moves his head back and  forth as you do. Give him time to imitate. If he d oesn’t, 
gradually guide his head back and forth,  until he imitates independently.  
b. When he can imitate your head movement, stop and  suddenly smile, see if he smiles back. Give him 
plenty of time. Don’t tickle or talk to him to get him to smile. You simply want him to imitate smilin g. When 
he does smile, stop smiling, but look pleasant for about 5 seconds and then smile again. Do this only a few 
times.
Smile and talk to child when attending his n eeds such as after feeding and when he walks from a  nap.

cards.title: Follows light with eyes, turning head

Tasks.Action:
Use a penlight and hold the light directly in front  of the infant. Gradually move the light to the rig ht or left. 
Cover light with different colored cellophone.
Place child in artifical and natural light to provi de variable visual stimulation.

Initially, move the penlight only a short distance to the right or left. When the child can follow it a short 
distance begin to move it a greater distance to the  right or left.

cards.title: Follows sound, moving head

Tasks.Action:
Use squeakly toy or bell, make the sound directly i n front of the child, making certain child is looki ng at 
instrument, move it gradually farther to right and left as you continue making the sound.

Sit behind child. Wind a music box and place it to one side of child but not so he can see it or touch  it. If he 
turns toward the sound gradually move it into his l ine of vision and across to his other side. Switch sides.

Be sure that other auditory distractors, such as a radio, are not present while working on this activi ty. This 
will increase the likelihood that the child will at tend to the stimulus sound.

If a toy is being used, and the child responds by t urning his head in the direction, let him have the toy for a 
few seconds as a reward.

cards.title: Regards hand

Tasks.Action:
Lay child on back in crib, on sofa or on lap. Hold child’s hand and move it slowly back and forth in f ront of 
child’s face.
When child focuses on hand, move his fingers for th e child to watch.

Initiate the child’s arm movement and watch to see if the child will look at his hand. Smile and strok e child 
when he does regard his hand.

Use colorful (red) infant socks as mittens and plac e on child’s hands. Cut socks so thumbs and fingers  show. 
Finally, eliminate socks when the child consistentl y looks at his mittened hand.
Tickle the baby’s hand when he’s not looking or tou ch it with something warm or cool.

cards.title: Kicks vigorously while on back

Tasks.Action:
Grasp child’s feet and pump his legs up and down. G radually reduce pressure as the child begins to kic k on 
his own.
Provide opportunity for the child to kick in water.

Lean over child and let him push his feet into your  stomach. Leap back, using verbal exclamations.  
      Then push forward on his legs again.

Tie a board to the side of playpen or place child a t end of crib so that toes touch the board and knee s are 
slightly bent. When child starts to kick encourage his delight by showing pleasure with your expressio n and 
words. Try uncovering his feet so he can get direct  stimulation with his bare feet.

String a large, rectangular surface (cookie sheet, heavy cardboard) between crib uprights with tough 
elasticized rope so that it will return to resting position when baby stops kicking.

cards.title: Opens mouth, begins sucking prior to nipple touching mouth

Tasks.Action:
Place child in same position, sit in same chair to feed him so that he has physical clues to guide him  in 
anticipation of feeding.
With child in feeding position make sure he can see  nipple before it touches his mouth.
Touch child’s chin or lips so that he will begin to  anticipate physical cue as well as the visual cue.

cards.title: Maintains eye contact 3 seconds

Tasks.Action: Hold face close to child’s face, smile and talk to the child to maintain eye contact.
Hold a bright object near your eye and call child’s  name. Talk animatedly to him to maintain eye conta ct.

Hold child with his head cupped in yours hands so t hat he can see your face and lips. Lean toward him,  smile 
and make some exaggerated sounds.

Focus all of your attention on the child during fee ding time i.e. don’t watch T.V., or read a book. Wh en the 
child looks at you, reinforce with eye contact. Tal king or humming quietly to the child while feeding should 
help to establish eye contact.

cards.title: Moves head while lying on stomach, up, down,  side to side

Tasks.Action:
Using a toy or object move the toy up and down and from side to side so that child needs to move head to 
continue to see the object.

Use a bell or squeak toy held at eye level, gradual ly move it from side to side and up and down so tha t child 
will move head.

Place your face at eye level, move your head and ta lk to child so that he will move his head to mainta in eye 
contact.
Throw a brightly colored balloon in air. Child will  need to move his head to watch it fall slowly.

Place child on stomach for 10 to 15 minutes at a ti me so he has opportunity to lift head and observe 
environment to practice head control.

Use a pull toy that makes noise. While the child is  in a playpen on his stomach, pull the toy slowly b ack and 
forth in front of him

cards.title: Swipes at objects

Tasks.Action:
Present a small, bright object about 6 inches from child’s eyes and off to the right or left (whicheve r is the 
predominant side for the child). If baby doesn’t ba t at it, gently push his arm towards it.

Hang mobile from center of crib. Hang bright irregu larly shaped objects from it with elastic rope. Be sure 
objects are 6-8 inches from child so he can hit the m if he swipes with his arm.

Touch child’s hand with a soft, brightly colored ob ject. Move it slightly away from child’s hand to se e if 
he’ll try to get it.

Tie a helium balloon to child’s wrist. As he moves his arm the balloon will move. Let child feel the b alloon 
afterwards.

cards.title: Holds head up while on stomach, 5 seconds

Tasks.Action:
Place child on stomach, hold toy, or object directl y at eye level. When child is looking at object, gr adually 
move it up so that child will lift head to keep obj ect in line of vision.
Place your face directly in front of his, gradually  move up so that he will lift head to maintain eye contact.

Place rolled up towel or small bolster under child’ s arms, dangle a toy or use a squeak toy directly i n front of 
him gradually moving object up.
Stroke or touch child gently under chin to encourag e him to lift his head.

Lay child on stomach at least one half hour a day t o assure him of practice in head lifting and head c ontrol. 
Ten minutes or so after mealtime might be an approp riate time.

cards.title: Follows object with eyes across 180 degree a rea

Tasks.Action: Use a pen light, hold the lightly directly in front  of the child. Move the light slightly to the right  or left.
Lean over child so you are in his line of vision. M ove either to right or left, verbalizing as he foll ows you.
Hang a simple (one item) mobile over crib. Use a br ight color such as yellow or orange.

Pass a brightly colored object on a string in front  of child so he will be able to follow the moving o bject with 
his eyes.

Do not hold object more than 3 or 4 feet away from the child. His focus is usually not refined past th at 
distance.

cards.title: Searches for sound by turning head in direct ion of sound

Tasks.Action:
When child is lying on side or back, place wind-up musical toy near ear so child will turn head toward s 
sound.
Try to get child’s attention by calling his name.

Try a variety of sounds such as bells, rattles, han d claps to get the child’s attention. It’s importan t to reduce 
other auditory stimulation when attempting to get a nd maintain the child’s attention.

Place the child with the rest of the family during mealtime and watch the child to see if he does atte nd to 
unusual sounds like the spoon dropping.

cards.title: Coos and gurgles when content

Tasks.Action:
After diapering or feeding child hold him/her and c uddle him. Make soft, high-pitched cooing sounds to  
him/her. Smile and stroke him/her when he/she makes  sounds.

Gently blow on baby’s neck and coo to him. After ba th while powdering or oiling him make soothing cooi ng 
sounds.
Reinforce any cooing the child does by smiling  and repeating his sounds back to him.

cards.title: Reaches for objects and attempts to grasp it

Tasks.Action:
Tie scarf or necktie around your neck. Lean over ba by so he can see your face and possibly touch the s carf. 
Shake the scarf so he can see it and reach for it. If he grabs at it or touches it, smile to show him you are 
pleased. Initially move scarf towards baby’s hands so he doesn’t need to reach for it as much.

Secure a dowel across top of crib. Tie onto it two objects that look and feel very different. Occasion ally 
switch positions of objects or present new objects,  but be sure all objects are within baby’s reach.

Hold enticing object that makes a noise a few inche s in front of baby in infant seat. Shake it to enco urage 
baby to reach out. Initially give him object even i f he reaches but can’t yet direct the reach enough to grasp 
it.
Put brightly colored long necklace around your  neck. Lean over baby so he can see and reach for i t.

cards.title: Holds head erect and steadily while being ca rried upright

Tasks.Action:
Hold child so he is looking over your shoulder. Cup  the back of his head in your head. Gradually relea se 
pressure of your hand but hold it ready to steady h is head when it wobbles.

Hold child so he looks over your shoulder while sta nding in front of a mirror or a simple bright pictu re fixed 
at eye level. Talk to him as you hold him there. Su pport his back.

Have another family member stand in back of you so he is facing the child. Then have him hold a toy, b ottle, 
or noise maker at the child’s eye level to get his attention. Gradually move the object up so the chil d will 
hold his head erect.

cards.title: Holds object using palmar grasp 30 seconds w ith involuntary release

Tasks.Action:
Hold a small object (strip of sponge, round clothes pin, piece of celery, roll of soft cloth) so baby c an see it. 
Touch the inside of his hand with it and let his fi ngers close around it. Take your hand away. When he  drops 
it, repeat the procedure. Try using different objec ts.

Give child object such as a pretzel, space ring or something that will almost get caught in child’s ha nd. 
Gently wrap child’s fingers around object if he doe sn’t. Do not force child to hold object. Gradually release 
pressure on his fingers.

Use pieces of different texture fabric etc. glued t o pieces of sponge. (i.e., fine sand paper, furry, rough,   
silky, nubby textures.)

cards.title: Repeats own sound

Tasks.Action: When child makes back of throat gurgle, lean close to child’s faceand repeat the same sound.
Repeat sound several times in high-pitched voice. S mile, hug or pat child when he makes the sound agai n

Record another infant’s verbalization, play recordi ng as you play and feed the infant. Reinforce any s ounds          
      that the child makes.

cards.title: Holds head and chest erect while on stomach and supported on fore arms

Tasks.Action:
Roll a blanket or use a pillow or bolster, place un der arms to hold head and chest erect. Dangle a toy  or 
bright object in front of him.
Place a colorful picture or toy in front of child s o he must hold his head up to see it.

Prop a mirror or shiny cookie sheet in front of chi ld. Encourage him to look at image by tapping mirro r and 
saying, “ See the baby,” etc.

Place child on stomach. Prop him on his forearms. H elp him support head with your hands. Gradually red uce 
the support you give him. Talk and attend to him on ly when he is supporting his own head and shoulders .

cards.title: Opens moutb when he sees spoonful of food

Tasks.Action:
Place child in feeding position and make sure he ca n see and hear preparation of food. Do this in same  
manner and place at every feeding. Bring spoon towa rds child’s mouth so he can see it. Use verbal cues  such 
as “ open wide”  “ Here comes some yum yums” etc.

If child doesn’t open mouth in anticipation, physic ally open his mouth, praise him and then give him a  bite. 
Reduce your physical assistance as child begins to open mouth on his own.

Try to make feeding time as hassle-free for yoursel f and the child as possible, so you won’t feel rush ed. Take 
your time, talking to the child and initiating eye contact. If the child is anticipating the spoon, co nsistently 
wait for him to open his mouth before feeding him r ather than “shoveling it in.”

cards.title: Laughs

Tasks.Action:
Gently put your head on his stomach instead of look ing at him face to face. If you do this several tim es he 
may laugh.
Babble at him (bobo bo bo bo) on a rising crescendo .
Make your cheek pop with your finger.
Blow “ raspberries” on his neck or cheeks while he holds your head or hair.

Find new places to tickle. When you are washing him  tickle the inside of his hand or under his chin wi th a 
washcloth.
Be sure to attend to laughter by laughing back, tou ching and smiling.

cards.title: Shows recognition of family member by smiles  or cessation of crying

Tasks.Action: Have a special person (mom, sitter, grandparent) wh o will show special attention to the child.

If another child is present, such as an older sibli ng have him attend to child. Babies usually respond  to 
another youngster.

Hold child in your arms as you feed him by bottle. He will learn to recognize your face sooner than if  seated 
in an infant seat and staring at things in the dist ance.

Give all family members the opportunity to interact  with the baby. Show other sibilings acceptable way s of 
playing with baby if they seem too rough or noisy w ith him

cards.title: Attempts to roll over using shoulders

Tasks.Action:
Raise the child’s shoulder on the side you want him  to turn by placing bolster under shoulder or pulli ng 
gently on the child’s arm over to initiate roll.

Place child on back. Standing or kneeling behind hi s head, hold object over child so he can see it. Mo ve 
object gradually to the side and toward top of chil d’s head so it is no longer in view. Move object sl owly, 
giving him time to follow it. If he turns over let him have object to play with. Repeat from other sid e. Use a 
colorful object on a string.
Place child on stomach, pull at the back of sh irt or gown to initiate shoulder movement.

cards.title: Moves thumb in opposition to other four fing ers

Tasks.Action: Children usually play with the nipple on their bott le using the pincher movement.

Put a small object of different textures of a size that fits conveniently in the child’s hand. Take it  out and 
have child attempt to pick up.
Start presenting the child with other objects to pi ck up such as pieces of clay, blocks, etc.

Sometimes larger objects will be useful in helping the child place his thumb in opposition to the othe r 
fingers. Don’t expect the child to pick up a large or heavy object; the goal here is that he grasps th e object 
using his thumb seperately from the other fingers.

cards.title: Babbles (series of syIIables)

Tasks.Action: Try for ma, pa, and ba first. When he babbles repea t sounds with him so he hears them.
Use musical toys, which use basic sounds.
Roll and bounce child to elicit sounds. Reward any sounds.
Play music and sing to him as you cuddle him.
As you feed and bathe him, say his name or sounds h e can make, over and over.

cards.title: Sucks and swallows liquid.

Tasks.Action:
Stimulate sucking by massaging cheeks when nipple i s in mouth, using a forward backward motion with 
fingers.

Place small amount of honey on tip of pacifier and place it in the mouth. If child still doesn’t suck on pacifier, 
move it in and out for him. As child increases suck ing response, put some honey on the nipple of the b ottle.
To encourage swallowing, gently stroke the child’s neck starting under the chin moving down to the thr oat.

cards.title: Eats liquefied foods, i.e. baby cereal.

Tasks.Action:
Hold child in semi upright position. Use small spoo n. Place small amount of food in child’s mouth. Wai t for 
child to swallow before feeding more food.
Place food toward center of tongue.
Put small pieces of crushed ice in the food. When t he ice touches tongue, child will swallow reflexive ly.

When you put food in child’s mouth, touch the tongue in 3-4 places before emptying food from spoo n. This   
encourages child to retract tongue to swallow.

cards.title: Reaches for bottle.

Tasks.Action: Hold the bottle so the child can see it. Move it sl owly toward the mouth while talking to child.
If the child does not reach for the bottle, place h is hands on it before inserting the nipple into mou th.
Do these activities each time you give the child th e bottle.

Give the child bottle and allow him to nurse for a short time. Then move bottle a short distance away from his 
mouth and see if he will reach for it. If he does n ot, guide his hands with yours to reach the bottle.

cards.title: Eats strained foods fed by parent .

Tasks.Action: Use small amounts of strained foods during times wh en the child is hungry.
Feeding should be a cheerful and comfortable time for parent and child. Talk to child as you feed him .
Have foods, bib, and warm washcloth handy so that feeding can continue uninterrupted.

Hold child in an upright position on your lap with  small spoon put small amount of food at least 2/3 of the 
way toward back of tongue.

Place bits of crushed ice in the strained foods. P lace food-ice well back on tongue. This encourages child to 
retract his tongue.

Use tongue depressor or Popsicle stick to feed ins tead of spoon. Touch tongue with depressor in 3-4 p laces 
forward of the place you deposit the food.

cards.title: Holds bottle without help while drinking .

Tasks.Action: Place the child’s hands around the bottle, while yo u also hold it.
Place the child’s hands around bottle and hold it l ess and less until the child is holding the bottle himself.
Hold the bottle during part of feeding and allow t he child to hold it during part of the feeding proc edure.
Fill bottle partially full and then refill it so i t won’t be too heavy for the child to hold.

When child is hungry, let him hold it during first  part of feeding. As he gets full and is not as mot ivated, you 
hold bottle for the last part. Gradually require ch ild to hold the bottle for longer periods of time.

If bottle slips from child's grasp, cover part of i t with a textured material such as masking tape or heavy twine 
so that child has more to grasp at. As child become s more adept, remove aid.

Roll or fold towel and place on child's chest for a dditional support for bottle. Encourage child to ke ep hold of 
bottle, but initially allow him to use towel for pa rtial support.

cards.title: Eats mashed table food fed by parent .

Tasks.Action: Introduce the food at the beginning of a meal when child is hungry.

Mash foods like macaroni, cheese, peas, bananas, a nd potatoes.  If the food is too stiff add a small amount of 
milk or strained fruit or gravy.
Expect him to like new food. Give it to him cheerfu lly as if you expect him to find it good.
Make foods as appealing and attractive as possible.

Give child small amount of liquid in between spoonf ul of mashed food to facilitate swallowing and to q uench 
thirst.
Use a plastic or Teflon spoon. They are not as hard  or cold as metal.
Use a large bib and expect drooling and dripping of  liquid in the beginning.
Let child see contents of cup before feeding.

Use a two-handled mug. Tilt the cup into the mouth giving the child a small amount of milk. Encourage the 
child to hold the cup by placing his hands on the c up and guiding his hands and cup to his mouth.

To increase the child’s desire to drink, feed him s alty crackers before giving him liquid in the cup, the 
alternate sips with salty solid food.

Use a favorite liquid to increase child’s desire to  drink from cup and if possible limit this favorite  drink so it 
is only given in a cup.

cards.title: Eats semi solid foods fed by parent .

Tasks.Action:
Use foods such as bananas, bread, toast, and cracke rs. Praise child for chewing and swallowing food pu t in 
mouth.

Gently move the jaws up and down after placing food  in the mouth by putting your fingers on the top an d 
bottom lip and moving your bottom fingers up and do wn keeping top fingers stable.

Use foods the child likes and do not introduce new foods until he is eating these semi solid foods eas ily. 
Gradually add these semi- solid foods to the meals.
Put food in back and to the side of the child’s mou th as this often initiates chewing.

cards.title: Feeds self with fingers .

Tasks.Action:
Put several bite size pieces of favorite food in fr ont of child. If food has an odor, hold to child’s nose before 
placing in front of child to gain interest in the f ood. Use foods such as toast, vegetables, hamburger , Weiner, 
cookies, and crackers.
Offer foods at beginning of meal when the child is hungry.

If the child does not pick up the food on his own, place a small bite of toast in his hand and help by  guiding 
his hand to his mouth. Reduce the help give as the child learns to accomplish the task on his own.

cards.title: Holds and drinks from cup using two hands .

Tasks.Action:
Stand behind the child and help him to guide the cu p to his mouth. Guide his hands to help him replace  the 
cup on the tray.
Use small amount of liquid in cup. (Milk, water or kool-aid or a thick liquid such as milk shake, crea m soup).
Begin letting the child does more and more for hims elf as he gains in skill. Praise the child as he im proves.
Use training cup or weighted cup to introduce activ ity. When child gains proficiency use a regular pla stic cup.

Use the plastic fastener from a 6 pack of pop, fold  it in half so you have three openings. Put small a mount of 
liquid in cup that fits securely in center circle. Put the child's hands around the cup and encourage him to take 
a drink.
Use two cups. You drink from one and have the child  imitate you.

cards.title: Takes spoon filled with food mouth with help .

Tasks.Action: Use a spoon with a large or built up handle (wrappe d in cloth or foam) or a swivel spoon if available.
Let child become familiar with spoon first.

Guide the child's hand from plate to mouth while st anding behind the child. If child tends to use one hand 
more than the other, help the child use that hand.

Use foods that the child likes and that will stick to spoon (mashed potatoes, pudding, whip and chill,  ice 
cream)

Sit in front of the child. Put a spoon in the child 's right or left hands gently put your free hand on  child's wrist 
and guide the spoon and hand from dish to mouth. If  necessary, hold the child's other hand so he doesn 't put it 
in the bowl of food.
Put honey on spoon and give child a taste. Put spoo n down. Hand it to child and encourage child to eat .

cards.title: Holds out arms and legs while being dressed .

Tasks.Action:
Hold garment close to child's body with the slee ve near the arm. Encourage child to raise his arm t oward the  
    Sleeve. Praise the child when he makes the effo rt. If the child does not do this on spoken instruc tions alone,    
    then help by raising his arm for him, praising him as you do this.
Do the same when dressing the child in socks, sh oes, pants.

To encourage child to place arms or feet in clot hing, play a peek- a- boo game with him (i.e. “Wher e's your  
     hand? There it is!" as his hand disappears int o clothing and then emerges.)

cards.title: Holds and drinks from cup with one hand.

Tasks.Action: Use a one handled cup.
Help the child by guiding his hand and praise hi m as he brings the cup toward his mouth.
Place a small toy in his other hand so he uses o ne hand to hold the cup.
Help him to hold the cup in one hand placing you r hand around his hand. Gradually withdraw help.
Place small amount of liquid in cup to avoid big  spills.

Initially use a relatively heavy cup so it is no t tipped over easily. Try putting two plastic tumbl ers together. Put  
    a small amount of sand in the bottom of the out side one to add weight.
Show child how to gently set down cup so it won' t spill easily.

cards.title: Puts hands in water and pats wet hands on fa ce in intimation.

Tasks.Action: Use a small stool so child can reach the sink.
Encourage child to put his hands in the sink when w ashing.
Show him how to pat face with wet hands by doing it  yourself and helping child imitate you.
Place child's hand in sink; move them around in spl ashing motion until he begins to do this on his own .

Praise him as he does more for himself and gains in  skill. For reinforcement, let child look in mirror  as he 
pats his wet hands on his face.
Put a smudge or chalk mark on child's face. Let chi ld use mirror to see if he can get it all off.

Begin teaching the skill in the bathtub. When chi ld is bathing physically guide him and show how to pat 
water on his face.

cards.title: Sits on potty or infant toilet seat for 5 mi nutes.

Tasks.Action:
When changing the child talk about " going potty", "pee- pee" or whatever words you intend to use. Use  the  
      same word or words each time.

Let the child watch the family use toilet and encou rage the family to use the same word you are teachi ng the  
      child.

Stay with the child and praise him for sitting on p otty. Get him used to it by telling him a story or nursery   
      rhyme while sitting on potty.

Choose two times when there is a likelihood that th e child will urinate. Seat him on the potty. Stay w ith him.  
Praise if he does go in potty.

Make this time enjoyable and pleasant for the child  to encourage him to stay on the seat. This is and initials  
      step in toilet training. Do not require the c hild to sit for longer than 5 minutes at a time.

cards.title: Puts hat on head and takes it off.

Tasks.Action: Give the child a hat and guide his hands and pla ce it on head.
Use a mirror to allow child to see himself do th is. Let the child place a hat on your head and remo ve it.
Put a hat on your head as child watches. Remove it and give it to the child to try.
Put hats on and takes hats off of dolls.
Provide a variety of adults hats for child to tr y such as a baseball hat, daddy's hat, a fireman's hat etc.,
Use hats much larger than child's head and play peek-o-boo.

cards.title: Pulls off socks .

Tasks.Action:
Pulls one sock almost off the foot and encourage th e child to complete 
 the task by placing  his hands on the     
sock and praising him when he pulls it off.
Place the loose end in his hand, place your hand ov er his and pull off the sock. Reward and praise.
Ask child to pull a sock off your foot.
Pull socks off dolls.

Put a sticker or draw a little picture on child's t oe(s) so that he will pull off sock to see it; or p ut a small piece  
      of wrapped candy in toe of sock for child.

Begin by using socks larger than the child's foot a nd gradually switch to smaller socks as the child g ains in  
       skill.

cards.title: Pushes arms through sleeve, legs through pan ts.

Tasks.Action:
Hold arm opening near hand. Encourage child to put hand in opening and push arm through. Give physical   
      guidance if necessary, then gradually withdra ws it. Praise child for pushing arm through without  aid. Follow   
 
      same procedure for pushing legs through pants .
Wait for child to initiate movement, rather than al ways pushing it through for him.

Play" peek-o-boo" with his arm. Say, "Where is your  hand"?  . When hand comes through, shake it and sa y,  
“Here's your hand!"

Initially use short pants and short sleeved or slee veless shirts. As child gains in skill use long sle eved shirts      
and pants.

cards.title: Takes off shoes when laces are untied and lo osened.

Tasks.Action:
If possible, start with slightly larger shoes t han the child normally wears such as an older broth er's or sister's  
     and encourage him to remove the shoes while si tting.

Place shoes just over the child's toes and enco urage him to remove the shoe. Repeat and place shoe  further and 
 
      further on the child's foot.

Encourage the child to take shoes off daddy and  doll, etc. Repeat with child's own shoe using same  process,  
     and praise success.
Pretend you can't get shoe off and encourage ch ild to try. Praise highly if he succeeds.

cards.title: Takes off coat when unfastened.

Tasks.Action:
The coat should be correct size for child so he can easily remove it. Have an activity, snack, or s tory as reward  
    for finishing task, " When you take your coat o ff you can

Have child watch you take off your coat and imit ate. Have the child place his hands on either side of the  
    opened coat. Pull the shoulders back and coat w ill slide off arms.

Have child tug at sleeve, aid him in pulling sle eve off. He can then remove coat easily. Continue u ntil he can 
remove coat without this help.
Encourage dressing and undressing of dolls.
Practice activity when it is functional as when child comes in from outdoors with coat on.

cards.title: Takes off pants when unfastened .

Tasks.Action:
Have the child grasp the elastic top of pants an d encourage child to pull them down. This can also be done by  
    hooking thumb in top of top of pants and pullin g down.
Show the child by having him watch older brother  or sister remove pants.
Praise the child for his attempts and successes.

Unfasten pants and pull down. Have child pull th em over feet. Next let child take them off from his  knees,  
    from hips and then all the way by himself.
Let him play dress-up and use larger clothing th an his own.

cards.title: Zips and unzips large zipper without working  catch.

Tasks.Action:
Place a strong piece of string through the hole in the zipper, or use a small bead strung with stri ng and thread it 
 
    through the hole. Have the child grasp the bead  or string to move the zipper up and down. As child  becomes    
    proficient, remove the bead and begin to decrea se size of string having the child grasp the zipper  pull.

Use a large zipper to start, then substitute it for the same size zipper that is on the child's clo thing. Let him 
practice zipping and unzipping first with the cloth ing off and then with the clothing on.
Guide child's hand through the zipping motion. G radually decrease aid.
Let child zip and unzip purse containing candy o r small toy.

cards.title: Uses words or gestures indicating need to go  to bathroom .

Tasks.Action:
Use the same words each time you are speaking of  toileting and use those same words when the child watches 
you go. When the child uses the words, immediately praise him and take him to the bathroom.
Use training pants instead of diapers during the  day.

Praise success and ignore accidents. Watch for g estures (pulling self, fidgeting) which might mean he has to   
    go. Praises the child, say the word associated with toileting and immediately take the child to th e bathroom.

Have family members announce when they are going , to the bathroom using same words as child is bein g  
    taught.

cards.title: Feeds self-using spoon and cup with some spi lling .

Tasks.Action: Place small portion on the plate and a small amo unt of liquid in cup to make the eating task less g igantic.

Have the child eat with the rest of the family s o he can watch and imitate others. Encourage the ch ild while he  
    feeds himself and praise his success. Maintain a happy relaxed atmosphere.
If the child can feed himself easier from a bowl , let him use it and change to using a plate later.
Parent may need to finish feeding him if he tire s.
Refrain from scolding child for spilling or " ma king a mess".

cards.title: Takes towel from parent and wipes hands and face.

Tasks.Action:
Show the child how to do the task guiding his hands  and giving instructions. Have child imitate you as  you 
dry your face and hands.
Praise the child for drying himself well.
Encourage water play by washing and drying the doll .
Have child use hand towel instead of bath towel so he can more easily manage it.
Give the child a towel that is his special one. Dec orate it or put his name on it.

Reward the child for drying well by allowing him to  put lotion on his hands, which will allow him to p ractice 
a similar hand motion.

cards.title: Sucks liquid from glass or cup using straw .

Tasks.Action:
Place a large plastic straw in liquid and hold the tip of the straw with your finger. The liquid will stay in the 
straw. With the straw in horizontal (-) position, p lace it in child’s mouth. You will feel the pressur e on your 
finger when the child sucks and you can release liq uid with each sucking movement. Gradually lower the  
straw to the normal vertical (|) position.

Cut the straw in half and place it into a cup and e ncourage the child to suck his favorite liquid. To increase 
thirst, feed the child a few salty crackers prior t o giving him the straw. Praise success.
Start with a very short straw and gradually increas e the length of the straw.

Use oversize straw you can buy in 5 & 10 with colou red sugar in it. Remove sugar, cut straw into very short 
lengths at first. Gradually increase length of stra w.

Take a small covered Tupperware cup and cut a small  hole in the cover. Push a small piece of plastic t ubing 
through. Squeezing the sides of the cup will start the liquid and make sucking initially easier. Have either the 
child or parent squeeze the cup.

cards.title: Scoops with fork .

Tasks.Action:
Use foods that can be easily picked up with a fork (larger pieces of semi- soft vegetables, meat, chun ks of 
fruit) and are appealing to the child.

Encourage the use of a fork for eating from a plate , place a spoon on the table only with a bowl, perh aps to 
finish meal when he tires.
Praise child for scooping with fork.
Scoop navy beans form one bowl to another as a game .

Put your hand over child’s hand and help him scoop.  Gradually decrease aid until child is scooping 
independently. Praise success.

cards.title: Chews and swallows only edible substances .

Tasks.Action:
Put two real objects before child, one that is food  and the other a non-edible item. Ask child which i tem we 
eat. Praise child for correct response. When child has mastered this task, move to pictures of edible and non-
edible substances and repeat procedures.
Praise child for not putting toys in mouth.

If child does put inedible items in his mouth tell him to take it out and explain why he shouldn’t put  the item 
in his mouth.

cards.title: Dries hands without help when given towel .

Tasks.Action:
Practice drying hands, instructing and showing h im how you dry your hands. Have child imitate you. Make  
    this a daily responsibility of child. Praise ch ild for drying his hands well.
Dry your hands at the same time as your child. E ncourage child to dry all the water off hands.
Have a special towel for the child. Put his name  on it or make animal face on it.
Put up low towel bar so child can reach towel an d hang it up himself.

cards.title: Asks to go to bathroom, even if too late to avoid accident .

Tasks.Action: Watch the time care fully and ask the child if h e needs to use the bathroom.
Avoid restrictive or hard to manage clothes. Kee p him in training pants rather than diapers.
Remind him periodically and praise him generousl y when he asks to use bathroom.

Ignore accidents by not changing the child immed iately and by encouraging the child to do much of t he job of  
   changing clothing himself.
Have family members model asking to use bathroom .

cards.title: Controls drooling .

Tasks.Action:
Simple reminders to the child to close his mouth  and swallow will help make the child aware of the need   
    to swallow.
Have the child imitate a "sucking in" sound that  you make, then reminds the child to swallow.

Using a straw to drink liquids and then thickene d drinks (milk shakes) will help the child develop practice and  
    exercise in sucking and swallowing.

Blowing cotton or ping pong balls across a table  or blowing soap bubbles and party favors will prov ide  
    exercise for the mouth, lip and tongue muscles.
Chewing gum or dried fruit will also control dro oling while chewing is occurring.

Place small amount of dry jello mix between lowe r lip and teeth. As saliva collects the child will taste the jelly  
    and be encouraged to swallow.

Use Kool-Aid at room temperature in a squirt bot tle. Place a small amount between lower lip and tee th. Tell  
   the child to swallow. The child will associate t he liquid in the front of his mouth with swallowing .

Placing honey or peanut butter on lips and encou raging child to lick it off will provide exercise f or tongue and  
    lip muscles.

cards.title:
Urinates or defecates in potty three times p er week when 
 placed on potty.

Tasks.Action: If the child does not remain dry for atleast tw o hours in between wetting, he is not yet ready for  training.
Allow the child to watch you and rest of the fa mily use the toilet. Let him listen to and look at the result.

Watch the time carefully and when the child may  be ready to wet, place the child on the potty. Do not make  
     the child sits for longer than 5 minutes. Stay  with the child while he's sitting.
Use the same words each time you speak of toile ting-such as "potty", "pee-pee", "poop".
If the child becomes frustrated, stop for few d ays and then try again.
Encourage and praise if child is successful in his toileting attempts and let him flush as a rewar d.
DO NOT scold or punish.
Give the child a drink of orange juice 10 minut es before he is placed on potty.

Running water in the sink or placing the child' s hand in warm water may help to increase the likel ihood of  
     urination.

cards.title: Puts on shoes.

Tasks.Action:
Begin with shoes at least one size too large. Show the child how to place them on his feet, slide toes  into 
shoes and pull shoe over heel. Reduce the size of t he shoe to correct size. Repeat. Praise the child: "Good 
______ you're learning to put on your shoes by your self.
Begin with shoes having stiff heels and uppers. Lat er try tennis shoes or slippers-type shoes.
Play with dolls, putting shoes on and taking them o ff.

Initially you put the child's shoe on most of the w ay and let him fit his heel in. When he child do th is , put 
only  half of his foot in. Let the child do more of  the work himself.
Show the child how to loosen the laces if he has to  tie shoes.

cards.title: Brushes teeth in intimation .

Tasks.Action: Keep child’s toothbrush and toothpaste in a special  place.

Brush your teeth at the same time as child so he ca n watch you and imitate your motions. Praise child for 
being successful
Give child physical guidance during brushing. Gradu ally reduce aid as child’s skills become more profi cient.
Let child look at self in mirror while brushing.

At first, put your hand over his and help him make the up and down motion. Continue to give at least v erbal 
directions until the child can adequately brush in imitation.

cards.title: Takes off simple clothing that has been unf astened .

Tasks.Action:
Make it a nightly responsibility of the child to re move dress or pants. Continue to encourage and let the child 
practice. Compliment child on being a big boy (or g irl).
Give child a sticker to put on chart each time he t akes off clothing without help.
Practice undressing dolls.

Don’t expect the child to undress himself completel y at first. Start with one or two items. When he ma sters 
these add another item.

Regardless of what clothing item you choose to begi n teaching give the child physical aid with verbal 
directions. Gradually withdraw the physical and ver bal help as the child gains in skill.

cards.title: Uses bathroom for bowel movements, one dayti me accident per week .

Tasks.Action:
The child should have some regularity of bowel move ments before he is expected to use the bathroom 
regularly. Before initiating training, chart the ti me of the child’s bowel movements for one week. Use  this as 
a guide to the times to place him on the toilet.

Allow and encourage the child to watch other family  members. Exaggerate your gestures somewhat and let  
him see the results before flushing.

When he is regular, place him on the potty about th e same time each day. Watch for gestures that will alert 
you that he is ready to go. Encourage and praise th e child if he is successful in his toileting attemp t. Let child 
do his own charting.

cards.title: Washes hands and faces using soap when adult  regulates water .

Tasks.Action: Wash your hands and face and encourage the child to  imitate your movements.

Give verbal directions as child washes hands and fa ce until he no longer needs verbal help. Praise chi ld for 
washing hands and face without verbal or physical h elp.
Let child look in mirror. Put a colored chalk mark on face and let him see if he can wash it off.

Put stopper in sink. Fill sink with water for the c hild. Let him wash his hands and face independently  and 
drain the water. Put chart in bathroom where he can  record that he has done so. Put pictures on wall o f the 
steps he is to follow so he won’t require as much s upervision.

cards.title: Asks to go to bathroom during day in time to  avoid accidents.

Tasks.Action: Dress the child in elastic waist pants for easy rem oval. Keep child in training pants.

Gradually stop placing on toilet regularly, allowin g him to begin to tell you when he needs to use the  
bathroom. If a toilet is being used, be sure to pro vide him with stool or steps so he can get on by hi mself.

If child is playing outdoors, watch carefully for s igns of need and ask him at regular times if he has  to use the 
bathroom.

Use reminders, praise and rewards for telling you t hat he has to go; i.e., keep wall chart and mark a happy 
face when he tells you he has to go and then does.

When you take child to an unfamiliar place make sur e to tell him where the bathroom is or to let him k now 
that one is available so accidents can be avoided.

cards.title: Places coat on hook placed at child’s height .

Tasks.Action:
Sew a metal chain in a semi-circle onto the inside of the collar of his coat. Have child take hold of this and 
hang it over a hook the child can reach.

Practice hanging potholders with loops over the hoo k. Begin with a large loop sewn inside child’s coat  and 
gradually reduce size to normal.
Practice activity when it is functional. When child  comes in from outdoors with coat on, have him hang  it up.
Put name or animal sticker by hook so child knows t hat it is his special place to hang his coat.

cards.title: Stays dry during naps.

Tasks.Action: Put child on potty just before naptime.
Cut down on liquid intake before naptime.

Praise child for staying dry. Do not punish or scol d if child wets bed. Have him help change sheets if  wet. 
Use plastic mattress cover.
Go to child as soon as he wakes. If he is dry, take  him to toilet immediately.

If you hear the child awakening, go in and have him  go to the bathroom immediately. Many children wet as 
they are waking up.

cards.title: Avoid hazards such as sharp furniture corner s, open stairs .

Tasks.Action: Take him to the stairs or to protruding furniture. Explain the danger. Show him how to avoid.
Tape some signal to area (red paper) to remind him of danger when he is close to the area.

Should the child accidentally hurt himself by not b eing alert to a hazard, don’t punish him further bu t take 
advantage of the opportunity by talking to him abou t avoiding the hazard in the future.

cards.title:
Uses napkins when reminded. 
.

Tasks.Action: Encourage the use of napkins using printed and colo red napkins.
Have him imitate other family members and praise hi m when he does.

Remind him to use the napkins and if necessary help  him use it gradually, letting the child do more fo r 
himself.
Ask child to put napkins on the table before each m eal.
Play “ tea” with dolls and stress using napkins.

cards.title: Stabs food with fork and brings to mouth.

Tasks.Action:
Use appealing food that is easy to pierce with fork  but will not fall apart (marshmallow, banana, cake , hot 
dog). Allow the child to use spoon for peas, etc.
Demonstrate how to stab fork in food and eat. Prais e child for correct imitation.

Initially guide the child’s hand and give him verba l cues. As he gains proficiency withdraw the physic al and 
verbal cues. Praise and encourage his successes.

cards.title: Pours from small pitcher (6-8 oz) into glass  without help.

Tasks.Action: Show the child how to place the glass and tip the p itcher to pour. Let him practice at the sink with w ater.
Let him pour his own glass from a small pitcher tha t is only partly full. Play “ tea party” using toy dishes.
Show him how to pour from one small object to anoth er.
Encourage water play, using a pitcher and a cup.
Use colored water to motivate child. Use rice as su bstance to pour from pitcher.
Use plastic pitcher and glass to avoid breakage.
Let child practice pouring water into various sizes  of containers during bath play.
Allow child to help you water plants.

cards.title: Unfastens snap on clothing.

Tasks.Action: Attach snaps to pieces of cloth and have child unfa sten.
Use discarded articles of clothing for unfastening practice or use doll clothes.

Start the child with help in pulling the snap apart . Gradually decrease aid. You hold and have child p ull. Then 
have him hold one side and pull other.
When child is able to unsnap, have practice activit y on an article of clothing he is wearing.

Make the skill functional for the child, when he ca n unsnap clothing have him assume the responsibilit y of 
doing this when undressing.

Use two washcloths, one for mother and one for the child. Put soap on the washcloth and encourage him to 
wash his arms and legs. Praise child for washing hi mself. Have child imitate your washing movements wi th 
his cloth.
Let him play in the tub with toys, bubble bath, etc , to make the bathing situation pleasurable.
With chalk, draw happy faces on doll or on child an d let him scrub them off.

When you put the child in the tub allow him time to  wash his own arms and legs without your direct 
supervision. When you finish bathing him praise him  for doing this himself. Make him aware that this i s his 
responsibility.

cards.title: Puts on socks.

Tasks.Action:
Put sock on most of the way. With your hands over h is, pull sock up. Reinforce. Gradually decrease dis tance 
of putting sock on. Also decrease physical aid unti l child can grasp and pull by himself.
Start with large socks that are easy to pull on and  work down to child’s normal sock size.
Be sure to show the child where the heel part of th e sock should be.

cards.title: Puts on coat, sweater, shirt.

Tasks.Action: Begin with a short-sleeved shirt. Use garment one o r 2 sizes too big.

Have child put one arm into coat; reach behind with  other arm and place arm into second armhole. Hold coat 
for him initially. Gradually decrease aid.

Place coat on low table with collar towards child a nd the opening facing up. Have him place his arms i n the 
sleeves and flip coat over his head.

cards.title: Finds front of clothing.

Tasks.Action: Sew tags in back of clothing to help child distingu ish between front and back. (do the same for doll c lothing)
Praise child for putting clothes on correctly.

Show child front and back of his own clothing. Desc ribe and point out the pertinent differences betwee n front 
and back (pocket, zippers, buttons, etc.)

cards.title: Feeds self-entire meal.

Tasks.Action: Have child eat his meals with family. Set a place f or him with a fork, spoon, plate and glass.

Encourage child to eat by himself. Give him more at tention for eating by himself than for not doing so . If he 
doesn’t eat by himself, verbally instruct him to do  so and physically guide him.
Put chart by table. Put smiley face or animal stick er on chart for each meal that he eats all by himse lf.
Give child small helpings of each food.
Put a treat (sticker or picture) under the child’s plate that he can have if entire meal is eaten.

cards.title: Dresses self with help on pullover shirts an d all fasteners.

Tasks.Action: Put shirt over head, continue holding it while he p uts in his arms and pulls the shirt down.

Place his coat on floor, neckline facing the child.  He bends, places arms in holes and flips coat over  head. 
Praise the child as he is able to do more without h elp. Encourage child to dress without help. Praise success. 
Describe how fasteners work as they are fastened. E ncourage the child to try fasteners.
Put small treats for child in things that can be un fastened (purses, snap pockets etc.)

Even if it takes more time for the child to dress h imself, allow him to do it. Let him know that you e xpect this 
of him. Plan your schedule to allow for the extra t ime this may take in the morning so you don’t have to do it 
for him because of lack of time.

cards.title: Wipes nose when reminded.

Tasks.Action:
Place the tissues where child can easily reach them . Tell the child when to get a tissue. Praise child  for wiping  
his own nose and for throwing away the tissue in a waste paper basket.
Show child how to wipe nose. Have him imitate you. Praise child for wiping his nose when you remind hi m.
Have a special handkerchief for the child that is h is to use.
Let child carry small packet of tissues in a pocket , particularly if he has a cold.

cards.title: Wakes up dry two mornings out of seven.

Tasks.Action:
Ask child if he has gone to bathroom just before go ing to bed. If not, take him or remind him to go on  his 
own.
Do not place diapers on child at night; use plastic  to protect mattress.
Limit the amount of the child drinks after supper m eal.
Wake the child and take him to the toilet before yo u go to bed.

Praise the child or reward with special activity fo r staying dry all night. Happy face stickers or oth er special 
stickers can be placed on a chart or on the bathroo m door for each successful night. If the child has an 
accident, don’t criticize him but involve him in he lping in changing sheets.

If the child has difficulty staying dry over night,  try checking him every two hours one night to find  out what 
time he is wetting. Set an alarm so you can wake hi m to go to the bathroom before his usual wetting ti me.

cards.title: Males urinate in toilet standing up.

Tasks.Action: Have other male’s model for the child.

Instruct child to stand in front of toilet, hold pe nis and urinate in toilet. Praise child, telling hi m he’s a big boy 
when he stands to urinate. Don’t expect perfect aim  initially. A stool may be necessary.

Make “ boats” out of sheets of toilet paper and enc ourage child to aim at these and “sink” them or flo at a 
ping-pong ball in toilet and ask child to try to “h it” it.
Put chart in bathroom. Let child put smiley face or  sticker on it when he urinates standing up.

cards.title: Initiates and completes dressing and undress ing except fasteners 75% of time.

Tasks.Action: Encourage child to take initiative in dressing. Pra ise him for his initiative in taking care of dressi ng needs.
Allow the child to dress himself even though he may  take a longer time. Praise him for his accomplishm ents.

Continue to encourage dressing of dolls. Talk to th e child about differences of clothing, what to wear  to bed, 
in house, for dress up, in the rain, etc.

Allow child to begin selecting clothes to wear by g iving him choices: "Would you like to wear your red  or 
blue shirt today, Johnnie”?

Begin by telling child it is either time to dress o n undress. Go with him and give him verbal instruct ions. 
Gradually stop going with him. Just tell him it’s t ime to dress. Put sticker on chart when child does so 
independently.

At night help child select clothing for next day. P ut it out where child can easily reach it. Do the s ame with 
pajamas. At the appropriate time, tell the child th at his clothing is out and he should put it on. Gra dually 
reduce aid by getting out only the clothing the chi ld cannot reach and let him get out his own underwe ar, 
shoes and socks.

cards.title: Snaps or hooks clothing.

Tasks.Action: Sew snaps and hooks on pieces of cloth. Help child by guiding hands to snap or hook. Gradually decreas e aid.

Have child watch you snap or hook as you describe w hat you are doing. Ask him to do the same thing as you 
give verbal instructions.
Fasten snaps or hooks on back of happy face or anim al. Practice snapping or hooking on to a background .

Begin by holding the bottom part of the snap and ha ving the child push the top part onto it. Gradually  let the 
child hold the bottom part of the snap as he pushes  the top part on.

Hold the loop part of the hook and let child hook t he other side into it. As child gains skill have hi m hold the 
eye himself as he puts hook into it.
Begin using very large snaps or hooks and gradually  reduce the size.

Practice on clothing on a table or on someone else.  When child is proficient here, let him practice on  clothing 
he is wearing. Make ”belts” out of material scraps with snaps or hooks on them. Let child put them on and 
snap or hook them.

cards.title: Blows nose when reminded.

Tasks.Action: Instruct child how to blow his nose. Demonstrate fo r him as you describe what to do.
Help child at first by guiding hands and instructin g when to blow.
When child needs to blow nose, tell him blow or wip e his nose. Praise when he does.

Have the child wear clothing with a pocket. Give hi m a kleenex or handkerchief to carry in his pocket.  Praise 
him when he uses it himself or remind him when nece ssary.

cards.title: Avoids common dangers (i.e., broken glass)

Tasks.Action:
Explain why certain objects and areas in house are dangerous. (Remind child why he shouldn’t touch hot  
stove.)

Use pictures of common dangers mixed with pictures of harmless things. Ask child which picture is 
dangerous and which one is Ok.

cards.title: Puts coat on hanger and replaces hanger on l ow bar with instructions.

Tasks.Action: Have hanger within easy reach of child.
Remind the child to hang up his coat and encourage him with spoken instructions.

Praise him for hanging up his coat. If he should fo rget and throw his coat on the floor or bed, have h im put his 
coat back on and walk outside, and immediately re-e nter the house to hang up his coat.
Lay coat on floor and show child how hanger fits in  the arms and shoulders. Pick up and hang on the lo w bar.
If possible use plastic or wooden child-sized hange r so it fits coat.

cards.title: Brushes teeth when given verbal instructions .

Tasks.Action:
Use a small toothbrush and let the child hold it un der the water. He can brush without the paste. Then  add a 
small amount of paste.

Have the child brush at the same time the parent do es. Encourage him to imitate your actions. Let him watch 
himself and parent in the mirror that is placed at a height where he can see himself.

Be consistent in this activity and encourage and he lp the child brush his teeth twice daily at approxi mately the 
same times each day.
Keep toothbrush and child’s own toothpaste in a spe cial place where he can find it each day.

cards.title: Puts on mittens.

Tasks.Action: Show child how the whole hand fits in the mitten wi th a special place for the thumb.
Use a comfortable size of mitten for child. Avoid u sing small or excessively large mittens.

Use mittens made to look like animal heads (buttons  for eyes, red between thumb and hand for mouth) to  
motivate child.
Help child put on mitten at first. Reduce aid as ch ild becomes more proficient.

Help child practice putting on mittens with his bar e hand and become proficient before teaching him to  put on 
the second mitten with hand that already has mitten  on.

cards.title: Unbuttons large buttons on button board or j acket placed on table.

Tasks.Action:
Take a piece of cloth, cut it in half and make a bu ttonhole ¾” wide on one side. On other side sew ½” button. 
Show the child by guiding his hands in buttoning. P ush the button partially through the hole and have the 
child finish the task. Give child less aid each tim e until he is unbuttoning independently.

Place the coat or piece of clothing with buttons on  a table or the floor so that he can more easily ma nipulate 
the buttons and the material

Encourage him to unbutton your dress or shirt and l et him unbutton his own clothing. Praise the child as he 
improves in skill.

Use a piece of cloth with three large buttonholes t o wrap around a picture or puzzle. Have child unbut ton 
cloth to get his picture or puzzle. If material is stretchy, it will fit over several sizes of objects .

Cut out a large buttonhole in the center of several  pieces of felt. Attach a large button to a piece o f yarn and 
attach yarn to center of plastic coffee-can lid. Yo u put the pieces on and let the child unbutton them  to take 
them off.

cards.title: Buttons large buttons on button board or jac ket placed on table.

Tasks.Action:
The button should measure about ½” and the hole sho uld be ¾”. Work with the material on table or floor  for 
easier handling.

Guide the child in holding the shirt with thumb and  first finger placing the tip of his thumb in butto nhole. 
Guide the child in holding button with his thumb an d index finger of other hand, putting edge of butto n 
against tip of thumb through hole. Child can push s o that the button is touching index finger and is o ver the 
hole. When the button is almost through the hole, h elp child take hold of button with his hand and let  child 
pull the button through the hole. Praise the child as he’s working.

Start backward with the button almost through the h ole and let him finish the task. Gradually let him do more 
for himself, by leaving more of the button out of t he hole. Continue praising as the child gains in sk ill.
Use pieces of felt with buttonhole and large button  on string attached to plastic coffee-can lid.

cards.title: Puts on boots.

Tasks.Action:
Demonstrate how to pull on boots. Help child as he tries to pull on boots. Praise his attempts. Help h im pull if 
he has difficulty. Gradually reduce aid as he becom es more proficient.
Practice with boots that are a little too big. When  he is proficient at this have him use correct size d boots.

If child has suede or cloth shoe that rubs against lining of boot and makes it difficult to put boot o n, put 
plastic bag over shoe so it slides easily into the boot.
Using the child’s boot, have him place his foot wit h just his sock on into the boot.

cards.title: Cleans up spills, getting own cloth.

Tasks.Action: Have a rag or sponge for cleaning up spills in a sp ecial place.
Encourage all family members to model cleaning up t heir spills.
Do not punish for accidental spills.
Praise child for cleaning up spills acceptably.

cards.title: Avoids poisons and all harmful substances.

Tasks.Action: Label poisonous substances and instruct child not t o touch them. Use the ”Mr. Yuk” stickers.

Put assorted bottles in front of child, several wit h Mr. Yuk stickers and several with regular labels.  Have the 
child sort the bottles so that he can recognize and  find the sticker even if it isn’t facing him.

cards.title: Unbuttons own clothing.

Tasks.Action: Use front buttoning clothes. Praise child for succe ssfully unbuttoning.

Have child put on clothing with large buttons and p ractice unbuttoning these items. Gradually reduce s ize of 
buttons. Give verbal and physical aid as is necessa ry.

Initially unbutton all but one button and have chil d do that one. Gradually increase the number of but tons to 
be unfastened at each try.

Partially unbutton each button and let the child fi nish the task. Give verbal directions as he does so . Gradually 
do less and less of the unbuttoning until the child  can unbutton independently.

When the child can unbutton his own clothing make t his his responsibility in undressing. Remember to p raise 
his independence in this.

cards.title: Buttons own clothing.

Tasks.Action:
Have child put on shirt or sweater with large butto ns and practice buttoning these. Gradually reduce s ize of 
button. Help child with verbal and physical aid as is necessary.

If his coat has buttons, encourage him to button so  he can go outside. If necessary pull button partia lly 
through for him.
Take turns buttoning with the child. You do one of his buttons, then he does one.

cards.title: Clears place at table.

Tasks.Action:
Show child where to place his dishes and trash. Be sure the other family members do this too so the ch ild can 
imitate them.
Let these be daily tasks for the entire family and praise the child for helping.
Use unbreakable dishes.

Initially help the child or give him verbal reminde rs to clear his place. Later reinforce him only whe n he 
initiates and completes activity independently.

cards.title: Puts zipper foot in catch.?

Tasks.Action: Show child how foot fits in catch.
Hold the catch for him as he puts in foot and zips.
Be certain that catch is working easily.
Try activity with article of clothing on table then  progress to clothing being worn by child.
Praise child for inserting foot in catch and zippin g without aid.

Use large zipper and gradually reduce size. Start t eaching with zipper on table before having the chil d work 
the zipper on items he is wearing.

Have a large separating zipper sewn on strips of do uble thickness of” pellon”. Child can practice with  2 flat 
pieces.

cards.title: Washes hands and face.

Tasks.Action: The child may need to be reminded when to wash his hands and face.
Praise the child each time he completes this task s uccessfully.
Let child have a special bar of soap, towel and was hcloth in place he can reach.
Provide steps or stool for child to use if needed t o see in mirror or reach faucet.

Initially show child how to use washcloth to wash f ace and hands. Give physical aid if necessary. Grad ually 
withdraw aid until child needs only verbal cues and  then can wash face and hands unassisted.

Put up a chart in the bathroom and let child put a smiley, clean face up when he successfully complete s the 
task himself. Have child drain sink and hang up tow el as part of task before rewarding him.
Be a good model for child at table by using correct  utensils. Talk about what utensil you’re using and  why.
Review before each meal what utensil should be used  for each food. Have the child tell you, if he can.
Praise the child at end of meal for using the prope r utensils.

cards.title: Wakes from sleep during night to use toilet or stays dry all night.

Tasks.Action: Limit liquid intake before bedtime.
Use night light in bathroom and bedroom if needed b y child.
Use sticker charts and praise to reward child for s taying dry.
If bed is wet in morning, have child help change sh eets. Do not punish or scold. Use plastic mattress cover.

Initially wake child at a particular time during ni ght to use bathroom. Gradually have him assume 
responsibility for getting up.
If the bathroom and the child’s bedroom are on diff erent floors, place one potty chair in the child’s bedroom.

cards.title: Wipes and blows nose 75% of the time when ne eded without reminders.

Tasks.Action: Keep tissues within easy reach in bathrooms and bed rooms. Encourage and praise use of tissues.
If child has a bad cold, give him a small packet of  tissues to carry around.
Give child a handkerchief that is his to carry in h is pocket.
Praise child each time he blows or wipes nose witho ut reminding.

cards.title: Bathes self except for back, neck and ears.

Tasks.Action: Use a non-slip mat in the tub.
Use verbal instructions to remind him to wash all p arts of his body.
Child may use small toy boat or other floating toy if he helps wash himself.
Use animal shaped sponge for washing.
Give child a choice between 2 different colored tow els if he washes acceptably.

When you put the child in the bathtub tell him how long he has to bathe. Set a timer if necessary. Tel l him 
that you expect him to be clean when the timer goes  off. Check and praise him if he has washed himself  
acceptably in the time allowed.

Have him take his bath 10 to 15 minutes prior to hi s favorite T.V. show so he will be motivated to com plete 
the bath and be clean in time to see the show.

cards.title: Uses knife for spreading soft toppings on to ast.

Tasks.Action: Keep butter or margarine soft. Use toast, as it wil l not tear as easily.
Use dull knife with large handle that is easy to ho ld.
Show child how to spread. Encourage imitation.
Use peanut butter or jam as a reward.
Physically guide child’s hand and gradually reduce amount of aid.

cards.title: Buckles and unbuckles belt on dress or pants  and shoe.

Tasks.Action: Physically help child buckle and unbuckle. Graduall y reduce aid.
Practice with belt on table. When child is proficie nt at this, have him practice while wearing belt.

Use belt with large buckle at first. When child is proficient with large buckle, reduce the size to th at 
appropriate for a child’s belt.

cards.title: Dresses self completely, including all front  fastening except ties.

Tasks.Action:
Lay out the clothing in the order for him to put it  on and give the child help in choosing the appropr iate 
clothing for the weather.

Encourage him to dress himself, praise and complime nt him. Make dressing his daily task and allow enou gh 
for him to do it.

cards.title: Serves self at table, parent holds serving d ish.

Tasks.Action: Use plastic dishes and large serving spoon.
Guide the child’s hand through the first few trials .
Hold serving bowl close to the child’s plate to avo id spilling.
Praise successful results.
Either hold bowl in front of plate or to the right if child is left-handed, to left if right-handed.
Give the child verbal instruction to assure that th e child takes an appropriate sized serving.

cards.title: Helps set table by correctly placing plates,  napkins and utensils with verbal clues.

Tasks.Action: Place silver in drawer separating knives, forks, sp oons.
