Help him count correct number needed by counting wi th him.
Keep dishes in low cupboard so child can help or se t the dishes on the counter so he can reach them.
Set the table with the child the first few times, t hen gradually withdraw your help.
Praise the child for helping. Tell the family how t he child helped set the table.
You set one place at the table to serve as a model for the child. Let him set the remaining places.

Draw an entire place setting on a paper towel and s tart by having child placed the correct utensils, e tc. 
directly on top.

You set up the places eliminating the plate perhaps , or a utensil. See if the child can provide the mi ssing 
object or put everything but spoons out and have th e child complete: then everything but spoons and fo rk, etc.

cards.title: Brushes teeth.

Tasks.Action:
Help the child to make this a habit by taking him w ith you at the same times each day when you brush y our 
teeth. Have him brush his teeth at the same time ea ch day.
Set up a chart and every time he brushes his teeth he gets a star or a happy face as a reward.

Use child-size toothbrush. When child needs a new b rush, reward him for good brushing by letting him s elect 
it in the store.

cards.title: Goes to bathroom in time, undresses, wipes s elf, flushes toilet and dresses unaided .

Tasks.Action:
Show the child how to wipe himself and flush the to ilet. Encourage the child to do this on his own. Gr adually 
withdraw all help and instructions and allow the ch ild to do these tasks on his own.
Praise the child for being a big boy or girl as he learns and remembers to wipe himself and flush the toilet.
Give child a happy face or sticker to put on chart each time he remembers and carries through with act ivity.

Put a series of pictures on the wall in the bathroo m of the things he is to do (wipe, flush, turn out light) to help 
him remember if necessary.

cards.title: Combs or brushes long hair.

Tasks.Action:
Let him watch you comb and brush your hair. Guide h is hand and give instructions as he looks into mirr or 
and watches himself.
Give child his own comb and brush.
Praise him for looking so nice.
Help unsnarl tangles before child begins to comb ha ir.
Practice combing dolls’ hair with doll comb.
If child combs hair well, allow to choose a bright bow or barrette to wear.
Make hanging up clothing a part of child’s daily ro utine.
Praise the child when he hangs up clothes without r eminders.
Adjust closet bar so it is reachable by child.
Provide small hangers so that the child’s clothing stays on the hanger.

Show the child how to put the items on the hanger a nd give him verbal and physical assistance as long as is 
necessary.
Use padded or foam covered hangers to make it easie r to keep garment on hanger.

cards.title: Goes about neighborhood without constant sup ervision.

Tasks.Action: Take the child over to a neighbor’s home telling an d showing the child where his boundaries are to be.

Let child take a note to a neighbor or if the home is in the country have the child take a note to Dad  in the 
garage or barn.
Allow the child to visit a friend for a given lengt h of time but he should tell you where he will be.

Praise him for staying within defined limits and fo r telling you where he is going and for coming home  on 
time.

cards.title: Laces shoes.

Tasks.Action:
Use lacing board with four eyes. Ask child to imita te lacing motions. As child gains skill, progress t o lacing 
board with more eyes. Then have child lace his own shoes.
Practice on adult shoe or large wooden lacing shoe.

Tie a white lace and a black lace together and use as one lace in large shoe. This will help child rem ember 
which side to release and pick up as he laces. If c hild needs help, give verbal instructions, using co lor as a 
cue.

cards.title: Ties shoes.

Tasks.Action:
Show the child how to tie a knot by letting him wat ch you as you do it slowly. Make one loop for the c hild 
and have the other one partially through the knot. He holds the completed loop with thumb and index fi nger 
with the other hand and pulls. You make first loop.  Help him hold it if necessary. Show him how to pus h the 
other one through the loose loop and pull tight. Yo u cross strings and pull tight, he makes both loops , tucks 
one over and under the other and pulls. 
2    Praise and reward the child as he goes through  these activities and let him tie your shoes or Dad ’s shoes as an  
      additional reward.
Use flat, easy-to-grasp laces.( Round laces are  slippery and more difficult to tie.)

Have child imitate following; 1) Cross ties. 2)  Make first knot. 3) Make a loop with one tie and c all it a tree. 4) 
 
     Call the other tie a bunny and tell child it i s hopping around the tree as you wrap second tie ar ound first  
5) Make a loop with the second tie and push it unde r the bunny trail. This is the bunny’s ear. 6) Tell  child to   
pull the tree and the bunny’s ear. 7) Shoes are now  tied.

Use large colored yarn( for tying girl’s hair.).  Wrap around sitting child’s leg above knee. Practi ce tying knot.  
    Make loop and hold with thumb and forefinger. B ring yarn around thumb and forefinger. Push yarn an d thumb   
     through loop with forefinger of other hand. Re lease and pull loops.

cards.title: Is responsible for one weekly household task  and does it upon request.

Tasks.Action: Choose task that child can easily do(i.e. sweep, du st, straighten books, straighten toy room)

Keep a chart of activities on bedroom wall or refri gerator. Have child draw happy face each week he fi nishes 
his task.
Praise child for carrying out his responsibility.
Give child a choice of which of two tasks that he w ould like to do for the week.

cards.title: Selects appropriate clothing for temperature  and occasion.

Tasks.Action: Let child select clothes for each day. Praise him f or making appropriate choices.

Look through clothing section of catalog and talk a bout when/where one would wear certain items (coats , 
raincoats, swimsuits, dresses).
Use paper dolls. Describe a particular kind of day to the child and have him choose the clothing.

At first, give the child a choice of 2-3 items of c lothing to choose from. As he gains skill, let him choose 
independently. If choices are incorrect, explain to  him why they are not appropriate.

cards.title: Stops at curb, looks both ways, and crosses  street without verbal reminders.

Tasks.Action: Remind child how to cross street before going to a friend’s house or to the store.
Ask child what he should do each time he crosses st reet.
Praise child for crossing street safely and correct ly.
Walk with child and show him how to cross street. W hen he demonstrates skill, let him go alone.
Role-play crossing street safely or use dolls and t oy cars to demonstrate.
Give child a safety star- shaped badge to wear when  he crosses street correctly.

cards.title: Serves self at table and passes serving dish .

Tasks.Action: Make sure the serving dishes are mot too heavy or h ot.
Allow for extra time while child learns task, and t hank him when he has passed the dish to you.
Let him hold on to dish along with you until child gains necessary skill to do it independently.

cards.title: Prepares own cold cereal.

Tasks.Action: Keep cereal and bowls in easy-to-reach place. Store  milk in an easy-to-pour container.
Use unbreakable bowls.
Praise child for preparing cereal without help.

Begin by giving the child step-by-step directions t o get his own cereal. As he gains proficiency let h im do it 
independently.

Put chart on wall showing each step that child must  carry out to get own cereal. Put sticker on chart each time 
he does task independently.
Give child treat of raisins or bananas on cereal if  he fixes it independently.

cards.title: Is responsible for one daily household task (i.e. setting table, taking out trash)

Tasks.Action: Mark on a chart when task is completed each day. Ke ep chart in visible location.
Praise child for remembering to complete task.

Put up chart with picture of child doing task to re mind him of it. Let him mark on chart each day as h e does 
his job.

If child forgets to do chore, set up weekly reinfor cement. Child must do task specified number of time s to 
earn the reinforcement. Number of times should grad ually be increased until he is doing it daily.

Put 7 construction paper spoons or trashcans, etc. in child’s room where he can store them. Each day, as child 
completes task, let him stick one up on refrigerato r door or on door of his room.

cards.title: Adjusts water temperature for shower or bath .

Tasks.Action:
Let child adjust water temperature in sink first. S how child how to turn faucet(s) to obtain a good ba lance of 
hot and cold water. Allow child to do this on his o wn with verbal instructions, then without instructi ons as 
you watch.
Let him practice adjusting temperature for you as y ou are preparing to take bath.
Instruct child to always turn on cold water first.

cards.title: Prepares own sandwich.

Tasks.Action: Keep items child will need in easy-to-reach places.
Use serrated table knife.
Have child imitate steps at first, then make sandwi ch on his own.

Let child make sandwiches with cookie cutters by cu tting out matching shapes of bread, cheese slices a nd 
cold meat.

cards.title: Walks to school, playground or store within two blocks of home independently.

Tasks.Action:
a)   Walk to site with child several times, po inting out landmarks and explaining procedures for crossing the  
             streets.  
b)   Pretend you do not know the way and have child tak e you to site. 
      c)    Walk ½ block behind child to make sure he can get there by himself. 
d)   Walk with him halfway. Let him finish trip by hims elf.

cards.title: Cuts soft foods with knife (i.e. hot dogs, b ananas, baked potato)

Tasks.Action: Use table knife with serrated edge.
Show child how to cut. Guide child’s hands through cutting motions. Reduce help as child gains in skil l.
Let child slice bananas, jello, etc., and have it b e part of family’s meal. Praise child.
Supervise while child plays at cutting sand in sand box.

Make a thick pancake out of play dough. Help him us e Popsicle stick or plastic knife to cut dough in p ieces. 
Gradually reduce aid.

cards.title: Finds correct bathroom in public place.

Tasks.Action:
Practice sight-reading words girls, women, boys, me n. Explain to child how we tell which bathroom to u se. 
Show child picture symbols of a man and woman.
Go with child at first. Ask him to show you where c orrect bathroom is. Praise correct response.
Instruct child in how to locate a responsible adult  to help him if he cannot find bathroom in a strang e place.

cards.title: Opens ½ pint milk carton.

Tasks.Action:
Use an empty carton at first. Close carton and ask child to open it. When child is proficient at this activity use 
a full, unopened carton.

Using a full, unopened carton, start to open carton  for child and let him finish opening it. Reduce ai d 
gradually until child can open carton independently .
Teach him to read “open’ so he knows which side to attack.
Let child help you open envelopes by sliding finger (s) under flap.

cards.title: Picks up, caries, sets down cafeteria tray

Tasks.Action:
Use tray without food on it at first. Ask child to pick it up, carry, and set it down. When Child seem s 
comfortable with this activity, place objects or fo od on tray and continue practice. Praise child for being a 
“big _________(boy or girl).”

Initially have child carry tray very short distance . Gradually increase both distance and obstacles th e child 
will have to negotiate.

cards.title: Ties hood strings

Tasks.Action: Practice tying strings of hood lying on table or on  another person.
Progress to tying hood while being worn.
Practice tying any lace with eyes closed.

cards.title: Buckles own seat belt in car

Tasks.Action: Show child how to buckle belt in car. Give verbal i nstructions as child buckles belt.
Physically guide child’s hands through motion of bu ckling. Gradually reduce aid.
Don’t do the task for the child when he knows how. Wait to start the car until he does it.

cards.title: Smiles in responds to attention by adult

Tasks.Action: As the child is being fed, diapered, and held, talk  softly and smile often.
Gently tickle the stomach: this will help to evoke a smile.
When the child smiles, respond by smiling and laugh ing back.
Greet child with a smile whenever picking him up af ter naps, when young someplace, etc.

When you walk by child as he is sitting or lying: s top,  talk to him, gently tap his nose, smile at hi m saying:  
      “ Do you have a smile? ” or “ Come on, you ca n smile”.

cards.title: Looks at own hands, often smiles or vocalize s

Tasks.Action: Hold child’s arm so his hand is in his line of  vision. Shake and wave his hand around so he notic es hands.
Touch his facial features with his hands. Wiggle hi s fingers so he realizes they move.
Place a bracelet that makes a noise as he moves his  hand.
Play “ This Little Piggy ” with his fingers.
Play “ Pat-a-Cake ” with his hands when they’re in his line of vision.

cards.title: Responds to being in family circle by smilin g, vocalizing, or ceasing to cry

Tasks.Action:
Allow the child to sit in an infant seat with famil y at mealtime, while mother is cooking in k itchen,  and 
when other children are at play.
Expose the child to sounds and people-turn on the r ecord player, use vacuum cleaner in his presence.
Encourage brothers and sisters to be involved in th e child’s daily care.

When family is sitting around talking, have family member hold child, occasionally caress and gently h ug 
child.

cards.title: Smiles in response to facial expression of o thers

Tasks.Action:
When attending to the child, make sounds by smackin g your lips, making clucking sound with the tongue 
and making cooing sounds.
Tilt your head from left to right and vocalize to t he child.
Smile at the child as you care for his daily needs.

Tickle the stomach gently while he is watching you do the above expressions, then discontinues ticklin g 
when child smiles at your facial movements.
Make exaggerated facial expressions when playing wi th child.

Play “Peek-a-Boo” with child and use exaggerated fa cial expressions, showing surprise and pleasure. 
 
 
  
.

cards.title: Smiles and vocalizes to mirror image

Tasks.Action: Hold child so he can see himself in a mirror. Say, “See the baby,” etc.
Provide an unbreakble child’s mirror so he can hand le it himself.

If child doesn’t smile at self, hold child so that he can see parent or sibling in mirror also. Point out both self 
and child. Put bright hat on child, or do something  to draw attention to the child.
Blink flashlight in mirror while child is looking. Smile in mirror and say “See the light or spot”.

Hold child at window at night, at glass door of sto ve or unlit T.V. set, show him his reflection by ta pping 
surface of glass. Say “See Baby”.

cards.title: Pats and pulls at adult facial features (hai r, nose, glasses, etc)

Tasks.Action: Bend over child, letting hair dangle hair ove r him. Encourage him to grab it.

Take child’s hand and place on your nose. Phy sically guide him in pulling your nose and make sil ly noises 
       Cry, “ouch, ouch!” to make him laugh.
Take his hand, palm open, and gently pat your  cheek with it.

Place his hand on your facial features as you  talk to him naming the features (i.e., nose, ears,  mouth, eyes,  
     Etc.)

cards.title: Reaches for offered object

Tasks.Action:
Use bright objects, jewelry or favorite toy. Offer the object and hold it close to the child’s hand. I f the child 
reaches, give it to him. When offering the object, shake it or tap it lightly first, to get his attent ion. If he does 
not reach, guide his hand to object.
Hold the bottle just in front of the child. Wait fo r him to reach for it before giving it to him.
Hold out your finger or hand and encourage him to t ake it. Physically guide his hand if necessary

Offer object to child. If he does not take it, gent ly stroke the child’s palm with the object and let him close 
hand around object.
Talk to child as you offer object. If he starts to reach for it, be sure to smile.

cards.title: Reaches for familiar persons

Tasks.Action:
Encourage the child to reach out with his arm as yo u hold out your arms to him and ask if he wants to come 
to you.

Encourage all of the familiar persons to hold their  arms to the child and encourage the child to do th e same. 
If child seeks adult attention, stand in front of c hild with arms outreached and have another person h old 
child’s arms out from behind. Parent should praise child as he reaches out (even with this help). Cont inue to 
cue child by touching his arms if necessary.

cards.title: Reaches for, and pats at mirror image or ano ther infant

Tasks.Action:
Hold mirror in front of child. Say, “Where’s the ba by?”  If he does not reach for mirror, take his fin ger and  
place on the mirror image and say, “ There he is!” Use a cookie sheet if mirror is not available.

Position yourself behind child so your image shows.  Ask, “Where’s mommy?” If he does not reach, guide 
his hand.

Place another small child next to him. Draw attenti on to other child with verbal cues. Say, “Pat the b aby,” 
and model. Physically guide his hand if he does not  comply.

Using two bolsters or rolied up towels for support,  prop two infants up on their elbows facing each ot her 
within reaching distance. Encourage children to int eract employing physical and verbal cues.

cards.title: Shakes or squeezes object placed in hand, ma king sounds unintentionally

Tasks.Action:
Help him hold rattle or squeeze toy by placing your  hand over his. Help him shake or squeeze it. Relea se 
Pressure.
Tie or tape bells or rattle to his hand so object m akes sound as he waves his hands.

Fasten small bells to ring or plastic bracelet that  is easily held. Reinforce by clapping and praising  when he 
makes sounds.

cards.title: Plays unatteneded for 10 minutes.

Tasks.Action:
Use mobile, soft toys, rattles or blanket. Many obj ects like spoons, plastic cups, etc. are as interes ting as 
commercial toys.
Place the child within sight of mother with several  toys.

Change the toys often as well as the child’s pasiti on. Place him near a window or door so he can look 
outside.
Use the radio or record player to provide sound to keep him company.

Tape or fasten large paper geometric shapes and app roximately 8” diameter happy faces on wall by playp en 
or crib. Change location of designs occasionally. R einforce child for longer and longer periods of pla ying.

cards.title: Seeks eye contact often when attented for 2- 3 minutes

Tasks.Action:
When diapering, feeding, or changing child talk, co o and make exaggerated facial expressions to him to  
encourage him to look at you. If child does not loo k, gently turn his head toward you. Smile and coo t o him 
when he does. Child may look away, but most of time  he should be watching your face.

If child loses eye contact for a while, regain his attention by waving object in front of him, or call ing his 
name.
Smile when he looks. Try to keep surrounding a rea relatively free of distractions.

cards.title: Plays alone contentedly near adult activity 15-20 minutes

Tasks.Action:
Place a few soft toys, rattles or objects from arou nd the house near the child. If the child begins to  lose 
interest, change the toys.

Let the child play with a variety of objects, such as kitchen utensils, unbreakable dishes. The child need not 
be within sight of mother, but she should check on the child from time to time.
Reinforce the child with verbal praise when he is e ntertaining himself.
Use records wind up musical toys or the radio to en tertain the child. Reinforce him for playing.

cards.title: Vocalizes to gain attention

Tasks.Action: Attend to child as soon as child cries or fusses fo r a legitimate reason, such as hunger or wet diaper s.

Hold a favorite object or food in front of child. D emand vocalization from child to gain desired item.  Do not 
anticipate the child’s every need.
Respond to the child’s verbal play with a smi le and by repeating the sounds he makes.
If child switches from crying to vocalizing, attend to him immediately with smiles.

cards.title: Imitates peek-a-boo

Tasks.Action: Take the child’s hands and place them in front of h is eyes saying “peek-a-boo” as hands are taken down .
Peek around a chair, table, smile and say “peek-a-b oo” Duck back again. Do this until he “peeks” for y ou.

Using hands, newspaper, toy, or blanket, cover your  face and peek out saying, “peek-a-boo” as you do t his. 
Give child the object to hide behind and after sayi ng  “peek-a-boo” encourage him to peek. Show him ho w 
by using physical guidance to help pull down the co ver.
Place sheet or towel over a stand-up mirror. Let child peek under it to see his image.

cards.title: Waves bye-bye in imitation of adult

Tasks.Action: Encourage the family to wave and say “bye-bye” when  they leave the house.
Take the child’s hand and wave “bye-bye” for him wh en someone says “bye-bye”.

Withdraw help gradually.  When bye-bye is said, hel p him raise his hand, but let him wave “bye-
bye.”  
Reward success with hugs and praise.
Play peek-a-boo, substituting waving and “ bye-bye”  as you disappear. Encourage child to do the same.

cards.title: Raises arms- “so big” in imitation of adult

Tasks.Action: Raise child’s arms and say “ so-o-o big ”. Make it a happy and fun time.

Model the motions as you say “so big” for the child  and praise for responding. If he does not, give cu e by 
pushing arms up with finger.

Place child in front of mirror. Ask “How big?” and physically help him to raise arms as you say “so-bi g.” 
Gradually reduce aid as child increases in skill. R einforce with praise and clapping.
Have other children or family members model f or the child. Ask “How big is Daddy?” etc.

cards.title: Offers toy, object, bit of food to adult, bu t does not always release it

Tasks.Action: Show the child how to hand you the toy by guiding h is hand towards you.

Play with the child giving and talking a preferred toy several times so the child will learn he will g et the toy 
back. In the beginning return the toy quickly and a lways keep it within his sight. 
When child is eating bits of finger food, dry cerea l etc. put one in his mouth; say, “give to -------- --.” Then 
when he picks up a bite, open your mouth or hold ou t your hand, say, “ give to -----------.” Physicall y guide 
his hand if necessary. Laugh and praise him.

cards.title: Hugs, pats, kisses “familiar” persons

Tasks.Action: Show affection as a reward for good behaviour.
Respond with affection when child comes to you for love and attention.

If child has a favorite crib toy (stuffed animal), demonstrate patting or hugging the toy and encourag e the 
child to do the same.

Model hugs, kisses to other family members when chi ld is going to sleep or out. Then say  “kiss daddy bye, 
or night.” Encourage him to imitate. Reinforce with  hugs and kisses.

cards.title: Shows response to own name by looking or rea ching to be picked up

Tasks.Action: Say the child ‘s name often—and always prior to giv ing any instruction.

Place the child in front of a mirror—touch him and say his name—“Jimmy.” and touch yourself—
“mommy.”

Say the child’s name and immediately squeak a toy c lose to your face. Reward the child for turning in your 
direction. Gradually reduce the loudness of the clu e by not squeaking the toy as hard. Finally, say th e child’s 
name without the additional attention-getting clue.
Use a puppet to talk to the child and have the pupp et repeat the child’s name often.

Use the child’s name with each bite of food during feeding, and with each article of clothing as he is  dressed 
(e.g., “Here comes some more meat, Johnny,” or “Joh nny, put your foot up here.”)

Have one person call the child’s name, and have ano ther person turn the child toward the speaker. Say,  
“Here’s -------.” as you tap the child’s chest.

Call child’s name and at same time quickly flash li ght on his face; the child will react to the light as he hears 
his name. Quickly move the flashlight under your fa ce and say child’s name again so he can see you spe ak 
his name. Make it a fun game. Gradually eliminate t he flashlight until the child responds to his name.

cards.title: Squeezes or shakes toy to produce sound in i mitation

Tasks.Action:
Squeeze or shake toy so child is aware of possible sounds. Then hand it to him to do. If he does not, clasp 
your hand over his and help him make motions necess ary to produce sound.
Clap hands or show surprise when child accomplishes  task.

Use dry beans, rice, B-B shot or sinkers in film ca nnisters, metal band-aid boxes, etc. Tape container  tightly 
shut. Model shaking container. Encourage him to sha ke to make sound. Reinforce with praise and clappin g.

Tape squeeze toy at foot of crib or playpen or on w all at foot of play mat. Physically guide child in pushing 
on toy with hands or feet to make sound. Gradually reduce aid. Reinforce with praise and clapping.

cards.title: Manipulates toy or object

Tasks.Action: Show and guide the child’s hand in picking up objec ts, like small cars, moving them back and forth.
Tap a toy on the table; guide his hand to repeat th e action.
Put a toy into a box; guide the child’s hand to rep eat the action.

Ring a bell, and then give him the bell and encoura ge him to copy you. Bang a spoon, spin toy, bat toy , or 
mobile, and encourage him to copy you.
Praise success at all levels and reduce help, as he  is able to do more of the action by himself.

Hang objects above crib, play pen, swing or “ teete r babe” (some with elastic). Physically guide the c hild in 
pulling, batting, or squeezing toy. Reduce aid grad ually. Reinforce with praise and clapping.
Use “busy box” type of toy or manipulate blocks wit h handles, squeak buttons, breads, etc for practice .

cards.title: Extends toy or object to adult and releases

Tasks.Action:
Place object in child’s hand. Give directions “Give  me” and hold out your hand to child. Physically gu ide 
him through the action, if necessary.
Use a musical toy. Demonstrate how you will wind th e toy if he gives it to you.
Give toy back to child occasionally so he realizes that a toy can be shared.

Make a game of “give me” by holding out a small ent icing object to child, say”give ____ to baby.” Clap  
hands and then ask “gi ve me ______.” Physically gu ide him if necessary then clap and praise.

cards.title: Imitates movements of another child at play

Tasks.Action:
Arrange for another child of about same age to play  with the child. Arrange for the other child to do a task 
that you want the child to imitate, such as pushing  cars, block building etc. Be sure there are severa l objects 
that are the same, like blocks, cars, beads.

Arrange for another child to do some physical activ ity such as crawl under a chair, and put a box over  his 
head. Encourage child to imitate.

Have two children seated together, initially give d irections to imitate movements child knows very wel l such 
as “bye-bye.” “pat-a-pat”, etc. Then initiate new m ovements such as touching top of head, touching toe s, 
bending over with head to floor as if ready to some rsault and turning round and round. Reinforce with praise.
Play “Ring around the rosy” with 2 children.

cards.title: Imitates adult in simple task (shakes clothe s, pulls at bedding, holds silverware)

Tasks.Action: Through play activities, teach the child the placem ent of household items.
Encourage the child to pick up and put away toys in  large box.
Give the child things to carry for you and show him  where they are to be put.
Praise the child when he helps or attempts to help.

Encourage child to help with tasks after he is fami liar with routines. 
 When folding clothes or sorthing clothes give child  washcloth or tea towel to shake and attempt to fol d while 
you are working. Praise him for helping.
When cleaning tubs or sinks let him rinse after you  have scoured with cleanser.

Encourage child to put unbreakable items (i.e.silve r, plastic glasses or bowls) in sink or dishwasher.  Praise 
him for helping.

cards.title: Plays with one other child, each doing separ ate activity

Tasks.Action:
Arrange for play with another child. Play with them  if necessary, and gradually withdraw from the play  
situation.
Give them toys such as blocks and provide plenty fo r both.
Have child sit next to another one and listen to a record or a story.
Give each child a toy truck, car, or tractor and en courage it to push toy across room. Reinforce with praise.

Give each child a doll and a bottle. Show them how to feed the babies. Reinforce them with praise for good 
playing.

cards.title: Takes part in game, pushing car or rolling b all with another child 2-5 minutes

Tasks.Action: Arrange group play activities with other children o f about the same age.
Encourage group situations and provide enough play materials for the children to give to each other.

Provide an activity that demands cooperation of two  children such as rolling a ball to each other, hav ing a tea 
party, etc.

Provide a cardboard propped on a book to make a slo pe, show the children how to place a toy truck or c ar at 
the top and push slightly to get it roll down.  Hav e one child start the toy and one catch, then chang e places.

Seat the children 3-4 feet apart and have them push  a toy vehicle or run a wind up toy back and forth.  Praise 
them for good playing.

cards.title: Accepts parents’ absence by continuing activ ities, may momentarily fuss

Tasks.Action:
Encourage the child to play in a room where mother is absent__ by having toys and activities away 
From mother.
Have the same person take over for the mother as a babysitter.

Leave the child for short periods of time, so he kn ows that mother will come back. (i.e., go outside t o  get 
mail)
Play with the child hiding and returning

cards.title: Actively explores his environment

Tasks.Action:
When visiting someone else’s house, show child arou nd and explain where things are. Say “Here is the 
bathroom.”  “Here is where we are going to eat.” “P lay with your toys here.”
Take walks around block or yard. Stop to look at an d discuss objects in area.
Ask child to go find things for you. Say thing s like, “Go in the bathroom and get my hairbrush.”

cards.title: Takes part in manipulative game (pulls strin g, turns handle) with another person

Tasks.Action: Push button toys and encourage him to imitate.
Pull cart toy. Place string in child’s hand. Place your hand over his and walk along, pulling toy.

Roll a toycar down a ramp. Clap or cheer when it re aches the bottom. Encourage child to repeat activit y by 
putting car in his hand and showing him where to pl ace it.

cards.title: Hugs and carries doll or soft toy

Tasks.Action:
Have child imitate you as you hug the dolly. Say th ings like “nice dolly,” “pretty baby,” etc. Give do ll to 
child and say “Love the dolly” ---give her a hug or  kiss.

Hand doll to child and instruct him to take care of  the doll: rock the doll to sleep, sing to your ted dy bear, 
take the dolly to daddy.
When child is given good night hug and kiss, ask ch ild to “hug and kiss dolly good night.”

cards.title: Repeats actions that produce laughter and at tention

Tasks.Action: Ask child to repeat a cute action for daddy or gran dma. Reinforce by laughting and applauding.
React when child makes a face or does some funny an tic.
Imitate animal actions and sounds. Encourage child to imitate. Reinforce with praise and clapping.

Repeat 
 finger plays and rhymes, physically guide the child  initially in following actions, gradually reduce 
assistance and encourage child to perform for other s. Reinforce with praise and clapping for appropria te 
actions.

cards.title: Hands book to adult to read or share with hi m

Tasks.Action:
If child wants to be read to, sit down and ask him to bring you a book. Give suggestions if necessary,  such 
as, “Let’s look at the ‘horsey book’,” or “Bring me  the baby book,”etc.
Show interest in a book when he shows one to you.

Children like to see pictures of self and family. H ave photo album available as book to look at. Repea t 
above, talking about what child is doing in picture .

When you are reading newspaper or magazine show the  child interesting pictures such as animals, childr en, 
etc.

cards.title: Pulls at another person to show them some ac tion or object

Tasks.Action: Admire his toys when he shows them to you.

Show the child something you think will interest hi m (new toy, aquarium, cookie baking, flowers). Then   
ask him to go show Daddy , or to bring sister to co me and see.

Walk with the child around the house. Point out obj ects or things happening within view from windows. 
(i.e., new flower on a plant, the garbage truck, a dog or cat outside, etc.)

cards.title: Withdraws hand, says  “no-no” when near forb idden object with reminders

Tasks.Action:
Ask parent to decide which objects or places will c onsistently be forbidden to the child. When the chi ld 
touches something forebidden, say “no” very firmly.  Try to limit the number of “no’s” for the child.

Put some kind of cue for the child on forebidden ob jects so that he will have a visual reminder that h e’s not 
to touch, such as a large red circle placed at his eye level, or a mad face.

When you see child definately approaching object, s ay “no-no” to him and have him repeat it, then remo ve 
him from object.

cards.title: Waits for needs to be met when placed in hig h chair or on changing table

Tasks.Action:
Encourage the child to be aware of wishes and needs  of others, quiet when someone is resting, talking on the 
phone.

Encourage the child to wait until mother has finish ed a task first, for a few seconds then building to  5 
minutes. Then do the activity the child has waited for.

Tell or warn the child when activity is due to chan ge, and allow a few minutes for the child to finish  present 
activity.
Thank and/or praise the child for waiting.

cards.title: Plays with 2 or 3 peers

Tasks.Action:
Provide opportunities for child to be around other children. Promote activities such as pushing and pu lling 
toys, playing with a ball, looking at picture books , coloring with large crayons.
Provide a sandbox or a wading pool.
Organize and conduct simple group games or have an older child conduct games.

Organize contests such as coloring with colored wat er or chalk on sidewalk, making paper bag masks or sand 
castles. Reward with prizes for most original, larg est, etc., so that each child gets a prize.

cards.title: Shares object or food when requested with on e other child

Tasks.Action: Roll a ball back and forth to him showing him he wi ll get the ball back.
Push a car back and forth to him.
Using a toy, trade and share, to show the child he will get the toy back.

Give the child 2 cookies and say, “ Give one to Jim my and you can have the other one,” and praise him for 
sharing.

cards.title: Greets peers and familiar adults when remind ed

Tasks.Action: Arrange situations for the child to greet adul ts, by taking child to door when answering doorbell .
Use toy phone and real phone and encourage the chil d to mimic you saying, “Hello, how are you?”

Encourage and model behaviour when daddy, sisters o r brothers come home by having them specifically 
greet the child. Praise the child when he does imit ate them.

cards.title: Cooperates with parental request 50% of the time

Tasks.Action: Reward good behaviours. Give praise and attention w hen the child seeks attention appropriately.
Warn the child that the activity is going to change  and give him time to finish what he is doing.

Gently but firmly guide. Do not ask questions that can be answered “no” such as, “Do you want to go to  
bed?”

Try not to tell the child to do something unless yo u can follow through by helping him comply with you r 
directions should he refuse. Praise the child even if help is given to aid him in following the direct ion.

Use simple and clear language when asking a child t o do something. Don’t ask him to carry out more tha n 2 
related commands at once and don’t ask him to do 2 unrelated tasks.

cards.title: Can bring or take object or get person from another room on direction

Tasks.Action: Have the child call father, other siblings at mealt ime.

Send the child on simple errands, like “please give  daddy his newspaper,” “please put this on the tabl e,”  
“put this in the hamper,” “bring me a diaper.” Than k the child for helping.

Initially go with child and help him with task. Lat er let him go alone as you give verbal direction. P raise his 
success. Initially give very simple directions that do not r equire moving out of immediate area. Gradually incr ease 
complexity of task.

cards.title: Attends to music or stories 5-10 minutes

Tasks.Action:
Read a simple and interesting story to the child. E xplain the pictures to him. Ask him to describe wha t he 
sees in the pictures.
Ask simple question about the story to find out if he really did listen.
Give the child the question you will ask before you  start the story.

Read to the child daily and at the same general tim e each day. Make this a fun and relaxing time for b oth of 
you—let him choose the story.

Play a record that involves simple motor activities . Go through activities with child. 
Later see if child can carry through actions from t he record alone.

cards.title: Says “please” and “thank you” when reminded.

Tasks.Action: Remind child to use these terms. Don’t give him sna ck until he uses correct term.

Use the terms when you want him to do something. Us e please and thank you such as  “please close the d oor. 
Thank you.”
The other members of the family should use these wo rds with children and adults.

At first you may need to tell him the entire word t o say (i.e. “Say thank you”) gradually reduce aid t o cue 
such as “what do you say.”  Reinforce the child for  being polite.

cards.title: Attempts to help parent with tasks by doing a part of the chore (holding dust pan)

Tasks.Action:
Encourage the child to help with activities by firs t being responsible for picking up his own toys. Re ward 
him with praise when he accomplishes task.
When dusting, give the child a cloth so he can imit ate your movements.
Let him take his own dishes to the sink and thank a nd praise him for volunteering to help with tasks.

Let child help you strip a bed, throw clothes in a dryer, put canned food away on shelves, or stir ins tant 
pudding or jello.
When you are sweeping have the child hold the dust pan so that you sweep dust into pan.

cards.title: Plays “dress-up” in adult clothes

Tasks.Action: Provide old clothes and a variety of hats.

Choose a character for the child to be. Say, “you b e the mom and I’ll be the person in the store.” Dre ss 
accordingly in old clothes.
Say “Let’s pretend-Who do you want to be today?” Pr ovide hats, clothes and accessories for him to choo se.

Provide or help the child make simple hats for nurs e, doctor, fireman, farmer, engineer, etc. Help him  to find 
toys that complete the outfit.

cards.title: Makes a choice when asked.

Tasks.Action:
Tak e two liquids, two toys or two foods. Give child a choice by asking him if he wants milk or juice, the  car or     
    the boat, etc. Wait until he makes a choice. If  he does not, put both items away and asks again at  a later time.
As you name each offering hold it out to him to help him understand he can have one or the other.

Give the child the opportunity to choose such th ings as red or blue shirt to wear, dog book or toy book to  
   read, or teddy bear or doll to take to bed.

cards.title: Shows understanding of feelings by verbalizi ng love, mad, sad, laugh etc .

Tasks.Action: Relate your feelings to the child. Ask him how he f eels.

If a sibling is expressing some emotion, ask chi ld to describe what is the matter. Give the child a  choice: Is he   
    mad or happy, etc.
Read child a book that shows people smiling or c rying. Talk about situation. Ask child why person i s _____
Have child look through magazines and cut out fa ces, which depict a certain emotion.
When giving the child a hug, tell him you love h im.

When angry, tell the child, " I feel very angry because --------. Thus providing a model for him to  use in  
    expressing himself.

cards.title: Sings and dances to music.

Tasks.Action: Demonstrate clapping and marching to music with the whole family.
Turn the radio on - take child's hands and 'danc e' with him showing how to move feet.
Encourage him to dance by himself- clap for and praise the child as he performs.
Provide rhythm band materials for children to pl ay with (pots, pan, spoons)
Sway body or nod head while singing to music. En courage child to imitate.

cards.title: Follows rules by imitating actions of other children.

Tasks.Action:
Play ring-around-the-rosy. Instruct child to wat ch the other children and do what they do. Help the  child by  
    telling him things like they're holding hands, etc.
Play " Simon Says" or "Follow the Leader".

Provide opportunities for child to play with oth er children in situations that require turn taking and offer an  
    opportunity to imitate. (i.e., sandbox play wit h digging, sand building or loading trucks, or play ground play  
    with swings, slide, merry-go-round and climbing  equipment).

cards.title: Greets familiar adults without reminders.

Tasks.Action: Role play, pretend daddy is coming home and let the child pretend to be daddy and then himself.
Use puppets and cutouts to act out situations i n which the child greets people.
Model the activity and have child imitate you, a s you are greeting people.

When you know a person familiar to the child wil l be arriving inform the child. If familiar adult i s at the door  
     inform the child as you go to answer the door to give him an opportunity to greet him.

cards.title: Follows rules in-group games led by adult.

Tasks.Action:
Start with small groups of children. Choose a ga me with very simple rules and demonstrate the game to the  
    children by going through it slowly. Then gradu ally withdraw your verbal and physical assistance.
Play games such as Tag, Farmer in the Dell, Lond on Bridge, Drop the Hankie.

Play a game one time then, let the child who has  turn to be leader choose the game. Review the rule s and  
     encourage the child to participate. Reinforce child for following rules.

cards.title: Asks permission to use toy that peer is play ing with.

Tasks.Action:
Model activity by asking child if you can use wh atever he's playing with. Promise to give back. Tak e it if he  
     does not give it to you. Play with it briefly and give it back to him. Praise him for sharing.

Give another child a toy that your child likes. Tell your child to ask for it if he wants it. Encou rage him to use  
   “ Please and thank you: and also to return the t oy when he is finished with it.
Praise child whenever he asks you for something before taking it.

cards.title: Says please and thank you without reminders 50% of the time.

Tasks.Action:
Show and tell the child when to use "please" and  "thank you" such as assistance with doors, picking  up objects, 
 
     Etc. Praise child each time he is courteous.
Use "please" and "thank you" appropriately in yo ur speech to the child and have family do the same.
If child does not respond, say  "what do you say "? and do not give in to request until child says " please".
Use" please" and "thank you" at mealtime when pa ssing food.

cards.title: Answers telephone, calls for adult or talks  to familiar person.

Tasks.Action:
Let the child use a toy telephone and have the chil d pretend he is answering a telephone, give him 
spoken clues .
Let the child talk to grandmother or familiar adult  to learn telephone manners.

Arrange for familiar adult to phone you, rehearse p rocedure just before adult is to call. Reinforce ap propriate 
phone answering.

Provide the child with a card of picture cues on an swering and calling parent. Reinforce child for fol lowing 
cues.

cards.title: Will take turns

Tasks.Action:
Encourage the child’s brothers and sisters to pl ay sharing games with the child, such as “London 
Bridge”.

Go to the park or public playground where the ch ild can see others waiting their turn in going down  
the slide.
Roll or catch ball with three other children.

At mealtime have food passed around, rather than  filling each dish at the counter. The child will w ait 
his turn to be served.
Praise him when he is able to take turns.

Play hopscotch, jump rope, table games. Give spo ken cues about sharing, waiting for turn in family 
activity. Let child be first, at times.

cards.title: Follows rules in group games led by an older  child

Tasks.Action:
Play games within the family circle where older children lead the activity. Initially have parent 
involved also, helping the younger child follow thr ough with the directions.

Involve child only in very simple games at first, s uch as Ring-around –the rosy, London Bridge, Little  Sally 
Saucer and praise child when he follows rules. Pare nt could act as observer at this point.

Arrange for child to have other children to play wi th by having a special outing or party if children are not 
available in neighborhood. Reinforce child for play ing with others for longer and longer periods of ti me.

cards.title: Cooperates with adult requests 75% of the ti me

Tasks.Action:
Comes when called – use child’s name often, say “Jimmy, let’s eat” saying the name before you 
give the direction. Sit on the floor a few feet awa y and call the child’s name holding out your hands 
saying “Jimmy, come here.” Gradually increase the d istance between you and the child. Praise 
success.

Responds to “no”- say the word “no” loudly and t hen help the child stop the activity by helping him  
open his hand and then take the object away, etc. T hen say “good”. Be consistent – don’t allow the 
child to tear magazines one day and punish him for the same behavior the next day.

Do not give too many directions. Be sure the dir ection is important enough to demand that it be 
followed through. Physically guide child through ac tivity if he does not comply.
Warn the child when an activity is going to chan ge and give him time to finish what he is doing.

cards.title: Stays in own yard area

Tasks.Action:
Take the child outside with you when doing outdo or work. Tell and show him where his limits are 
and praise him from time to time for staying within  this area.
If child leaves yard area bring him back and remind  child of the boundaries.

When the child consistently stays within his yard w ith you going with him, then let him go out by hims elf for 
a short period of time. If he stays within boundari es, praise him and let him stay out for a longer pe riod next 
time.

When he does go out alone, watch him from a window.  If he leaves the yard, immediately return him to t he 
house. Repeat again later in the day, reminding the  child of his limits.

Put a timer out in yard with child. Tell child to c ome in when timer rings and if he’s stayed in yard area 
during that time he’ll get a treat. Next time incre ase amount of time on timer, etc.

cards.title: Plays near and talks with other children wh en working on own project (30 minutes)

Tasks.Action:
Provide situations in which the child can play w ith others the same age. Play such as sand box and 
block play, are appropriate tasks. Be sure there ar e enough blocks for all children.
Take the child to the neighborhood park or playgrou nd and encourage him to participate using the equip ment.

Arrange for children to be available for play situa tions in the home. Help initiate projects or play f or the 
children, reinforce them for playing appropriately by playing or discussing their play with each child  
individually.

cards.title: Asks for assistance when having difficulty ( with bathroom or getting a drink)

Tasks.Action: Model activity by asking child to help you. Say “I can’t do this by myself, will you help me, pleas e?”
If child is having difficulty and is whining, tell him what he should do and say to obtain assistance.
Explain the magic of words “please” and “thank you” .

Intervene before the child gets very upset. Tell hi m that he can ask you for help. Model the phrase fo r him, 
for example “please, help me find my car.” After th is try just asking, “what should you do if you need  help?”
Reinforce the child for asking for assistance, (i.e . “Thank you telling me you need help.”

cards.title: Contributes to adult conversation

Tasks.Action: Encourage child to greet visitors and answer que stions.
Provide situations in which child can communicate w ith an adult.
Make suppertime a time when each family member tell s about his or her day.

When family decisions need to be made, encourage ea ch child to participate in the discussion. Let chil d know 
he has a right to contribute.

Don’t ridicule or scoff at child if his ideas are n ot entirely appropriate. Instead, cue him in on the  topic of 
conversation.

Discuss with child or rehearse with him what he did  during day that he could use as contribution to di nner 
conversation. Reinforce him for appropriate contrib utions.

cards.title: Repeats rhymes, song, or dances for others

Tasks.Action: Read nursery rhymes often. If records of rhymes are available, play repeatedly.

Say the nursery rhyme. Have child say the last w ord of each line. Gradually increase the number of 
words for him to say.
Puppets can be very useful for this; the child can “teach” the puppet.

Encourage the child to relate experiences to grandm other or familiar adult. Let the child gain confide nce in 
talking to others.

Put on a little “show” for and with friends. Have e ach child perform. Clap hands for each performer, p raise 
and give a little treat.

cards.title: Works alone at chore for 20-30 minutes 0

Tasks.Action:
Give the child a choice of a chore to do. Explai n what needs to be done for task that child has 
chosen Set a timer for 15 minutes and tell child if  he works at task until timer goes off he will rece ive 
a treat. Praise child for working on task and next time set timer for 20 minutes, etc.
Check child’s progress and encourage him as he carr ies out task.

Some tasks that the child might be able to sustain interest working for longer periods of time might b e raking, 
or picking up sticks or twigs prior to an adult mow ing lawn, carrying trimmings and clippings, dusting , 
washing bath tubs, rolling cookie dough into balls on cookie sheets. If you work near by it will be ea sier for 
him to maintain interest. Reinforce for attending.

cards.title: Apologizes without reminder 75% of the time

Tasks.Action: Encourage courtesy at home among all family memb ers.
Use courtesy in dealing with the child.
Always set a good example, by being courteous yours elf.

If child doesn’t apologize in an appropriate situat ion, wait silently and keep child in attendance. If  necessary, 
ask him “What do you say?” and praise him for compl ying.

cards.title: Will take turns with 8-9 other children

Tasks.Action: Provide play activities, tea parties, sand play,  sliding, blocks, playground equipment or toy pool.
Parent should not interfere in play activities of c hildren. Children should be checked on intermittent ly.

Play a circle game where the children make up a sto ry where one child starts it and each child, in tur n, adds a 
sentence or a thought, or a circle game where one c hild chooses a category and each child in turn name s 
something from the group.

cards.title: Plays with 2-3 children for 20 minutes in co -operative activity, (project or game)

Tasks.Action:
Utilize a playground. Children can take turns sl iding down the slide, pushing merry-go-round, ridin g 
teeter-totter.
Build a farmyard, putting up fences and boundaries using blocks.
Build a road. Provide enough cars for everyone to d rive down road.
Play games such as tag, ring-around-rosy.

Give children an idea of what you expect. Tell them  if they play by themselves they can have juice and  
cookies when you call them.

cards.title: Engages in socially acceptable behavior in p ublic

Tasks.Action:
Explain that some things are best done in privat e such as picking his nose, scratching, belching, 
etc. Remind quietly when necessary.

If child does something unacceptable intentionally or for attention in public, ignore him, remove the child 
from the situation or hold child firmly and remain silent. Have no eye contact with child until the be havior 
stops. Then give the child another opportunity to b ehave appropriately.
Be a good model for the child.

cards.title: Asks permission to use objects belonging to others 75% of the time

Tasks.Action: Do not allow child to keep others’ belongings wi thout asking.

Other family members should ask the child’s permiss ion to use his possessions, and adults and brothers  and 
sisters should ask each other.
Knock on his door before entering.

Tell him “this is mine 
” and he must ask to use or play with object.

cards.title: Plays with 4-5 children on co-operative acti vity without constant supervision

Tasks.Action: The activity should be organized, but not length y.
Each child should have a chance to participate in s mall groups.
Provide enough materials such as blocks so each chi ld can contribute to the activity.
Play “house” or games that need cooperation from al l to succeed such as tag, ring-around-rosy.

cards.title: Explains rules of game or activity to others

Tasks.Action:
Make sure child knows how to play game. Tell him he  can be the leader or the teacher and ask him to sh ow 
the other children how to play. Give verbal cues if  necessary.

Model an activity for the child and have him explai n what you’re doing, or ask him what to do next. Th en 
have the child do the activity and explain to you w hat he’s doing. Show him what comes next if necessa ry. 
Finally let child explain the activity to the whole  family. Praise child.

cards.title: Imitates adult roles

Tasks.Action:
Provide old clothes, long dresses and a variety of hats. Play “house” or act out stories with 
characters wearing appropriate “costumes”.
Provide a long mirror on door or wall so child can see how he looks.

Allow child to pretend he’s the daddy or mommy for a short amount of time. Let him use props from arou nd 
the house.
Let child put on a play or fashion show for the fam ily.

cards.title: Joins in conversation at mealtime

Tasks.Action: Ask child questions about his activities, so he has something to talk about.
Vote on family decisions. Let child decide what  his vote will be.

Ask child what his thoughts are on a subject bei ng discussed at mealtime. Be sure to pick 
something he can relate to.

Try not to let one person consistently dominate the mealtime conversation. Let each person have a 
chance to speak.

cards.title: Follows rules of verbal reasoning game

Tasks.Action: Play a guessing game such as : I’m Thinking of S omething ___________.

Play Twenty Questions. Older siblings can model by being “first”. Cues can be whispered in child’s ear  when 
it is his turn.

Praise the child or let him be the leader of the ga me next as a reward if he makes a particularly appr opriate 
response.

cards.title: Comforts playmates in distress

Tasks.Action:
If friend is hurt, suggest ways child can comfor t, such as; to go get a band-aid, help him wash wit h 
soap and water, give him a hug, bring him a toy, et c.

Read the child a book in which situation arises whe re someone needs help. Ask the child what he would do if 
he were there. If child suggests something, praise him! Give him more appropriate suggestions if neces sary.
Let him role play using dolls and comforting them.

cards.title: Chooses own friends

Tasks.Action: If he can have a friend over., ask, “do you want me  to call Mary or Jimmy, today?”
Provide opportunities for child to play where sever al children are present. Let him play with child he  chooses.
Occasionally let child take an extra treat or extra  cookie to school to give to a friend.
Do not force child to play with children who may ha ve come with a visitor of parents.

cards.title: Plans and builds using simple tools (inclin ed planes, fulcrum, lever, pulley)

Tasks.Action:
Provide materials necessary such as blocks, tinker toys, string, etc. Show him a picture or build a mo del for 
him to copy.

Explain fulcrum, lever, pulley, etc. simply and sho w what results can be obtained. Let him incorporate  these 
ideas into his building plans.

Allow the child to leave project under construction  out so that he can continue working on building. I f some 
areas must be cleared and toys put away, provide on e area where he can build. Reinforce him for approp riate 
play.

cards.title: States goals for himself and carries out act ivity

Tasks.Action:
Choose a project the child can and will carry throu gh. Sit down with the child and orally list the ste ps 
necessary to complete the task. As he works on the activity, give verbal cues such as, “What do you do  first? 
Next?” etc.

Once child decides on a goal for himself (such as brushing his teeth each night without reminders) le t him 
figure out a chart by which he can record his progr ess with stickers or tokens or check marks. Parent can 
monitor activity by rewarding child when a certain number of stickers or checks are reached.

cards.title: Acts out parts of story, playing part or usi ng puppets

Tasks.Action:
Use stick puppets and act out a story such as The T hree Billy Goats Gruff, doing all the parts yoursel f. Then 
ask the child to take any one part and go through t he story again. Give verbal cues if he needs help.
Take turns with child so he has the opportunity to be several characters.

Use cardboard characters. Draw character on tagboar d and cut holes for hands and head. Help child plac e 
hands and head in correct openings
Build a puppet theatre out of cardboard boxes. Chil d can stand behind “stage” to manipulate puppets.

cards.title: Reaches for object 6-9 inches in front of him.

Tasks.Action: Suspend a toy from the ceiling on a long string and place child so he can watch toy move and dangle and reach out to hit it. Use stretchy rope to attach objects (elastic thread).
Use a favorite toy or food placed within vision. Initially assist child in reaching out and picking up objects. Call his attention to picking them up. Move his hand to touch the object.
Allow child to reach out and pat glass or slap hand on table. Demonstrate these activities so he gets idea of reaching out with his hands.
Use a suction toy (clown or jumping jack) attach to flat surface 6-9 inches in front of child, help child to reach and grasp toy.

cards.title: Grasps object held 3 inches in front of child.

Tasks.Action: Poke child’s clenched fist open with your forefinger and insert so he closes fist around it. Playfully move finger so his hand and arm move out from his body.
Hold small, easily grasped toy in front of child. If he does not grasp, open his hand and place object in it. Place your hand over his for several seconds, gradually release your grasp.

Use a favorite squeaky toy that’s easy to grasp and place it first within his reach. Provide any assistance necessary to help him grasp and reinforce with praise and smiles (squeak the toy so that he is also reinforced by the sound). Gradually move the toy until it’s three inches in front of the child.

cards.title: Reaches and grasps objects in front of him.

Tasks.Action: Sit child on your knee. Hold enticing object far enough in front of him so he must reach out for it.
If child does not reach, hold object close to him and gradually pull farther away as he learns to reach.

Tie a scarf or necktie or place wooden beds around your neck. Lean over baby so he can see your face and touch the scarf. Shake the scarf so he can see it and reach for it. When he grabs the scarf or even touches it, praise him. Smile to show him you are pleased. Initially move scarf towards baby’s hands so he doesn’t need to reach as much for it.
Use a ball hanging from string tied around it. Swing ball slowly in front of or over child’s face. Help him to hit the ball by moving his hand.
Blow bubbles in front of him. Encourage him to touch and break bubbles by talking to him or clapping and smiling.

cards.title: Reaches for preferred object.

Tasks.Action: Limit selection of toys to just a few so he learns to accept one as his favorite. Hold toy in front of him and do not give it to him immediately. Encourage him to reach for the toy.

Secure a towel across top of crib. Tie onto it two objects that feel very different (satin cloth, net ball). After a day or two switch the objects from left to right. Later remove one object and replace with something different. Next try 3 objects. Be sure they can all be easily seen and reached by the baby.
Use brightly colored objects or toys with facial features to attract his attention.

cards.title: Puts object in mouth.

Tasks.Action: Move the child’s hands about by clasping them, clapping them, and guiding them to his face.
Place an object in the child’s hand and help him move it to his mouth. Tape the object to his hand if necessary.
Give the child a piece of food and guide his hand to mouth.

Place finger food on tray and you pick up a piece and put it to your mouth. Place food in his hand and encourage him to imitate you. If the child does not imitate you, place the food in his hand, then guide his hand to his mouth. Reduce help given by lessening the pressure on his hand.
Use a sucker or Popsicle. Clasp child’s hand around stick. Guide to mouth for initial taste.

cards.title: Head and chest supported on arms while on stomach.

Tasks.Action: Place the child on his stomach on the floor, and speak to him to get his attention.
Place the child on stomach and forearms and hold toy or rattle above head so that he will have to raise up to look at it. Move toy upward so child will raise head.

Place the child over bolster or pillow, hands flat on the floor, and encourage him to look at you by making sounds. Replace the pillow with one that is smaller so that the child will have to do more of the work himself.
Place a mirror in front of child’s head while on stomach. Make noise or talk to child to encourage head raising.

cards.title: Holds head and chest erect supported on one arm.

Tasks.Action: Place child on his stomach and forearms. Hold a bright colored object, preferred toy, or food to one side so child will extend one arm to obtain object. Physically guide hand if necessary.
Position child on floor. Place small cloth on head, hanging over eyes. Encourage him to reach up and remove with one hand.
Use a pull toy that makes noise or movement, place string with bead or ring within easy reach. Encourage child to pull toward him so that toy makes sound or action.

cards.title: Feels and explores object with mouth.

Tasks.Action: Hold an object for child to see. Place it in his hand if he doesn’t reach for it himself. Guide it to his mouth.
Use teething rings, hard and soft rubber toys.
Put dry jello mix, honey, peanut butter, or other preferred food substance on the object to initially motivate child to put object in his mouth.
Try letting him hold hard teething biscuit, a carrot stick, or large pretzel stick in his mouth. Watch that he doesn’t bite or break off large piece.

cards.title: Understands shape of object with the help of mouth and taste

Tasks.Action: Hold a teether in front of child where he can reach it. Encourage him to place it in mouth.
The teether could be made of rubber or any soft rubber material, which is child safe.
Give the child soft eatables such as chocolates, cakes, carrots etc. to encourage eating.
Notice whether the child is able to chew or break the eatables into bits before eating.

cards.title: Is able to roll from stomach on to back

Tasks.Action: Place the child on his stomach
Place a toy just out of reach of the child to his side but where he can see it.
When the child tries to reach for it, move it a little away to the side. This would encourage him to roll. If he succeeds give him the toy.
Repeat the procedure on the other side.
Place the toy above his head and encourage the child to roll over and reach for the toy.

Lay child on back in crib. Tie a hanging toy to the crib and let your child observe you doing so. Now turn the child over on to his stomach. He will try to reach for the toy and roll over on to his back.
Lie down beside the child. Tug at his clothes to get his attention. Talk to him till he rolls over.

cards.title: Moves forward one body length on stomach.

Tasks.Action: Place child on floor, arms extended. Place a toy or bit of food just a few inches out of child’s reach. Reward him with object if he is able to get it. Gradually move toy farther away.
Position self in front of child with head at same level as child’s. Smile and talk to child to encourage him to move forward.
Slowly pull child forward by pulling lightly under upper arms.
Help him to rock back and forth to initiate movement. He may move backward before going forward.

cards.title: Rolls form back to side.

Tasks.Action: Physically guide the child in rolling from his back to his side by taking the upper arm and pulling the child over (pull left arm to right, pull right arm to left). Place a rolled blanket at his back to help maintain position initially.

Place the child on his side in a crib, talk to him or ring a bell to get his attention. You should be on the other side of the crib so that he will roll over to see you. Help him if necessary and gradually withdraw the help as the child is able to do more for himself.
Place child in a room with rest of family to stimulate him to turn to side to see everybody.
Wind up and place a musical toy close to side of head so he will roll over to see it.

cards.title: Turns from back to stomach.

Tasks.Action: Place child on back. Grasp arm and leg and gently roll him over toward you. Gradually reduce aid.
Position child on his side. Place bolster or pillow behind him so he cannot roll over on his back. Encourage him to roll over on his stomach. Push him gently with the pillow to complete roll over.
Slowly pass object over his head to encourage him to roll after toy.
Sit on one side of child and put out your arms to him. Coax him to roll to you.

cards.title: Pulls to sitting position when grasping adult finger.

Tasks.Action: Prop the child to an almost sitting position. Grasp the child’s hands and help him to sit up. Gradually reduce amount of propping items.(pillows etc.)
Place the child on his back on floor. Place your fingers in the child’s grasp. Enclose his finger with your hand and pull him to a sitting position.
Using two people, one kneeling behind the child’s head and holding the child, and the other taking the child’s hands, pull him to a sitting position. Gradually reduce support given to the head.
Lie child on lap with head at your knees. Help him pull to sit using your fingers and bracing feet against your stomach.

cards.title: Turns head freely when body is supported.

Tasks.Action: Prop the child securely in infant seat or high chair or corner of large chair or sofa. Walk back and forth in front of him while talking or use a bell or rattle to keep his attention.
Sit the child in a room that you are working in i.e. kitchen, living room. Talk to the child, rattle the dishes, make movements that encourage him to turn his head.
Sit child in infant seat or high chair at family dinner table. Reinforce with smiles and by talking for the child to turn his head in response to different family members.
Place child in infant seat or propped in chair, cross his hands across his chest and slowly rock him from side to side, so that his head moves freely.

cards.title: Maintains sitting position for two minutes.

Tasks.Action: Place pillows around child and keep pillows high on sides.
Sit the child in corner of a couch or chair with pillows for support.
Sit the child in a high chair with the straps loosely tied for support.
Place the child between your legs and place his arms on your legs for support. Gradually sit farther away so he is supporting himself with his hands and only slight pressure on his back.
Place child in an infant seat and draw him up to you holding his hands. Support head or shoulders if necessary.
Construct right angle form plywood or cut cardboard box, utilizing one corner. Round edges. Prop child in box, placing one arm over side to maintain balance.

cards.title: Puts down one object deliberately to reach for another.

Tasks.Action: Give child a toy to hold in each hand. Then offer a preferred toy or favorite finger food. Help him release object in one hand and grasp new object if he does not do so by himself. Use verbal encouragement. Say “Put down the block first so you can have the cracker”
Immobilize one arm by holding, putting inside shirt, putting under high chair tray, etc. Have him hold object in free hand. Then offer a preferred object so he must release first object.
Whenever you see child put down one object to pick up another, reinforce him with smiles and praise.

cards.title: Picks up and drops object on purpose.

Tasks.Action: Place child in high chair or any child’s chair with tray. Help child grasp object in hand and physically guide hand over side and release object over side making a noise as it hits floor. Show child that you think this is funny. Retrieve object and place back in tray. Do again, gradually decreasing aid.
Use blocks and container. Hold block over container and drop. Model activity. Place block near child’s hand and encourage him to imitate.
Use verbal cues. Say-give me, drop it, pick it up etc.
Objects and containers that make a noise may be more appealing.
While bathing child, let him drop something in water to make a splash. Help him retrieve it from the water.

cards.title: Stands with maximum support.

Tasks.Action: Hold the child securely around his waist and bounce him so that his legs support him for brief periods.
Hold the child in a standing position in front of a mirror, picture or window and praise and talk to the child as he stands.
Hold child in front of low table with toys on top. Encourage child to play as you help him stand.
Under direction of a physical therapist, use a standing box.
Sit child on your lap facing you pull to stand by having him grasp your fingers. Encourage him to bounce and flex his knees.

cards.title: Bounces up and down in standing position while being supported.

Tasks.Action: Place child in a jolly jumper (swing suspended on spring in doorframe so child’s feet touch floor). Hold child under arms. Promote jumping motion by raising up and releasing.
Use a “teeter-babe”. Help him to bounce initially so that he gets the rhythm.
Stand child on your lap and bounce him up and down.
Help him stand holding on to end of crib and urge child to jump or bounce.

cards.title: Crawls one body length to obtain object.

Tasks.Action: Place the child on the floor and move one of the child’s arms forward and repeat this movement, alternating arms.

Place the child on the floor. Place a toy or bit of food just a few inches out of the child’s reach. Get his attention by tapping the object on the floor and talking to him. Reward the child with the object if he is able to get to it. Gradually increase the distance between the object and the child.

Place the child on a scooter board so that his tummy is touching the board. Help him to move by moving his arms in a swimming fashion, so that he is propelling the board. Provide goodies for him to go to.
Sit in front of child and grasp both his arms at shoulder. Pull him toward you.
Put towel under child and hold up both ends of towel so that you help lift the child’s stomach from the floor. as he starts supporting himself, reduce aid.

cards.title: Sits self supported

Tasks.Action: Sit on the floor with child sitting between your legs so that he can support himself by placing his hands on your legs.
Place the child’s hands flat on the floor, palms down.  As he is sitting push down lightly on his shoulders in bouncing manner.
Place interesting object in front of child so desire to sit is maintained.
Use pillows around him to cushion fall if he tips over. Sit facing him with feet outstretched, roll a ball or push a toy car to him.

cards.title: From sitting position, turns to hands and knees position

Tasks.Action: Place the child in a sitting position and encourage the child to come to you, using toys or snacks to tempt him.
Help the child by giving him support and reward the slightest turn of the hands or body, which would be associated with getting into a crawl position.
Sit child on the bed; gently tip him to hands and knees position by pushing.
In sitting position on floor, pat the floor in front of the child. Encourage child to lean forward and pat the floor to get him to put his hands down and lean forward.

cards.title: Moves from stomach to sitting position.

Tasks.Action: When child is lying on stomach, roll him to the side, lift his knees toward his chest, have him push with his hands and sit up right. Praise him while you’re giving him aid. Gradually reduce aid.

Place the child on the floor on his stomach. Offer the child a piece of cracker or toy and then gradually move it to the side and then raise it to encourage the child to reach and at the same time to change position. Reward with toy or treat.
Provide object to use as lever so he can grasp it and pull himself up.
Show the child how to back up to a chair or wall and push upward with hands to sitting position.

cards.title: Sits without hand support

Tasks.Action: Place your arm behind the child’s back to provide support, while encouraging him to manipulate a toy. Gradually reduce the amount of support you are giving him.

Place the child in a sitting position between your legs and allow him to place his hands on your legs for support. As he becomes steadier, give him a toy to play with so he will not use his hands to support himself.
Sit child on floor with pillows around him to make him secure, make certain he is sitting firmly on buttocks with legs outstretched for balance. Reinforce by talking and playing with him.

cards.title: Flings objects haphazardly

Tasks.Action: Sit next to the child and give him a ball. Then move a few feet away and hold out your hands saying, “Throw it.” Praise success.
Place your hand around his and help him fling the ball, toy or paper and praise him.
Sit on the floor, facing the child. Ask him to throw the ball to you. Praise him regardless of the direction the ball is thrown in.
Use object that makes noise when thrown. (Beanbag with jingle bells sewn on or rattle) Or let child throw object in water so it splashes.

cards.title: Rocks back and forth on hands and knees

Tasks.Action: Place a beach towel under child’s chest holding the ends. Lift up so only his hands and knees touch the floor. Move towel back and forth so child rocks.
Hold child at hips. Move forward and backward.
Model rocking back and forth for the child. Then physically guide him through the motions.
Place a pillow or bolster under child’s chest. Initially guide him in rocking back and forth. Praise him and verbalize “rock-rock” or “back and forth.”

cards.title: Transfers object from one hand to the other in sitting position.

Tasks.Action: Take brightly colored objects and set several of them within easy reach of child to encourage him to pick them up.

Give the child one object and hand him another to be taken by the same hand. Show him how to transfer the first object to the other hand in order to grasp the second object. If he holds two in one hand, or puts them to his chest with one hand then give the third object to him.
If the child tends to use one hand more than the other, place a snack in the child’s less preferred hand. Reinforce him for transferring to preferred hand.

cards.title: Retains two one inch cubes in one hand

Tasks.Action: Place child where he cannot easily set an object down. Offer him small objects until he has one in each hand. Then offer a preferred object so he must transfer initial object to other hand. Help him to do this if necessary.
Use the one inch-cubes. Keep offering them to him saying, “Hold this.”
Place two one-inch cubes in one of child’s hands. Encourage him to hold them. Give physical aid if necessary. Reinforce with praise and verbalize, “take another”, “now you have both.”

cards.title: Pulls self to on-knees position

Tasks.Action: Position child on knees in playpen with his hands grasping bars. Maintain position until he is familiar with it by holding him there physically or amusing him with toys or actions.

Place child in playpen in sitting position close to railing. Hold toy just high enough so he must pull on bars to raise himself on knees to reach it. Physically guide him through activity if necessary.
Place toys on low table that child can reach easily if on knees. Play with toys on table to encourage child to come and do the same.

cards.title: Pulls self to standing position

Tasks.Action: Place toys or snacks on a low chair or table. Be sure the child is watching as you do this. When the child pulls himself up to obtain them, praise him and let him have the toy or snack.
Physically pull the child up and place his hands on a rail or edge, and give him a treat. Small steps or solid pillows may help to provide him with something to place his hands on as he’s puling up.
Dangle toys above child’s playpen that he will be able to reach by pulling himself up using side of playpen.
Position child so he has one foot flat on floor and weight on one knee. Tell him to pull with his arms and push with leg. Help by pushing his seat.

cards.title: Uses thumb and forefinger to pick up object

Tasks.Action: Place small item of food such as cereal on tray in front of child. Show him how to grasp it with thumb and forefinger by modeling. Position his thumb and forefinger and guide with your hand if necessary.
Use sticky raisins, sugar candy that are moistened to make them sticky. Let child eat them as reward as he picks them up. Use small beads and ask child to pick them up and give them to you.
Tape three remaining fingers if he persists in using palmer grasp. Verbalize, “pick it up” and reinforce him for doing it.

cards.title: Creeps

Tasks.Action: Place the child on a scooter board so that his tummy is touching the board. Help him to move by moving his arms in a swimming fashion, so that he is propelling the board. Provide goodies for him to go to.

Place the child on the floor. Place a toy or bit of food just a few inches out of the child’s reach. Get his attention by tapping the object on floor and talking to him. Reward the child with the object if he is able to get to it. Gradually increase the distance between the object and the child.
Place a beach towel under child’s chest holding the ends. Lift up so only the child’s hands and knees touch the floor. Propel him slowly along the floor praising him as you go.

As the child is held in creep position, pull back on one foot, then let go. There will be an automatic movement to pull that leg forward. Do the same with each leg. Gradually pull more lightly and decrease aid to just taking hold of the foot.
