Using two people, pattern creeping movement. One person moves arms; the other person moves legs in an alternating manner. Creep to something so activity has a purpose for child. Say,  “Let’s go find Daddy.”

cards.title: Reaches with one hand from creep position

Tasks.Action: As the child is in the creep position, encourage him to reach for a toy or object. Reward verbally or with treats any attempt to reach.
Place the toy or object close to his hand so he will only have to make a slight hand movement. Gradually move the object a little further from his grasp.
Dangle objects from rod or bar that child will be able to reach from a creeping position.
When child is creeping, pull a pull toy on a string in front of him within easy reach. Tell him to “get the car”, etc. Reinforce him for reaching out.
Offer finger food to the child when he is in creep position.

cards.title: Stands with minimum support

Tasks.Action: Stand the child at the side of his crib or playpen and place his hands on the rail. Help him hold his hands there by placing your hands over his.
Have the child grasp your fingers then pull him to a standing position, praising and talking to him as you do this.
Place your hands under his arms as he holds on to the crib or playpen railing. Gradually withdraw the support so that he is balancing on his own.
Place a bar in doorway so child can stand and watch things outside.
Place a jump rope, dishtowel, etc. under the child’s arms. Support him by holding ends of the rope up behind him. Gradually reduce support.
After the child has pulled himself to a standing position at chair or sofa sit on the floor near his side and hold toy or treat near enough so he will withdraw one hand and reach for treat or object.
Place favorite toys on couch. Encourage child to stand and play with toys using couch for support.
Use a toy monkey hanging from doorframe; lower it so child can place feet firmly on floor. When he tires he can just sit without falling. Reinforce him with praise and smiles.

cards.title: Licks food from around mouth

Tasks.Action: Place food such as peanut butter, jam, or honey around mouth. Model tongue movement. Encourage child to remove the sticky food form his lips
Use a sucker and after child tastes, move sucker around mouth so child will follow it with his tongue.

Place a small dab of pudding (or any tasty substance) on upper lip. Encourage child to lick it off with tip of tongue. Repeat by putting taste in corners of the mouth. Let child look at himself in mirror and lick it off.
Place food substance on tip of your finger, after putting it on tip of tongue, trace around mouth with fingertip. Praise him and verbalize, “That’s good” or “yum.”

cards.title: Stands alone for one minute

Tasks.Action: Pull the child up to standing position and place his hands on a stable piece of furniture. Talk and smile as you do this. Gradually withdraw support. Offer him toys to get him to let go of object. Reinforce verbally.
While he’s standing with support, provide a toy, a small mirror, etc. to look at to keep his attention while standing.
Praise success and provide a small treat for increasing the time he stands.
Give the child something to hold in each hand, like small blocks to help him maintain his balance.
Pull the child up to a standing position and place him with his back towards a wall or the refrigerator for support.

cards.title: Dumps object from receptacle

Tasks.Action: Place blocks and cup on a tray. You place the blocks in the cup and then dump them out slowly. Ask child to imitate you. Guide his hand if necessary and praise him as you help him accomplish the task.
Place small bits of cereal or cracker into cup for child to remove and eat.
Place goodie or raisin in narrow mouthed container. Show him how to remove by dumping.
Say “in” pointing into cup, “out” pointing to table or tray. Praise success by hugs, kisses and “good.”

cards.title: Turns pages of book, several at a time

Tasks.Action: Read simple stories to the child and show him how to turn the pages as you read the story. Help him turn the pages by guiding his hand. Gradually let him help you turn the pages.
Give the child old catalogs or magazines to play with or storybooks with plastic coated pages.
Tape pieces of cereal or candy on pages of book and show child as you do this. Then give him the book and let him find the treats.
Use a favorite book, ask child to “find the dog” or object that he recognizes in the book. Praise him for turning pages.

cards.title: Scoops with spoon or shovel

Tasks.Action: In sandbox, demonstrate scooping with spoon or small shovel. Help him grasp shovel and guide through the motion.
Use a spoon that is easy to grasp. Help him by guiding spoon into food such as cooked rice, mashed potatoes.
Put uncooked navy beans or macaroni in container. Encourage scooping with shovel, measuring cup, large spoon.
Use uncooked beans in container. Encourage child to scoop and put into toy truck.
Use rice or dry cereal in a bowl, have the child scoop and put into smaller dishes or tea set cups. Reinforce verbally.

cards.title: Puts small objects in container

Tasks.Action: Use any ordinary unbreakable cup and small blocks (1 inch.) Place the blocks and cup in front of the child. You take one block and place it in a cup. Then give the child a block and tell him to “put it in.” a. Take the child’s hand and help him pick up a block. Help him place the block in the cup and repeat several times and praise the child. b. Give the child a block, tip the cup toward him and point to the cup saying, “put it in.”
Vary objects and container to keep child’s interest using different textured things such as buttons, raisins, stones, or acorns.

Use objects that will make a noise when dropped into container. The sound of the object hitting the bottom will act as a reinforcer. After the child has placed the object in the container, help him shake the container to hear it rattle.

cards.title: Lowers self from standing to sitting position

Tasks.Action: Help the child bend his knees to a squat position and move the child’s hands down the crib rail, couch or playpen; then lower him to sit and praise him as you do this.
Before helping the child to sit, place a favorite goodie or toy in the bottom of the playpen or floor. Be sure that he sees the toy.

Guide the child in bending his knees to a squat position with the aid of two people, one behind the child holding hips, the other holding the child’s knees in front. Together lower him to sitting position.

Stand facing the child holding on to his hands. Have another family, member stand behind the child. Together move from standing to sitting position. The person standing in back of the child can touch the back of his knee to help initiate the movement.

cards.title: Claps hands

Tasks.Action: Place the child’s hands in yours, and clap both sets of hands together while saying, “pat-a-cake.” Praise the child as you do this.
Reduce the pressure on the child’s hands as you feel him doing more of the action himself.
Say “pat-a-cake” while clapping your hands. Encourage him to clap like you. Reward him for pat-a-caking by smiling, laughing, and praising the child.
Place the child on your lap, put your arms around him and very lightly hold his wrists bringing his hands together to “pat-a-cake.” Stop and hug and praise the child and repeat activity.
Clap hands when child does something you like. Encourage him to do the same.

cards.title: Walks with minimum aid

Tasks.Action: Support the child’s shoulders from behind. Slight pressure on the shoulders will help him to alternate his feet.
Have child carry object (toys, blocks). Support him under his arms. Gradually withdraw major support. Play a walking game, carrying objects to family members. Praise and reinforce him.
Two people can be used if it is necessary to hold hips and shoulders.
Child walks grasping person’s hand. Decrease to finger hold.
Child walks hanging onto rope or towel. Gradually decrease pressure on rope.
Stand child in playpen with his hands grasping railing. Offer object, holding it so he must walk a few steps hanging onto railing to obtain it. Gradually increase distance.
Encourage child to push doll carriage or stroller to gain practice in walking with support.

cards.title: Takes a few steps without support

Tasks.Action: Stand in front of child grasping both hands in yours. Pull him gently forward. Gradually let go. Praise and reinforce.

Two people can sit on small chairs with backs facing and about 2 feet apart. Place child between the chairs letting him hold onto one for support. The person should hold out his hand, call the child’s name, and give him a treat if he comes. Gradually increase the distance between chairs.
Stand child a few steps away from desired object (playpen, stuffed toy on chair, swing). Gradually withdraw support as child moves toward object.
Giving the child something to hold or encouraging him to hold on to his own clothing may aid in helping him to maintain balance.

cards.title: Creeps upstairs

Tasks.Action: Position the child’s hands and knees on the stairs. Place something on the next step that he would like. Encourage him with spoken cues to get the object.
Place the child in the position and physically help him move up the stairs. Hold him, moving his knees and hands. Praise slightest efforts made by the child.

Begin with 2 steps for the child to crawl up. Place a toy or goodie on the second step and help him, if necessary, to get it. Reduce help and gradually increase the number of steps to crawl up to get the goodie
Sit at top of stairs and call child. Encourage him to come to you. Have another person stay behind the child in case he slips or tumbles.
Place several large pillows or bolsters on the floor and encourage the child to creep up on them.
Use a low stool or box against the wall. Encourage him to creep up this one step, then try short flight of stairs.

cards.title: Moves from sitting to standing position

Tasks.Action: When the child is sitting on the floor provide a goodie or toy held above the child’s reach to encourage him to stand up. Give him the goodie or toy when he stands.
Extend your hand to him and help him get up and then praise him and give him the goodie.
Reduce the amount of assistance by letting him do more of the pulling up to reach the standing position.
Use a chair. Have child pull himself up to standing position. Gradually use lower chairs.
Have the child sit on the bottom stair and encourage him to stand by holding on to your hand or the banister.
Have the child sit on box or low stool, place a heavy sturdy chair in front of him that he can hold on to help pull himself up.

cards.title: Rolls a ball in imitation

Tasks.Action: Sit facing the child. Place the child’s feet wide apart. Place your legs apart, too. Sit 2 feet from the child and roll the ball to him. Place his hands on the ball and help him roll it back to you. Gradually increase the distance between you and the child. Reward all improvements by praising the child.
Sit in back f the child. Take his hands and help him hold the ball. Help him roll the ball across the floor to another person. Reduce the amount of help given as the child gains in skill.
Roll ball to simple target set 4 feet away.
Sit child in front of mirror. He may try rolling the ball to his image.
Use empty detergent bottles as bowling pins. Roll ball to knock them down.
Use various sizes and textures or with internal toy that moves to maintain interest.

cards.title: Climbs into adult chair, turns and sits

Tasks.Action: Place child facing front of upholstered chair, hands on chair. Help him raise knee on chair and give him a boost up. Turn him if necessary. Gradually reduce physical aid.
Sit in chair. Encourage child to crawl up and sit with you, and give any physical assistance necessary.
Remove the seat cushion from the chair so the child doesn’t have quite so far to go.
Help the child, if necessary; grasp hold of the arm of the chair for support in pulling up.
Use a kitchen chair with rungs on the back. Encourage the child to bend over the front of the chair to reach and grasp a rung for support in pulling himself up.

cards.title: Puts 4 rings on peg

Tasks.Action: Use wood or plastic colored rings and a large peg. Let the child explore the rings and peg. Then take a ring and place it on the peg. Then give the child a ring and guide his hand to the peg and help him place it on the peg, if necessary. Praise the child regardless of the amount of help needed.
Gradually reduce the amount of physical help needed as the child learns the skill.

Give a ring to the child. Give instructions, “Put it on,” and gestures (point to the top of the peg). Praise success. When he can place one ring on without either physical help or directions, give him additional rings and continue praising success.
Use a ¼” dowel secured in wooden base and metal jar rings. This allows child more space in which to operate and still be able to place ring on peg.

cards.title: Removes 1” pegs from pegboard

Tasks.Action: Remove one peg from board. Ask the child to do the same. Say, “Give me the peg.” Hold out your hand. If he does not, take his hand and help him grasp peg and pull.
Put just one peg in board. Encourage child to take it out. To motivate him, put happy face or other sticker in peg hold so he’ll have to lift out peg to see it.
Use commercial ‘peg people’ that fit into tractors, houses, circus platforms, etc. Encourage the child to pull them out. Provide assistance as necessary.

cards.title: Puts 1” peg in pegboard

Tasks.Action: Place pegs and pegboard in front of the child. Put one peg in the board. Ask the child to do the same. “Put the peg in the board.” Praise him when he does.
Take child’s hand and help him by guiding his hand and placing the peg. Praise him as he succeeds.
Gradually reduce help as the child learns the skill and continue praising success.
Use 1” pegs to start with. Gradually decrease size of peg as child becomes more proficient with activity.
Use small plastic container, cut hole slightly larger than peg in center, the sound of the peg dropping should be reinforcing, when he can put the peg into the container, try the pegboard.

cards.title: Builds tower of 3 blocks

Tasks.Action: Place 6 small blocks on the table. Build tower of 3 blocks. As you place the blocks, have the child imitate you placing each block on the other rather beginning with the full sequence of 3 blocks. Praise the child after each correct placement.
Point to where each block goes saying, “Put it here,” substituting instructions for physical help.
Take child’s hand and help him place one block on top of the other block. Praise the child and gradually remove physical help.
Use large blocks at first, gradually reducing size.
Use magnet blocks to insure success.
Start with a large block for base (3”). Give the child a smaller block to put on top (2-2 ½). The third block should be slightly smaller than the second block (1 ½- 2”)

cards.title: Marks with crayon or pencil

Tasks.Action: Use large pencil or crayon and paper. Tape paper to table, so child doesn’t have to hold it. Make a mark on the paper. Tell the child to make a mark like yours. A mark can be (l) or (_). His mark need not be exactly like yours. Praise any attempt.

Use large strokes covering the entire page and make them quickly, to encourage imitation. After you have drawn a stroke, give the child a crayon and take his hand and help him make the stroke. Do this several times, praising each attempt and reduce help as the child gains in skill.
Practice on paper just using your finger to make the stroke instead of a crayon. Have the child imitate your motions and then go to a crayon.
If an average sheet of paper is not large enough for the child, start with a newspaper. Gradually reduce the size of paper. A water base-marking pen might encourage the child to try.
Chalk and chalkboard, magic markers, lipstick, paints, magic states may also stimulate the child in wanting to mark.
Place paper on wall or to refrigerator front so child can stand to mark.
Melt crayons and mold into blocks of color that can be easily grasped by child (palmer grasp).
Use finger paint or shaving cream on tabletop with child and practice making lines with fingers.

cards.title: Walks independently

Tasks.Action: Stand the child with his back against furniture or wall, facing you. Have a toy or goodie ready. Sit on the floor a few feet from the child ready to catch him if necessary. Ask him to come to you, holding the goodie out for him.

Provide a doll buggy or stroller with the handles lowered, or a large cardboard box, so the child can push it. This will provide him with support while gaining practice in walking without parental help. Pushing a small child’s chair across the floor will provide the same king of practice.

Place 2 small chairs within two to three feet of each other and place the child between the two chairs. A parent and brother or sister can sit in each chair. Encourage the child to move from chair to chair by using sugarcoated cereal supplied by each person. Gradually increase the distance between the chairs. Praise the child for each improvement.

cards.title: Creeps downstairs, feet first

Tasks.Action: Put the child at the bottom of stairs. Have him watch you creep down a few steps, making a “whee” happy sound as you come down.
Place the child on the last step from the bottom. Put your hands on his waist and help him creep down giving all verbal and physical help needed.
Repeat over and over giving less help each time and gradually adding to the number of steps to creep down.
Sit at bottom of steps. Call child to come down the steps to you.
Put child at top of steps. Position yourself 2 steps lower than child. As he comes toward you, move down the steps just in front of child. When child reaches bottom of steps praise and hug him.
Initially use a short flight of stairs or motor development stairs available through equipment supply centers.

cards.title: Seats self in small chair

Tasks.Action: Place a large chair next to the child’s small chair. Slowly sit in the large chair, point to the small chair and ask the child to sit in the chair just like you.
Stand him near his chair and lower him to the seat. Praise him.
Stand him up again with his back close to the chair. You let go and see if he sits. Place his hands on side of chair as he sits. Praise success.
Stand the child in front of the chair, show him how to place his hands to his sides and move them back so that he can touch the chair with his hands before he begins to sit.

cards.title: Squats and return to standing

Tasks.Action: Play ball or bean bag games that require the child to pick up the object in order to continue playing with it.
Have the child pick up and put away his toys.
Place some of his favorite objects in a place where bending and straightening up is required to get them.
Have him imitate you, “ now we are small,” (when you squat) and “now we are tall “ (when you straighten up).
Hold his hands to support him as he lowers himself to a squatting position.

cards.title: Pushes and pulls toys while walking

Tasks.Action: Provide a doll buggy or stroller so the child can push it. Pushing a small child’s chair or cardboard box across the floor will provide the same king of practice.
Provide a pull or push toy that moves or makes sounds.
Put string or handle in his hand. Direct him to walk to somebody and show off his pull toy.
Hold your hand over his as walks along pulling toy.
Make a “train” of containers or shoeboxes fastened together with string, he could place small toys or objects in the “train,” and pull it.

cards.title: Uses rocking horse or rocking chair

Tasks.Action: Lift the child on the horse or chair. Begin the rocking motion for the child.
Place the child in a sitting position in front of you. Sit on the floor so that his back rests against your chest.   Show him a rocking motion by rocking your body back and forth.
Place the child on floor facing you. Grasp hold of his hands telling him, “Let’s row a boat.” Pull him gently toward you, then push towards him.

Place the child in the rocking chair or on a rocking horse. If a rocking horse is used, be sure the child’s hands are put on the handles or bars. Use only a very gentle rocking motion. If the child shows any fear, take him off. Place a doll or animal on the horse or chair and let the child watch the animal “rock” as he pushes, then try the child again.
Encourage the child to mount the horse alone. Use a step stool if needed.
Place the child in a small rocker so his feet touch the floor. Show him how to push with his arms and legs to get the rocker going. Reduce help as the child begins to rock himself.
Use a child size rocker that plays music as it is rocked.

cards.title: Walks upstairs with aid

Tasks.Action: Practice walking up curbing holding onto the child’s hand. Praise and encourage him.

Begin with the two bottom steps on a set of stairs. Have the child place his hand on the rail and you take the other hand. As you walk up the step, gently pull on the child’s hand to encourage him to step up. Praise him as he does.
Place goodies on every other step. The child should walk upstairs using the railing and your hand for support. He can have a goodie each time he steps up.
Move his legs up and down in a marching fashion. Then place one leg on a step. Place our hand behind his knee and move his leg up to the other step. Praise and reward him for each step he takes.
Walk up the stairs backward in front of the child and reward him for each step he succeeds in climbing up.
Practice marching to music. This will give him the idea of stepping up.

cards.title: Bends at waist to pick up objects without falling

Tasks.Action: Roll ball to child as he stands. Ask him to pick it up.
Model how you want child to pick up objects. Praise child for bending at waist as you do.
Have child pick up tall objects at first. As child becomes more coordinated at bending over, reduce the height of objects to make activity more challenging.

Have the child pick up toys or books and place in toy cart of box. Reinforce by clapping each time he succeeds. You can take turns, first you pick up an object and clap, then have the child pick up an object.

cards.title: Imitates circular motion

Tasks.Action: Show the child how to make a circle by making gross concentric movements on paper for the child to copy.
Take the child’s hand and guide him in making the circular movements with a crayon. Praise the child as you do this.
Having the child use his finger to make the circular movement on the paper, in flour, finger paint, or in sand will give him additional practice before using a crayon.
Have the child trace around the circle you draw. Then encourage him to make one on his own. Reward “good circles” by drawing “happy faces” inside them.
Use large newspaper to encourage gross movement of the arm before reducing the size of paper and requiring the finger movement of fingers and hand.
Let the child make circles by swinging his arms around in large circle.
Have the child practice on a tile wall in bathroom or on a plastic tabletop using suds or shaving foam.

cards.title: Strings 4 large beads in two minutes

Tasks.Action: Use large beads and string with plastic coated ends. a) Hold the string at the base of coated tip. Place the bead on the tip and with the other hand take hold of tip. Remove your hand from base of tip and let bead drop. b) Repeat the process, but this time let the child place bead on tip. Have him hold the tip and you remove your hand and let the bead drop. c) Place the child’s fingers on base of tip and help him hold it. Let him do the whole process, with as little help as needed Praise and reward the child for each success.
Hold the string so it dangles next to edge of table or chair. Once bead is on string it will drop quickly to end of string. Child can pretend he is stringing fish.
If task is too difficult, use large blocks with a hole in the middle and a round stick to put through the hole.
If fine motor control is poor, rest the arms on the table and make the end of the string stiff with glue or tape.
Use a “thread-a-block.” (Large wooden block with holes and dowel like needle) to practice.

cards.title: Turns door knobs, handles, etc.

Tasks.Action: Place hand over child’s and turn knob. Reinforce and verbalize, “turn.”
Use kitchen play set with knobs and handles. Put a favorite toy or treat inside cupboard as child watches. Close door and ask child to find it.
Stand in bedroom or closet and close door. Ask child to open door to find you.
Let child help you by turning water on and off, opening doors in stores, etc.
Have the child turn knobs on musical toy to practice.
Use large plastic nuts and bolts to improve skill at turning.

cards.title: Jumps in place with both feet

Tasks.Action: Stand in front of child holding both his hands. Have him bend his knees as you do. Lift his hands up as you jump up, keeping feet together. Reinforce him and verbalize, “jump.”
Use mini-trampoline or inner tube with canvas stretched over it as base instead of floor. Use rim of inner tube. Jump on inner tube with a piece of plywood on it.
Use the bed as a base for jumping until child has idea of motion.
Have child jump up, as if making a basketball jump shot, raising his arms above his head may help him to gain upward momentum.

cards.title: Walks backwards

Tasks.Action: Choose open area to avoid bumping into things. Model activity. Have child imitate.
Lead child through activity, holding his hand.
Move your feet forward one at a time to touch his toes as a signal to move that foot back. Reinforce and verbalize, “back” as he moves.

cards.title: Walks downstairs with aid TITLE:

Tasks.Action: Practice walking down starting at the bottom step and gradually increasing to 3-4 steps and finally to top of stairs.

You walk downstairs backwards in order to face the child. Talk to him, encouraging him to move one foot down. Place your hand on his foot, pick it up, move his foot down. Make sure you are giving him full support and assurance so the child doesn’t become frightened. Praise him for each attempt to move down one step.

Stand directly in front of the child on next step down. Hold the child by his hips, firmly. Ask him to take a step down. You may need to move his body towards the side of foot he’s using and brace him as he comes down. Gradually reduce aid and continue to praise him.

You may need to start the child on short flight of stairs, he could sit down and “bump” down on his buttocks to the last step, then have him take the handrail and step down. Gradually increase the number of steps that he walks down.    WHAT TO DO :

cards.title: Throws ball to adult 5 feet away without adult moving feet

Tasks.Action: Begin by sitting facing child, rolling a ball, then standing and rolling a ball back and forth, then throwing it. Praise and reinforce.
Play a game with inner tube or basket and beanbag or ball, trying to toss the ball or bag in the ring.

Sit about one foot from the child. Toss or roll a ball to him or place it in his hands. Tell him to “throw” ball to you. Remain close to his, making sure your hands are near his to facilitate catching. Praise behavior. Repeat procedure several times, lengthen the distance gradually.
Sit behind the child, take each arm while he’s holding the ball and guide him in throwing the ball. Praise and reward him Gradually remove the aid as he gains in skill.
Use a beanbag, foam rubber ball, or large plastic ball and stand about 3 feet from the child and encourage him to throw the ball to you. Praise improvement in direction.
Use a large ring or a wastepaper basket for the child to aim at. Have the rest of the family participate too.

cards.title: Builds tower of 5-6 blocks

Tasks.Action: Place 6 blocks before the child. Ask him to build a tower. a) Praise him for each block he places on the tower. b) If he stops at 3, hold out another block to him and ask him to place it on the tower. Guide his hand if necessary. Praise success. c) Gradually remove aid (verbal cues and physical aid).
Put a sticker or star at a point “6 blocks high” on a wall. Tell child to try to build tower up to reach the star.
Let child knock down tower as a reward.
Have the child practice stacking using other materials such as sponges, cans, plastic freezer containers, or books.

cards.title: Turns pages one at a time

Tasks.Action: Provide the child with books to look through and manipulate.
Have him turn the pages for you while read the story. Praise and thank him for helping you.
Use a picture book with cardboard pages. Reinforce him for success.
Show child a picture of himself. Place picture under next page to be turned to encourage child to turn page to find picture.
Make a scrapbook of pictured favorite objects, place index tabs on the corners of the pages for ease in turning.

cards.title: Unwraps small object

Tasks.Action: Show the child how to remove wrappings, using a treat both you and the child will enjoy.
Begin by partially removing the wrapping and allowing the child to help more and more with the task.
Vary the wrapped items so the child will not lose interest – such as bits of cereal, cookies, crackers, a small toy, or a book.

Wrap an item in many layers of paper. Let each member of the family remove one layer and person who removes last layer gets the item as reward. Be sure that at least the first time the child gets the reward.
Wrap blocks or balls in foil. Or wrap cookies for snack time. Foil is excellent as it forms the shape of the wrapped object.

cards.title: Folds paper in half in imitation

Tasks.Action: Pretend to wrap up a pencil, crayon, or candy.
You fold paper in half. Have child copy action.
Draw a diagonal line on paper. Let child fold on this line.
Bring one edge of paper over to other edge and ask child to create the fold. Praise child. Reduce amount of help given.
Let him try folding materials, such as towels or hankies.
Let child practice refolding items with creases, like napkins and Kleenex.
Use construction paper have the child fold in half to make tents, make a “tent city” with correctly folded papers.

cards.title: Takes apart and puts together snap-together toy

Tasks.Action: Hold child’s hands in yours as you pull toys apart and put together again.
Attach objects together with “Velcro” and have child imitate pulling apart. Reinforce.
Play tug-of-war with child by each holding a large plastic object that has been fastened to the other in an attempt to pull them apart.
Use strips of tape with grippers attached to practice.
Attach facial features to a felt “happy face” with snaps or grippers, have the child take off and put on the features.
Place child’s hands on top and bottom of toy. Put your hands over child’s and make twisting motion to unscrew.
Use jars with screw lids to practice twisting motion and put treat inside clear jar so child can see it.
Place goodie in each section of nesting toy.
You hold bottom piece while child unscrews top.

cards.title: Kicks large stationary ball

Tasks.Action: Show him what to do by walking up to a ball and kicking it yourself. Then have the child imitate you.
Stand a few feet from the child, kick or roll a ball to him for him to kick back to you.
Physically guide the child in the act of kicking. Move his leg from the knee and ankle. Have him maintain balance by holding onto a chair.
Demonstrate kicking motion several times and ask child to imitate you. Praise him when he does.
Practice kicking other objects- plastic pail, pillow, etc.
Rope a weight or beanbag to a ball so that it will travel in an erratic pattern when kicked.

cards.title: Rolls clay balls

Tasks.Action: Use play dough or make your own.
Break off a small piece of clay and show child how to roll ball between palms or on table with one palm
Make a nest for child and have him put rolled balls into nest as bird eggs.
Let child help you roll cookie dough into balls and then flatten them with bottom of a glass.
Use sand and water outside to form round balls. Bake in the sun.

cards.title: Grasps pencil between thumb and forefinger, resting on third finger

Tasks.Action: Place pencil in correct position in child’s hand. Guide his hand as you mark on paper. Praise child for making mark while holding pencil correctly.
Use ink crayons. Show child how to mark. Physically guide him in holding pencil; gradually reduce aid as he increases in skill. Reinforce him for holding pencil correctly.
Grip aids are available commercially to help maintain correct grasp. Wrapping Popsicle sticks around the pencil will also form a triangular base.
Large manuscript or beginner pencils are easier to grasp.

cards.title: Forward somersault with aid

Tasks.Action: Demonstrate the somersault by doing one yourself.
Help the child hold his head down as he rolls over. Hold him and push as he rolls. Be sure your hand is in back of his neck to protect him.

You somersault with the child by having him imitate each of the movements needed to accomplish the skill – for instance, he gets on his hands and knees in imitation of you, he tucks his head in imitation of you and so on until the final sequence of behavior is accomplished.

Position the child bent over with knees flexed, head and hands on floor. Remind him to tuck in his head, and physically guide him in “walking” his feet forward to tip over. Gradually reduce help using verbal cues of “walk,” and “head in” and a gentle push as you say “over.”  Reinforce with praise and clapping.

cards.title: Pounds 5 out of 5 pegs

Tasks.Action: Use 2 hammers, one for you and one for child. Let him imitate you pounding.
Show the child how to pound. Give physical help by guiding his hand. Use a pegboard with clothespin-size pegs that fit but can be pounded deeper.
Praise the child and reduce help as he gains skill and aim.

Begin by pounding down all the pegs but one in the center. Physically guide him if needed and gradually reduce aid as he begins to pound more accurately. Add one peg at a time as he increases in skill. Reinforce by praising good pounding.

cards.title: Puts together 3 piece puzzle or form board

Tasks.Action: Hand the child one shape at a time beginning with the circle. If necessary, point to the correct hole and guide his hand. When he can replace the circle without any help, hand him the square and then the triangle to replace.
Have the child trace around the empty shape with his finger and then find one that looks and feels like that shape.
Place the shapes above or next to the correct openings and then have the child replace them. Praise the child after each correct placement.

Use a large wooden puzzle with 3 forms: a circle, square and triangle. At first, tape the triangle to the puzzle so the child will not be distracted by the third form. Place knobs on each puzzle piece so they are easily grasped. Remove the square and circle and give each shape to the child one at a time, for him to replace. Praise success.

Remove only the circle and give it to the child for him to replace. If necessary, show him where to place it by pointing to the correct hole. Repeat several times until the child can place the circle in the correct hole without error or help. Then add the square for him to replace.
Asking the child to look for and find the shape that is the same as the empty slot in the puzzle will aid in avoiding trial and error placement.
Have the child trace the out line of the shape and its hole with his finger to aid in identifying like shapes.

cards.title: Snips with scissors

Tasks.Action: Place child’s fingers in the proper position. Hold your hand over his and say, “ open,” “shut,” as you cut.
Begin by cutting narrow strip of paper with one stroke. Praise the child as he gains in skill.
Fringe sides of paper by cutting 1 snip at a time around edges.
If child cannot manipulate scissors go back to activities such as picking up objects such as cotton balls or marshmallows with tongs and transferring them from one container to another.
Use training scissors with double handles, with which you guide his hand.
Hold paper for child as he snips. Then let child hold paper and snip.

cards.title: Jumps from height of 8 inches

Tasks.Action: You jump, ask the child to do the same.
Make chalk lines on sidewalk, or yarn lines on rug. Encourage the child to jump between the lines.
Jump from 1 colored circle to another placed on the floor.
Encourage the child to jump off the bottom step of stairs or curb by standing in front of him and holding your arms out to catch him if necessary.
Jump from a 3” book. Increase height gradually and praise child for each improvement.
Encourage the child to jump from edge of carpet onto a bare floor or from a secured scatter rug or carpet sample to floor. Reinforce with praise and clapping for good jumping.

cards.title: Kicks large ball when rolled to him.

Tasks.Action: Show him what to do by walking up to ball and kicking it yourself. Then have the child imitate you.
Standing a few feet from the child, kick or roll a ball to him for him to kick back to you.
Physically guide the child in the act of kicking. Move his leg from the knee and ankle. Have him maintain balance by holding onto a chair.
Demonstrate kicking motion several times and ask child to imitate you. Praise him when he does.
Child may have to lean against a wall to start out with the kicking.

For additional practice in kicking a ball in motion, fasten the ball as a tether between two stakes or across a gate outside, or across a doorway inside, have child kick the ball and it will return to him. Reinforce him for good kicking.

cards.title: Walks on tiptoe

Tasks.Action: Have the child watch you as you walk on tiptoe and encourage him to imitate you.
Encourage the child to reach for objects on a table or counter where he must stand on tiptoe with support to get the object.

Place feet patterns made of construction paper on the floor. Play “follow-the –leader”, having the child imitate what you do. Praise success and place reward on every 4th pattern so that if child has completed the previous 4, he will be rewarded. Gradually decrease use of tangible rewards and use verbal praise.
Walk on tiptoe in stocking feet, the try it while wearing slippers or shoes.

Hold dowel or wooden spoon above child’s head so that he reaches for it on tiptoe, walk a few steps at a time, gradually reduce your grip on rod and let child walk independently holding it above his head. This will help him maintain balance on tiptoe. Reinforce for good walking.

cards.title: Runs 10 steps with coordinated, alternating arm movement

Tasks.Action: Encourage games involving running. (Catch me, race around yard, etc.)
Have races with siblings and dad.
Hold the child’s hand and run with him slowly. Gradually increase the speed of gait and gradually remove your support. Praise success.
Practice running fast, then slowly, modeling for the child. Praise good running.
Practice by pretending to be a racehorse, a “plow” horse, or different animals such as deer or fox, etc.

cards.title: Pedals tricycle five feet

Tasks.Action: If the child cannot reach the pedals, build them up with blocks taped or screwed onto the pedals.
Push the child on the tricycle so that he gets the feel of pedaling.

Tape the child’s feet to the pedals. Move the trike, so that the child can feel how the pedals work. Gradually reduce the amount of tape used. Straps from roller skates may serve the same purpose as tape.
Put pressure on the child’s knees to help push the pedals down. Continue pushing each knee. Say “up,” “down’” etc. Decrease aid gradually.
Stand about one foot in front of the child on the tricycle. Show the child a goodie and tell him to come and get it. Praise and reward success.
Pull trike towards you with rope so child can concentrate on pedaling instead of steering.
Put trike in a stand to keep it stationary as child pedals.
Put trike on a slight incline so child won’t have to use as much pressure at first.

cards.title: Swings on swing when started in motion

Tasks.Action: Use a chair swing first that is likely to be found in a playground.
Push child in chair swing. Reassure him by keeping close to the swing, touching child often. Do not swing high.
Have the child watch other children swinging and show him that their legs move back and forth to make the swing go. Encourage him to lean “back” and “forward.”
Don’t push the child each time the swing comes back to you and tell him to move his legs back and forth with each swing.

As he becomes more independent switch to a swing without sides and have the child hold onto the chain, Be sure the swing is low enough for his feet to touch the ground. Continue encouraging him to swing on his own.
Stand in front of child and encourage him to reach out to you with the feet each time the swing comes forward to start a pumping motion.

cards.title: Climbs up and slides down 4-6 foot slide

Tasks.Action: Go down slide with the child on your lap.

Place him on the last 2 feet of the slide. Guide him as he descends and praise the child. Then place him a bit higher letting him slide down holding him by the waist. Eventually let him climb to top and descend slide alone.
Use a small slide at first, and walk beside the ladder as he climbs. Hold him around waist on the way down the slide.
Wait at bottom of the slide to catch him and praise his success.

cards.title: Somersaults forward

Tasks.Action: Show the child how to somersault by doing a few for him to watch.
Place child’s hands flat on floor. “Tuck” his head under so he rolls over on the nape of his neck. Give physical aid by lifting his legs over. Gradually withdraw aid.
When child is in somersault position tell him to push hard with his feet. Praise improvements and success.

Use a footstool or stack pillows and a mat. Help the child to lie on stomach across stool with head and shoulders hanging over edge towards mat, have him move forward and help him go over as you say “over.” Reinforce for good tumbling.

cards.title: Walks upstairs, alternating feet

Tasks.Action: Help the child accomplish the task by standing in back of him and moving his feet up to the next step skipping the step his other foot is now on.
When he can do this with reduced physical help, just touch the leg to be moved.
Hold onto the child’s hand and help him walk up the steps alternating; then reduce the help. Have him hold railing to increase balance.

Have one of the child’s shoes tied with red string, the other with green and place colored yarn, red and green on alternating steps going up. Praise the child and reward each improvement in skill. (Red shoe goes on red step, green shoe goes on green step, etc.)

cards.title: Marches

Tasks.Action: Begin by marching in place. Model activity for child.
If necessary, give aid by grasping child’s ankles and gently move legs up and down, alternating.
Use a cadence count, left-right, marching music, to establish rhythm.
Use baton, drum, cymbals or other rhythm instruments to improve rhythm.
Remind child to lift his knees by modeling with exaggerated movements and verbal reminder “knees up.”
Play marching music with strong cadence beat. Reinforce for good marching.

cards.title: Catches ball with two hands

Tasks.Action: Have the child hold his arms out, and stand behind the child. Have someone toss ball to the child, standing at first just a foot away. Push child’s hands together to help him catch the ball. Praise and gradually reduce aid.

Have the child hold his arms out. Make sure the child is watching the ball. Say, “Arms out. Here it comes.” Then gently toss the ball to him. Praise the child as he improves. Gradually increase the distance between you and the child when he is catching the ball consistently at a distance of one foot.
Use a large, light ball. At first, a foam rubber ball may be appropriate.
Use a balloon at first so the child can get some idea of grasping onto a slowly moving object.

cards.title: Uses templates

Tasks.Action: Use templates of circle, square, triangle. Demonstrate to child by tracing around inside of template. Lift and show child design to motivate him.
Hold template steady for child, show him how to hold and move hand out of way.
Show him how to hold it himself with one hand while he traces with other. Tape template to paper if necessary.
Ask him to make shape pushing against the cutout edge of stencil.
Use ink crayons, colored pencils, and crayons.
Let child try tracing around household objects.
When bathing, let the child trace wall patterns in water and suds with finger.
Use shapes in sand box. Encourage child to make “pictures” by tracing objects with finger or stick. Reinforce good tracing.

cards.title: Cuts along 8” straight line within ¼” line

Tasks.Action: Draw heavy lines across 8”x11” paper. Have child cut strips as you hold paper. Gradually reduce aid.
Make paper chains out of strips that were cut correctly as reinforcement.
Cut on a diagonal line.
Start with a 4” long line and lengthen line to be cut as child improves.
Draw two lines about ¼” apart and ask child to try cutting between the lines.

You may need to begin with long 1” wide strip marked with heavy lines about an inch apart so that child can snip off one inch piece. Gradually increase width of strip so that it will take more and more snips.
Use verbal cues (i.e. “on the line,” “open,” “shut”) to keep him cutting until he reaches end of paper. Reinforce good cutting.

cards.title: Stands on one foot without aid 4-8 seconds

Tasks.Action: Place the child in a hallway or between 2 chairs. Have the child hold on to the wall of chairs with both hands as he raises one foot. Count slowly to 5, and praise the child as he gains in skill.
Use one small chair or hold one of the child’s and ask him to stand on one foot.
When the child can stand on one foot with support, gradually reduce the support given. Go from holding on to a chair, to holding the end of a pencil (with adult on the end).
Walking between rungs of ladder which is placed on the ground, stepping over a suspended rope and kicking a ball will provide the child with momentary practice of standing on one foot.
Let the child hold onto the pencil (without support on the other end) or a block to help him balance himself.
Count aloud the number of seconds he stands and reward improvement. Start with the goal set at one or two seconds and gradually increase the time criteria.

cards.title: Runs changing direction

Tasks.Action: Show child how to do the activity.
Mark a course with tape, string, or markers that would necessitate changing directions.
Run relays. Play tag.
Practice running with directions such as “Go near Dad” or “Go near Mum?” using 2-3 part directions such as “ run to the tree and then to the swing.”
Practice using “left” and “right” as direction words such as “run left, run right, run left” as directed by leader. Reinforce for following directions by allowing child to be leader.

cards.title: Walks balance beam

Tasks.Action: Place the board flat on the floor and walk the length of it showing the child how to balance himself. Walk heel to toe on floor.
Have the child look at a spot on the wall (like a picture) while you help him walk the beam by holding onto his hand. Praise the child as he reduces the number of times he falls off.
Give the child something to hold in each hand like a small block to help him balance. Have the child hold his arms to the side.
Place strips of paper directly on the floor about four feet in length, and one foot in between them. Then try the balance beam. Praise the child as he improves.
Place a beanbag on the top of his head. This will help him hold his body and head erect for more balance.
Place the board on top of cinder blocks.

cards.title: Jumps forward 10 times without falling

Tasks.Action: Show the child what to do by mumping forward, counting aloud each time as you go. Encourage the child to imitate you. Reinforce him for jumping.
Practice jumping in place 10 times, counting aloud so the child and you will know if he’s improving.
Stand a few feet in front of the child and ask him to jump to you. Count aloud each jump and gradually increase the distance. Praise each improvement in skill.
Make chalk line on sidewalk, or yarn lines on rug; encourage child to jump between lines.
Jump over boards or over suspended rope.
Play leapfrog, jack-in-the-box, sand bag jump.
Pretend you are bunnies and jump around yard.

cards.title: Jumps over string 2 inches off the floor

Tasks.Action: Begins by jumping over markers lying flat on the floor such as tape, yardstick, yarn, etc.
Begin by having child jump over a string or jump rope one inch off floor. Gradually raise. Praise all effort.
Stand in front of child (string between you) holding his hands. Physically aid by pulling him up and over string.

Secure a rope 2 inches off floor by tying it to the legs of 2 sturdy chairs. Model how to jump over the rope. Encourage the child to jump. Count the number of times that he jumps successfully. Reinforce by praising improvements.
Secure a bamboo pole 2 inches off the floor. Encourage the child to jump over the pole for practice.

cards.title: Jumps backwards six times

Tasks.Action: Choose open area to avoid bumping into things. Model activity. Begin by jumping backward one time. Gradually increase.
Hold child by the waist, either facing him or behind him. Jump together until child is confident enough to jump by himself.
At the beach, encourage the child to jump backwards from the sand into the water, start at one jump distance and gradually increase distance.
Practice jumping to a named location (i.e. jump to the sandbox, jump to the chair.) Reinforce good jumping.

cards.title: Bounces and catches large ball

Tasks.Action: Show the child what to do by bouncing the ball yourself.
Stand 3-4 feet away from the child and bounce the ball to him and have him bounce it back to you.
Stand behind the child take his hands and help him bounce the ball.
Have the child drop the ball and catch it with both hands on the bounce up.
You drop the ball on the floor and have the child bounce it.
Hold onto the child’s elbow and wrist with both of your hands and withdraw aid to just the wrist. Bounce the ball for him by moving his hand up and down hitting the ball.
Use verbal cues as you model and physically guide the action so that the child will use the cues to help with his timing. (i.e. “Bounce and Catch” )

cards.title: Makes clay shapes put together with 2 to 3 parts

Tasks.Action: You and child each roll 5 clay balls. Show child how to stick balls together to form a body of a gingerbread man, snowman, a rabbit, a cat, etc. Tell him to copy your model. Verbally cue him on placing the parts.

You and child each roll 5 “ sticks” plus a rectangle          Show child how you attach “sticks” to form legs and tail for an animal or legs for a chair, table, etc. Let clay dry and use objects as play furniture for the animal shapes made of clay.
Practice using bread or cookie dough to make men and animals. Reinforce the child by letting him eat the finished product.
Use marshmallows and have the child stick them together with frosting to practice making shapes.
Use sand and water mixture to make shapes.

cards.title: Cuts curve

Tasks.Action: Cut corners from a square.
Cut out circles. You hold paper and turn as child cuts.
Cut out “tail” following heavy lines on paper.
Use simple shapes with gentle curves.
Cut curved strips of paper.

Use heavy line as guide initially. Physically guide child in holding and turning the paper as he cuts. Gradually reduce the aid to verbal cues of “turn” and “cut on the line” and finally have the child cut on the line independently. Reinforce successful cutting.

cards.title: Screws together threaded object

Tasks.Action: Use jars with lids, nuts and bolts.
Hold bottom piece while child screws on top.
Place your hands over child’s and help him make the twisting motion to screw object together.

Child may need to hold container between knees for added stability. Encourage him to hold the jar near the top with left hand and to twist the lid with the right. Reinforce opening jar by having a treat or toy surprise inside the jar.
Initially make certain lid is started on threads correctly so that child can finish turning on the lid.

cards.title: Walks downstairs alternating feet

Tasks.Action: Child uses handrail and holds adult’s hand.

Tie one of the child’s shoes with red string and the other with blue. Place colored yarn, red and blue on alternating steps going down as a guide for the child. Praise child and remove yarn as he improves.

Show the child how to “step and hold” or not put both feet on the same step. An exaggerated example may help him to remember to keep shifting feet. Encourage him to use verbal cues. Reinforce good stair walking.
Initially a short flight of stairs or beginning near the bottom of the stairs will allow him to succeed more readily.

cards.title: Pedals tricycle, turning corner

Tasks.Action: Place obstacles in path of tricycle.
Have child “chase” you on tricycle as you move in different directions in front of him.
Initially stand behind child and help him turn with hands by guiding the handlebars. Gradually reduce the aid in steering until the child can do it himself.
When child can pedal successfully forward, encourage him to “turn” to the left or toward the sandbox or other object. Physically help him turn the handlebars and gradually reduce aid.
Clear a space large enough for the tricycle to make a full circle, tie handlebars in wide turn position so that child has practice riding in a circle.
Have the child go around an object such as sandbox.

cards.title: Hops on one foot 5 successive times

Tasks.Action: Have the child hold onto your arm for initial support. Hop with him across floor and praise the child.

Use a rod or stick such as a broom handle. Stand in front of the child holding the broom handle at his chest level and let him hold it with one hand and hop. Gradually let go and let the child hop with the stick.
Play stepping stones, hopping from 1 spot to another.
Stand a short distance (2 feet) in front of the child and have him hop to you. When he can do this, gradually increase the distance. Praise each improvement.
Sometimes giving the child something to hold in each hand, such as blocks, will give the child enough “support” so he can maintain his balance while hopping.

cards.title: Cuts out 2-inch circle

Tasks.Action: Draw circles on paper with heavy black lines. Use different thickness of paper.

Start with a heavy sheet of paper with a circle about 4 inches around and circles inside that one down to about 2 inches around. Have child cut them out, one at a time, starting with the largest, until he gains the skill of cutting smaller circles. Reward child after each circle and challenge him to cut a smaller one.
Encourage the child to practice cutting circles by letting him cut with kitchen scissors (i.e. cheese slices into a circle to toast on a bun, luncheon meat to make designs on bread, etc.)
Initially you may need to help him turn the paper or use verbal cue of “turn, turn.” Gradually reduce the aid. Reinforce good cutting.

cards.title: Draws simple recognizable pictures such as house, man, tree

Tasks.Action: You draw a house using simple shapes – a square or rectangle plus a triangle for a roof. Ask child to copy. Use verbal cues.
Encourage child to sit and draw with colored pencils, crayons, ink crayons.

Encourage child as he draws if he forgets important parts by asking child questions like, “Does a house have a door?” “How many legs does a man have?” etc. Praise child for his attempts. His drawings need not look like yours.
Have the child shut his eyes and using a black marker make one “scribble” on a paper. Let him open his eyes and make a picture using the “scribble” as a head, a roof, a pull string, etc.
Let the child use different materials such as markers, paint, colored chalk on dark paper, etc. Reinforce good drawing.

cards.title: Cuts out and pastes simple shapes

Tasks.Action: Cut out geometric shapes. Trace around shapes on paper. Paste shapes into outlines.
Cut out picture of familiar objects from magazines. Trace around shape, paste picture into outline to make a scrapbook.
Cut colored pieces of paper and paste onto another piece of paper to make a picture.
Cut out a red circle, square, and triangle, and a blue circle, square, and triangle. Paste red circle into red outline and blue circle into blue outline, etc.
Let child practice cutting by cutting out pictures in sticker books where the pictures are already perforated.

Mark around pictures in toy catalog or magazines with markers making heavy triangle, circle, curved or square shapes. Let the child cut them out and paste in a scrapbook or on a large sheet of newsprint.

cards.title: Prints capital letters, large, single, anywhere on paper

Tasks.Action: Provide a model of letter for child to copy.
Child can hold crayons as you guide hand.
You draw one line at a time and child does likewise until form is made.
Use a different color for each line. Tell child to copy form using the same color you did.
Provide a chalkboard and chalk.
Encourage child to form letters by going from left to right and by making downward strokes for vertical letters.

Provide practice by letting the child use different materials such as a shoebox of sand and a stick to make sand writing. Print with squeeze tube of frosting on wax paper, when hard child may peel off and eat. Use plain or colored water to “paint” letters on the sidewalk or driveway with a big brush.

cards.title: Walks balance board forward, backward and sideways

Tasks.Action: Play follow the leader on balance board. Have child imitate what you do.
Give physical aid to child if he needs it, gradually withdrawing aid.
Assure Child you will catch him if he falls or stumbles to encourage him to try movements on his own.
Let the child pretend he is a car, truck, train or cycle as he moves forward, backs into position to “load” etc. Reinforce good performance.
Let the child pretend to be an animal as he walks the board. (i.e. elephant, tiger, bird, etc.)

cards.title: Skips

Tasks.Action: Start by galloping – stepping with one foot, hopping with the other.

Stand behind the child and hold him under his arms. Push his right leg forward with yours as you begin, saying, “Step, hop, step.” Move through the motion slowly. Then do the same with the left foot. Continue until the child can step, hop, alternating feet, using verbal cues.
Have the child watch you as you say and do – step, hop, step, hop, skipping slowly so he can watch each movement.
Have the child skip holding onto your hand, skip with him slowly saying, “step-hop” as you go. Praise the child as he improves.
Have the child skip by himself still giving the verbal directions of “step-hop”

cards.title: Swings on swing initiating and sustaining motion

Tasks.Action: Child should be able to touch ground with feet when sitting on swing.
Model for child how to initiate swinging motion. Praise child for imitating.
First have the child practice just sustaining motion. You give him a push to start. When he can do the pumping himself, show him how to initiate movement by pushing off with his feet.
Encourage the child to use verbal cues “back” and “up” or “forward” as he swings.

cards.title: Spreads fingers, touching thumb to each finger

Tasks.Action: Demonstrate and ask child to copy.
Use physical aid to help child touch thumb to each finger.
Have child try picking up small objects with thumb and each of the fingers. Let him keep the objects if he can pick them up.
Draw a face on each finger. Encourage the “mailman” thumb to deliver a letter to each finger.
Print numerals on each fingertip. Have the child count or say the number as he touches each with his thumb. Reinforce success.

cards.title: Can copy small letters

Tasks.Action: Provide a model for child to copy.
Print letters with dotted lines for child to outline.
Child can trace cutout letters or use templates.
Place a colored mark as cue for starting point in forming letter.

Practice using large pencils, crayons, markers, chalk, paint or different surfaces such as the floor, windows, chalkboards, mirror, table tops with washable materials such as tempera paints, whipped colored soap suds, shaving cream, etc.

cards.title: Climbs up step ladders or steps ten feet high to slide

Tasks.Action: Give child verbal instructions for climbing.
Assure child that you are right behind him if he slips. Praise child for climbing independently.
Put reward at top of ladder or slide.
Initially you may need to follow closely behind and slide down with the child between your legs.
Let the child place both feet on each step and make certain he has a firm grip on the railings. Encourage verbally each step up initially.

cards.title: Hits nail with hammer

Tasks.Action: Use 2 hammers, one for you and one for child. Let him imitate your pounding.
Show the child how to pound. Give physical help by guiding his hand.
Start out the nails for the child, and be sure he can pound them fairly well before having start the nails out.
Space each nail so he has room to miss without hitting another nail.
Use soft wood for pounding and nails with large heads.

cards.title: Dribbles ball with direction

Tasks.Action: Show the child what to do by bouncing the ball yourself.
Hold onto the child’s elbow and wrist with both of your hands and withdraw aid to just the wrist. Bounce the ball for him by moving his hand up and down hitting the ball.
You drop the ball on the floor and have the child bounce it.
Mark an “X” on the floor with chalk; have child bounce the ball on top of the ‘X’ and then catch it.
Have child bounce ball several times in stationary position. Then ask child to bounce ball as he walks toward you or another object.

cards.title: Colors, remaining within lines 95%

Tasks.Action: Color geometric shapes first, then move to simple pictures.
Use coloring book with large, simple pictures. Have the child outline the picture first, then color it. Praise child for staying within the lines of pictures.
Use Elmer’s glue and completely outline the drawing. Allow the glue to dry. This will provide a tactile guideline to help the child color within the lines.

Let the child color inside a metal template or make templates of plastic coffee lids or paper plates. As his skill improves try having him color inside a heavy marker line. Gradually reduce aid. Reinforce success at each step.

cards.title: Can cut picture from magazine or catalog without being more than ¼” from edge

Tasks.Action: Cut object away from rest of page so it is easier to handle.
Have child choose object from magazine or catalog that he wants to cut.
Let child cut from magazines with thick pages initially.

Initially outline the picture with heavy marker lines, reduce the size of the line, then have the child outline with crayon before cutting. As he improves, gradually reduce the aid given. Reinforce good cutting at each step.

cards.title: Uses pencil sharpener

Tasks.Action: Show child where to insert pencil. Hold your hands over his and physically guide him through operation.
Use thick pencil at first.
Instruct child to take pencil out occasionally to check if it is sharp enough.

Count the approximate number of turns needed to sharpen a pencil on your sharpener. Have the child count to that number as he turns the handle so that he does not sharpen away his entire pencil. Reinforce him for doing a good job of sharpening.

cards.title: Copies complex drawings

Tasks.Action: Ask child to carefully look at drawing.
Use verbal cues as he attempts to copy.
Have child imitate line by line as you draw. Proceed to having him imitate your drawing two lines at a time. Gradually work up to child copying completed drawing.
Let child practice using tracing paper over complex line drawings and tracing over them.

Have a model for him to look at. Use your finger as a cue or have him trace the line he is going to make on the model, then on his paper before copying the line with his pencil. Reinforce good drawing.

cards.title: Tears simple shapes from paper

Tasks.Action: Show child how to tear a shape. Use simple ones such as a ball, a heart, a leaf, etc. Progress to a doll, an animal. Praise all efforts.
At first, make an outline on paper or have child draw guidelines of the shape to be torn out. As he gains the skill of tearing paper with some sort of guide, Have him try it without aid.
Tape or staple the outline of a shape on a piece of paper. Have child tear around it.

Initially use a plastic bowl, cup or plate or a metal template held against the tabletop. Have the child tear the paper from around the object. Gradually reduce aid to outline of cardboard or drawing. Reinforce success at each step.

cards.title: Folds paper square two times on diagonal in imitation

Tasks.Action: Demonstrate activity. Do one step at a time and have child copy.
Draw lines on square to aid child in folding it diagonally.
Have child refold paper at first. Have him fold a piece of paper around one that has already been folded.
Mark the inside corner of the paper that the child will be folding towards, mark the outside corner diagonally opposite it with the same color as a guide.
Use verbal cues such “make certain the corners are together.” Gradually reduce the aid given. Reinforce appropriate folding.

cards.title: Catches soft ball or bean bag with one hand

Tasks.Action: Give child an object to hold in less preferred hand. Stand 3 feet away from child and toss beanbag or softball for him to catch with preferred hand. Praise success. Gradually move further away from child as his skill improves.
Use object that has more parts to grasp such as a soft pillow, rag doll, washcloth or a rag with a knot tied in it.
Have the child put the less preferred hand in his pocket or behind him, let him stand in a corner of the room or against a wall to make it easier to catch the object. Reinforce success.
Let the child practice throwing the ball against a wall or a net and catching it with one hand.

cards.title: Can jump rope by self

Tasks.Action: Begin by having child bring rope over head and stop rope in front of feet. Then jump over rope. Continue until child can do both actions in a continuous motion.
Use cue words such as “swing, jump!”
Have two people turn rope as child jumps.

Initially the child should have a thick, rather heavy rope so that it will swing with ease. A lighter rope can have a knot or a series of knots tied in the middle so that it will swing to the floor or ground without tangling.

cards.title: Hits ball with bat or stick

Tasks.Action: Roll large ball on ground. Child can hit ball toward you with bat or stick.
Use a whiffle ball and plastic bat.
Use an old racquet if child needs wider area to hit.
Stand next to child, put arms around him and hands over his, holding bat. Physically cause him to swing at the right moment.
Give verbal cues –“now!” “hit!” etc. at time he should swing bat.

cards.title: Picks up object from ground while running

Tasks.Action: Run relay that has running to pick up object and back to starting point as the objective.
Object may be placed higher to begin with and gradually lowered to ground.
Model the activity for the child and initially use objects that can be picked up easily, such as things with handles.

Initially you may let the child run and just touch a certain point, then have another person hand him the object, finally let him pick up the object independently. (Indian club, bowling pin, wooden baton, balls, beanbags are some objects that might be used.)

cards.title: Skates forward 10 feet

Tasks.Action: Support the child, under arms or holding hand. Gradually withdraw aid.
Show him how to get back to standing position by kneeling in the grass or on the ice and getting up or pulling self up on fence, etc.
Initially let child skate on indoor-outdoor carpeting so he won’t slip so much.
Walk beside the child holding a broom handle or dowel so that he can maintain balance for two or more alternations of feet.

cards.title: Rides bicycles

Tasks.Action: Use training wheels.
Support child by hanging onto bike at handlebars and seat while running along side. Gradually reduce aid.
Hold the seat from the back just enough to prevent him from tipping over.
Have the child start out on a slight incline so that he can gain momentum.

cards.title: Slides on sled

Tasks.Action: Model activity for child.

Let child lay on sled as you pull him on level ground. Then pull child down a small incline. Next, try sledding on a small hill, starting halfway down the hill, then starting closer to the top each time.
Slide down hill on the sled with child on top of you, then repeat and let him steer the sled, finally let him slide independently with just a push to get started.

cards.title: Walks or plays in water waist-high in swimming pool

Tasks.Action: Let the child adjust to the water temperature very gradually. Have him splash water on himself before he gets in it. If impossible water temperature should be somewhat close to body temperature.
When child is standing in water, let him hold on to edge of pool so he can accustom himself to the feeling of buoyancy.
Let child bounce up and down in water while holding onto edge.
Get into water with child and let him hold your hand while you walk around.
As child becomes able to walk by himself in water, play games with him such as catch or tag.
Have the child practice putting his face in the water momentarily, on the beach he can lie with body in water and just head and neck out.
Use a life jacket to help the child in being secure as he plays.

cards.title: Steers wagon , propelling  with one root

Tasks.Action: Model activity.
Position child in wagon. Physically guide foot if necessary.
Place wagon on slight incline.
Push child as he sits in wagon until he can control steering.

cards.title: Jumps up and pivots on one foot

Tasks.Action: Model activity.
Hold child under arms and physically guide him through motion.
Play hopscotch.
Stand behind child. Ask him to jump up one foot and turn around to look at you.

cards.title: Prints name on primary paper using lines.

Tasks.Action: Explain guidelines to child.
Print child’s name on lines. Have him trace.
Use a model and have child copy.
Direct his moves with verbal cues. Praise!
Divide page into large lines about 2 inches high.
Dot out letters between lines for child to connect.

cards.title: Jumps from height of 12 inches and lands on balls of feet

Tasks.Action: Model activity. Explain and demonstrate landing on balls of feet. Child then imitates.
Use verbal cues; bend your knees, land on balls of feet.
Stand in front of child. Grasp his hands and help him jump.
Let the child jump into the water at the pool or beach.

cards.title: Stands on one foot, no support, eyes closed, 10 seconds

Tasks.Action: Model activity.
Count aloud to
Hold child’s hand, finger, clothing to help him maintain balance. Gradually decrease aid.
At first, let child stand with the toes of his other foot on ground for some support.

cards.title: Hangs 10 seconds from horizontal bar bearing own weight on arms

Tasks.Action: Hold child at waist while he hangs on bar. Gradually decrease support.
Use a bar that is low enough so he is suspended only a few inches from the ground.

Let the child climb the ladder side of bars set. Encourage him to climb up the rung and hang by his arms briefly holding his feet above ladder rung. Gradually increase the time he supports his weight.

cards.title: Removes cloth from face, that obscures visio n

Tasks.Action:
Lay child on back in crib. Place cloth over face. T alk to the child so he knows you are still there. S mile 
and hug child as he pulls cloth off eyes.

Physically guide child by holding upper arm and hel ping him bat at cloth; gradually withdraw aid. 
Reward with touching, smiling, exaggerated facial e xpression when cloth is removed.

Cover only one eye with the cloth and you gradually  move from child’s vision. Help him tug at cloth to  
uncover both eyes. Reward child with praise and a k iss.

1 Hold a bright coloured toy in front of child. Remov e from line of vision slowly. 
2 Use ratte or noisemaker.Remove from line of vision and shake rattle to gain child’s attention 
3 If child will look at person when he moves from dir ect line of vision, but not object; begin by holdin g 
object near your face. Move slowly out of direct li ne of vision. Verbalize as you do this as long as t he 
child follows you. Gradually hold the object furthe r from your face so child visually follows object a nd 
not you. 
4 Put brightly colored chain around your neck. Bend o ver child so he sees the necklace, but not so close  
that he can pull it. Move slowly away from child as  he watches beads.

Show the child how to take the object out of the co ntainer by doing it yourself.say “out “ as you 
remove the object and repeat several times. Then re place the object and point to it and container and 
say  “out  “

Physically guide the child’s hand to help him remov e the object. Say, “good, you took it out.”Reward 
with smiles hug or kiss. Gradually reduce aid to po inting and saying ‘OUT.”

Put object in container and shake contaner to make noise. Point to object in container and shake 
again. Praise child for removing object from contai ner.

Put out several small toys to see which one the chi ld begins playing with. Then use this to teach the 
skill in the ways suggested above.
Point to the child’s toy on the floor and say,” get  the ball.” Praise him when he does.
Help the child pick up the toy by guiding his hand.  Reduce help as the child gains in skill.
Food ,like a small bit of cookie place d on the flo or ,may provide the child twith the desire to pick it up.

Tie a toy on the end of a string and tie the other end to tray of high chair or bar of a crib so that the 
child has opportunity to practice this skill when c onfined or when adult is not actively attending.

Place small on object on coffee table or low table.  Get child to watch it. Slowly push toy over the ed ge, 
have child pick up object.

When child drops object assist him in picking it up . As child gains skill, verbally direct him to pick  up 
his own toy. .

Line up 3 blocks for the child and push the blocks saying, "choo-choo". Physically guide the child’s 
hand to help him push. Praise the child as you help  him push the blocks. Gradually withdraw aid.

You take a set of 3 blocks and line up 3 blocks for  the child. Have him imitate your movements as you 
push the blocks. Have a race with the child to anot her object.
Push blocks across table unitil they tumble off edg e. Pick up blocks and ask child to imitate.

Show the child how to remove the circle from the fr ame. Physically guide him in removing circle. Say 
“out” and reward with praise. Point to or tap table  or tray where he should put the circle.

Tape other pieces to the puzzle or remove other sha pes that may be in the puzzle so the child just has  
one to look at and manipulate.

Glue an empty spool of thread or a small knob to th e puzzle piece so it will be easier to grasp and li ft 
out. Praise the child as he works and has success.

Tape a picture of interest on puzzle underneath rou nd block for child to see when he removes puzzle 
piece.

Show the child how to clap hands by first clapping your hands together and saying pat-a-cake. Then 
take the child’s hands and clap them together for h im saying “pat-a-cake” as you guide the child 
through the movements.
Place the child in your lap with your arms around h im to help him clap his hands. Smile and hug.

Gradually reduce help by applying less pressure to his hands. Continue praising and smiling as you go 
through the motions and as the child imitates the a ction by himself.

Say “Let’s clap hands” to the child and start clapp ing your hands. Praise child for imitating. 
Withdraw your model. Say, “Let’s clap hands” and pr aise child for clapping his hands without your 
model.

Encourage child to imitate gestures such as: a. Pick up toy phone and say “Hi.” b. Sniff a flower. c. Wave a toy in the air. d. Pretend to drink from a cup. e. Hold a block in each hand and hit them together.  
f. Make a coughing sound.
Hold the container so the child must remove the obj ects individually and not dump them.

Use colorful blocks and a large cup. Show the ch ild how to remove the blocks. Hand the cup to the 
child and say “Give me the blocks”. If necessary gi ve physical assistance by guiding the child’s 
hand. Gradually withdraw physical help and give ver bal clues only. Praise the child’s attempts and 
successes at removing each block individually from container.

Put treat in bottom of container and six blocks or small toys on top. When objects are removed he 
can reach in  and have the treat.

Put parts to a toy in container. For instance,anima ls to Fisher-Price barn in the silo.Have child take  
one out at a time and set them up.

Let child help you with a task such as taking cloth es out from a laundry hamper, taking silverware 
from a drawer,or taking food out of a grocery bag.P ut a treat for child at bottom of whatever 
container you use.

Hold a doll, and ask “Where is the dolly’s nose?” I f necessary, guide the child’s hand and praise him 
as he touches the correct body part.

Point to child’s own nose and say, “Here is John’s nose.” “Where is John’s nose?” Help him by 
guiding his hand and reduce the help as the child l earns.
Using a mirror show the child where his nose is.hav e him feel it, also let him feel your nose.
Use any body part not necessarily his nose.

In daily activities start mentioning the child’s bo dy parts. Let the child wear stickers on certain bo dy 
parts, i.e put a star on his hand.and ask him where ’s the star? Answer for him if necessary and point 
at the same   time, say “There it is ! It’s in your  hand!” Use masking tape if stickers are not availa ble. 
Have the child peel off tape as you name body part.

cards.title: Stacks 3 blocks on request.

Tasks.Action:
Start with larger blocks –2 or 3 inches square. Sho w the child how to stack by doing it slowly yoursel f, 
saying,  “First this one, then this one, then this one.” Then give the blocks to the child asking him to 
make a tower like yours. Reward improvements with p raise and hugs.

If physical help is necessary, guide the child’s ha nd and gradually reduce physical help as he gains i n 
skill.
Point where each block should go to provide the chi ld with some clue. Reward each improvement.

Begin with 6 blocks. Build a model with three block s and then leave yours up for him to imitate with 
his three blocks. Praise success.

Use 6 blocks and build two towers together. Have th e child imitate each of your movements with his 
tower as you build yours-slowly and one block at a time. Praise the chils as he imitates.
Reward child for stacking 3 blocks on request witho ut a model.
Let child knock down the tower as a reward.

cards.title: Matches like objects.

Tasks.Action:
Begin with four objects the child is familiar with (2 balls, 2 dolls, etc.) Hold one ball and ask chil d to 
“Find the other ball.” Repeat for dolls. Gradually increase the number and kinds of objects to match.
Repeat above activity using pictures instead of obj ects.

For variety, use 2 paper bags with identical object s. You pull an object from your bag and ask the 
child to find the same object in his bag.
