Let child try to sort silverware or white tee shirt s from dark socks or apples from oranges in a bin. 
Give him a model by putting out one place setting, a tee shirt and a sock, etc.

Make a “pegboard” out of a shoe box and use clothep ins for pegs. Show the child what to do by 
placing atleast one peg in a hole.Then hand the chi ld another peg and, if necessary,show him where to 
place the peg by pointing to a hole.

Give physical help by guiding the child’s hand to t he hole and reduce help as he gains in skill. Prais e 
the child as he improves.
Talk about activity as it is being done so child wi ll eventually do it when asked without a model.

cards.title: Points to named pictures

Tasks.Action:
Use large family photographs or a children’s book w ith large pictures of common objects. Show the 
child the picture and say “show me the ball.” If ne cessary guide child’s hand to point to object as yo u 
name it. Then ask child again “Where is the ball?”
Start with one picture and as the child learns, add  additional pictures.
Praise and say, “That’s right, that is the ball, et c.” after each correct response.

Make a booklet containing pictures the child can po int to. Use pictures of favorite foods such as 
cookies, potato chips, pop, etc.Let child have some  of that food as reward if he points to it correctl y.

Use individual pictures. Present two at a time and ask him to point to one. Guide his hand and shw 
him the correct picture if he does not know.

When child can point to individual pictures then pr esent him with stimulus material with more items 
on a page.

cards.title: Turns pages of book 2-3 at a time to find named pic ture.

Tasks.Action:
Open book to page with familiar picture. Talk about  picture and have child point to it. Close book and  
ask child to find picture.

Use a small child’s storybook, with cardboard pages . Read it several times to the child or talk about 
the picture in it. One particular picture may catch  the child’s interest. Close the book and have the 
child find the picture for you. Help him initially by physically guiding the child in turning the 
pages.Give verbal clues and encourage child to keep  looking if he does not find the picture 
immediately.
Let the child look through several books and use th e one that he is most interested in.
Use storybooks or picture books with only a few pag es and one pictured item per page.
Keep child’s books in a special pile or on a certai n shelf so child knows where his books are.

Use two books at first. Talk about the pictures on the cover and read books to child .Ask child to fin d 
thebook about dogs from those two books. Mix the oo ks in with child’s other books and ask him again 
to find the dog book. Praise correct response.

Use two or three books that are quite different (an imals, trucks and people) so the child is not 
confused by similar content of the books.

cards.title: Completes 3 piece formboard

Tasks.Action:
Hand the child one shape at a time beginning with t he circle.If necessary,point to the correct hole an d 
guide his hand.When he can replace the circle witho ut any help ,hand him the square and then the 
triangle to replace.

Have the child trace around the empty shape with hi s finger and then to find one that looks and feels 
like that shape.

Place the shapes above or next to the correct openi ngs and then have the child replace them. Praise th e 
child after each correct replacement.

Color code pieces so child is placing a red circle into a red hole; or blue triangle into blue hole; o r 
orange square into an orange hole. Fade the color c ues when child is proficient at this level.

Begin by having the child name common household ite ms using real objects. Cut out pictures of 
cookies, table, chairs, T.V., bed etc. out of magaz ines. Place pictures nxt to the real objects and ha ve 
the child name the pictures. Present the pictures a lone for the child to name. Praise each correct 
response.
Encourage the child to look through simple picture books and name the pictures.
Look at picture books with child and name pictures he does not know for him.
Use photograph of real items in the child’s environ ment.

cards.title: Draws a vertical line in imitation

Tasks.Action:
Tape paper to a wall. Have child watch you draw a v ertical line from top to bottom. Ask child to imita te you. 
Give physical help if necessary. Gradually reduce a id as child gains in skill.
Make a cardboard template to guide child’s downward  stroke.
Use chalks, crayons, colored pencils, and magic mak ers.
Practice making vertical lines in sand or fingerpai nt or shaving foam.
Put stickers at top and bottom of page. Ask child t o draw from one to another.

Put M & M’s or raisins (treat that child likes) at bottom of page. Tell child he can have it if he dra ws a line 
down to it. Help him by putting his hand at top of page.
Tape paper to table. Have child use crayon to push a block to top or bottom of paper .Say “ See the li ne? You

Make a line for him to imitate. Make it quickly and  have the line go the full width of the paper. Then  give 
the child a crayon to imitate your mark.(The mark n eed not be perfectly straight.)
Guide the child’s hand in making the mark and gradu allyreduce the pressure on his hand as he gains in skill.
Have the child trace over your line and then encour age him ti make one without tracing.

Newsprint placed on the table or floor and magic ma rkers may aid in allowing the child to make a gross  
movement. Gradually reduce the size of the newsprin t.
Make a cardboard template to guide child’s horizont al stroke.
Practice making horizontal line in fingerpaint or s and.
Draw small objects at opposite ends of paper. Instr uct child to connect the two by drawing a horizonta l line.

Show the child how to make a “circle” by making gro ss concentric movements on paper for the child to 
copy.

Take the child’s hand and guide him in making the c ircular movements with a crayon. Praise the child a s you 
do this.

Having the child use his fingerto make the circular  movement on thr paper, in flour or in sand,or fing erpaint 
will give him additional practice befor using a cra yon.

Hve the child trace around the circle you draw the encourage him to make one on his own. Reward “good 
circles” by drawing “ happy faces”  inside them.
Use large newsprint to encourage gross movement of the arm before reducing the size of paper and requi ring

cards.title: Matches textures

Tasks.Action:
Put matching textures in two separate bags. Ask chi ld to select a texture from one bag and find the 
matching texture in the second bag.
Start with two or three textures at first and add m ore as child gains skill.

Talk about how the textures feel (rough, smooth, so ft, furry). 
 Mount a variety of textures on a board 
 Hang board at child’s level. 
 Give child identical sample of textured piece. 
 Have child match sample with a piece on the board 
 Repeat giving child additional samples to match on board.

cards.title: Points to big and little upon request

Tasks.Action:
Collect big and little versions of the same type of  objects, i.e (big and little envelopes, pencils, s tones, 
shoes, coats, dishes, cookies, marshmallows, chairs , cars)

Place a big and little pencil in front of child ask  him to make a mark on paper with the big 
 pencil. 
Praise success. Repeat activity with other objects.
Ask child to find big and little objects around the  house.

Have parent or teacher name big and little objects for the child for a week..After this have the child  
begin pointing to the big and little objects.

Do motor activities such as taking big steps little  steps, big jumps, little jumps, sit in a big chair , little 
chair.

cards.title: Matches three colors

Tasks.Action:
Begin using two colors—yellow and red. Cut out 6 re d and 6 yellow circles. One at a time you place 4 
red circles in one pile and 4 yellow circles in ano ther. Hand the child the last four circles. He is t o place 
last 4 circles. Guide his hand to help him place th e colors correctly if necessary.
Leave more circles for him to match and sort and wi thdraw help. Reward correct matches with praise.

Use a pegboard and colored pegs. Hold up a red peg and ask the child to find another like this. Repeat  
with other colors. Instruct child to place pegs in board in rows of colors .

Place large colored circles on floor, (red, yellow and blue) Hand the child one colored circle. Instru ct 
him to step only on the circles, which are the same  color as the one he is holding.

Place 3 different colored pieces of paper in front of child. Ask him to match objects of the same thre e 
colors which he draws one at a time from a bag to t he correct paper color.

Cut out circles of 3 colors that you want the child  to match. Let child carry them around house to fin d 
things that match in color. Then let him take circl es around and leave them on matching objects. Have 
him show you them. Reward with praise.

cards.title: Places object in, on and under upon request .

Tasks.Action:
Use an inch cube and cup. Tell child you are puttin g cube under the cup. Have him imitate you. 
Repeat for “on” and “in.”
Use a big box .Ask child to position himself in, on , and under in relation to the box.

Name positions of the child as you move him out of his bed, up in the air, down on the chair, into his  
bed,etc.

Say the directional word and show him how to place either himself or an object. Tell the child in a 
single word command—IN.

Use a desired toy or doll and place it in, under an d on relative to a box. Then encourage the child to  
place the toy according to the directions you give.  Praise success and give needed help and reduce tha t 
help as the child gains in skill.
While looking through picture books have him tell y ou if certain objects are in, on, or under others.

cards.title: Name objects that makes sounds

Tasks.Action:
When the telephone rings say, “that’s a telephone,”  repeat with doorbell, alarm clock, tractor, vacuum  
cleaner, airplane, etc. When the sound occurs, ask the child “What is that?” Give help if needed.

Make some animal sounds yourself (barking dog, meow ing cat, moowing cow, quacking duck) and ask 
the child to name the animal that makes that sound.

Cut out pictures of animals and have the child find  the animal whose sound you make, i.e, “which one 
goes quack, quack?”
Tape record familiar environmental sounds and ask c hild to name them when heard.

cards.title: Puts together 4 part nesting toy

Tasks.Action: Use two parts at first and add more as child shows understanding of skill.
Using two identical nesting toys, ask child to imit ate you step by step as toy is put together.

Give verbal instructions to child as he puts togeth er toy. “Pick up the smallest one Good! Now find th e 
smallest piece left on the table and put it inside. ”

If using a 5 part-nesting toy, give him only the fi rst two pieces. Have him choose the one that goes n ext. 
He will have fewer objects to choose from this way.  When he chooses one then put out another one.
Nesting toys are like barrels or eggs that come in a series of sizes a all fit into one another.

cards.title: Names action pictures

Tasks.Action: Point to pictures as you read stories and tell the child what action is pictured.

Point out actions of other family members; explain what they are doing.i.e, “ Daddy’s washing the car,  
Mommy’s sewing,’’ “Billy’s riding his bike.”

Play a guessing game with the child. You act out ac tions like crying, running, ironing, baking, sewing , 
and have the child tell you what you are doing.
Go through a magazine or book and ask the child to tell what he sees happening in the picture.

Show the child pictures of a boy (a) standing (b) w alking (c) running. Ask him to tell you what he see s 
in each picture. He may say “ A boy.” Then ask,  “ What is the boy doing in this picture?”

Have the child go through these activities himself,  such as walking, running, standing and show him 
the pictures as he is doing this.

As you go through the picture book, have the child tell you what is happenning in the pictures to 
specific animals, objects or persons.

Place pictures in front of the child and play a gam e taking turns describing activities and objects in  a 
picture. Point to the picture as it is described.

cards.title: Stacks 5 or more rings on a peg in order

Tasks.Action:
Begin with two rings of different sizes. You place each ring on the peg saying “ fist this one, and th en this 
one.” Remove the rings from the peg and have the ch ild imitate your placement. Add additional rings on e at 
a time as the child consistently succeeds.

Place things on a table in a line in order accordin g to size. Then mix them up, and have the child 
arrange pegs in order. Help him compare sizes by te lling him  “ this one is bigger than that one,” usi ng 
the biggest and smallest rings..Gradually add the r ings in between.

cards.title: Names big and little objects

Tasks.Action:
Use 5 large blocks and 5 small blocks that are the same color. Begin by having the child sort the bloc ks 
into 2 piles according to size. The child should be  able to sort without error before going on to poin ting 
to big and little Praise correct reponse.

Use two objects that differ only in size. For examp le, use two red balls, one big and one little. Begi n 
with very large and very small items. Name the ball s or blocks or other objects as big and little. The n 
ask the child to give you the big ball and then the  little one. Change the position of the objects oft en. 
When the child can cosistently point to big and lit tle without error, begin by having the child name 
object size; big or little.

Use small penny size candy bars and the same brand of large candy bars (Wrappers are the same) 
Have the child name big, little. Give the candy bar s as a reward.

Place 6 inch cut out circles and 3 inch cut out cir cles on the floor. Have child step only on the big 
circles, the on the little circles. Have child tell  you which circle to step on ( big or little ) and he is to tell 
you if you are correct.

Place a treat on one of the circles. The child shou ld correctly tell you if the circle is big or littl e before 
getting the treat.

cards.title: Points to 10 body parts on verbal command

Tasks.Action:
Begin with facial parts .As you say, “ Here are my eyes,” point to your own eyes and have the child 
imitate where you point on his own body. Repeat wit h additional body parts including hands, feet, 
neck, elbow,stomach, fingers,toes, etc.

Stand in front of a full-length mirror with the chi ld. Have the child move or touch a body part as you  
name it. “ Touch your knee, wiggle your nose, etc.”Reward by  praising.

Draw two circles one larges than the other on paper . Draw in one or two body parts and then have the 
child name what’s missing and point to where each b ody part should go. Praise the child when he 
answers correctly.
Point to body parts on dolls.
Encourage child to say name of body part as he poin ts to it.

Let child put a sticker on body part if he points t o it corectly. 
.

cards.title: Points to boy and girl on verbal command

Tasks.Action: Identify family members by sex when appropriate—“ W hat a big boy,”  “ What a pretty girl,” etc.

When reading stories to the child, point out the ch aracters in pictures as boys and girls. Then you 
point to one of the pictures and ask the child to p oint to the boy and girl.
You point to a picture and have the child identify the picture as a boy or girl.
Use boy and girl dolls (GI Joe, Barbie) and encoura ge the child to dress the dolls according to sex.

cards.title: Tells if objects is heavy or light

Tasks.Action:
Let the child hold something heavy (5 lb bag of sug ar) and say to the child,  “That’s heavy,” then giv e 
him a bag of marshmallows,  “That’s light.”Try to u se objects that are the same size but that differ i n 
weight then place the two bags of objects on the ta ble and ask him to lift each and tell which is heav y, 
which is light.

Gradually reduce the difference in weight between t he objects Praise the child when he is able to tell  
you which of the objects is heavy, which is light.

Use pictures of objects such as an elephant and a b ell,a car and a baby,and a plane and a chair, and 
have the child sort the pictures in two piles ,one for heavy objects,one for light objects.
Name heavy and light objects in household.

Let child fill glasses or pans with different amoun ts of sand or water. Have him choose which pan with  
sand is heavy, which is light.

cards.title: Puts together two parts of shape to make who le

Tasks.Action:
Use a cardboard circle cut in half. Show child how to make a circle by positioning the two parts. Have  
child imitate. Have another circle whole as a model .

Draw a circle on paper divided in half by a line. H ave child martch circle parts to guide lines on pap er. 
Remove guide lines as child gains in skill.

Use simple outline drawings of animals and objects cut in half. Begin by putting out only one shape at  a 
time for the child. Gradually increase the number s o the child must find the 2 pieces that go together .

cards.title: Describes two events or characters from fami liar story or T.V. Program

Tasks.Action:
Tell, read and re-read simple and interesting stori es. Ask the child questions about what happens next , 
what the    dog’s name is etc. Encourage the child to act out stories and retell them to dad and sibli ng’s 
.Use puppets or dolls to tell story.

Find stories that appeal to the child’s interests A fter reading the story two or three times, re-read it 
again but before turning the page, ask the child wh at he thinks happened next.

Watch segments of the child’s favorite T.V. shows w ith him. At commercials or short intervals ask the 
child to tell you what happened. Aid him with verba l cues and questions if necessary.initially.

cards.title: Repeats finger plays with words and actions

Tasks.Action:
Examples “ Itsey-Bitsey spider,” “Pat-a-cake,” “Her e’s the church, Here’s the steeple,” “ 3 Little 
Monkeys” “Two little Black birds.” Say and do the e ntire finger play. Repeat one line of the words and  
motions. Have child repeat one line of the words an d motions. Have child repeat one part at a time 
after you then 2 lines, etc. until he can repeat en tire finger play.
Have him start by only doing the actions as you say  it. Then have him say and do actions.

Have the child say the rhyme with you, but leave of f the last word of each phrase for him to say by 
himself. Gradually leave off additional words. Prai se the child as he gains in skill.

Cue child by saying the first word of each line and  having child finish on his own or do the action fo r 
child as a cue for the words.

cards.title: Matches 1 to 1 (3 or more objects)

Tasks.Action:
Put 3 cups on table. Give child 3 marbles. Ask chil d to put one marble in each cup saying “ 1 marble 
for 1 cup,” etc.

Draw 3 bowls in a column along left edge of a paper . Draw 3 spoons in column along right edge of 
paper .Ask child to draw a line from 1 spoon to 1 b owl.

Put a red and blue pile of blocks in front of child . Take one block from each pile and say “ one red 
block-one blue block.” Have child imitate you.

Have child help with table setting .you put plates on and let child put one napkin, fork, etc.by each 
plate. Use play dishes if available.
Let child pass out cookies or a snack one item to e ach person.
Allow child to help you decorate cookies by putting  one M & M or one raisin on each before baking.

cards.title: Points to long and short objects

Tasks.Action: Collect long and short household items, i.e (s traw, pencils, rulers, spaghetti, socks).
Put a long and short straw before child. Ask him to  point to the long straw Praise success.
Use a chalkboard. Have child draw long and short li nes in imitation and on request.

Talk to the child about long and short items. Name items in the house as long and short before asking 
him to point to them.

Play a game with a long and short broom straw, toot hpick, or stick. Hide long and short items in 
separate hands behind back. Have child guess which hand contains short item. When he has guessed 
show him both hands. Have him point to the hand tha t has short item. Repeat with long item. Reward 
when correct.

cards.title: Tells which objects go together

Tasks.Action: Use household objects, i.e (cup and saucer, sock an d shoe, pencil and paper, hat and coat, etc.)

Put cup and saucer and sock and shoe on table in fr ont of child. Explain why pairs belong together. 
Model activity and ask child to imitate.

Name an object and ask child to think of another ob ject.that goes with it. (Example keychain-key, 
hairbrush-comb.)
Put assortment of objects that go together in front  of child. Have him put together in pairs.

While doing routine household tasks talk to the chi ld about the items you use and explain to him why 
they go together.

cards.title: Counts to 3 in imitation

Tasks.Action:
Count to 3 frequently during day as activities are happening i.e count dishes as you wash or dry them,  
count             towels as you fold them., count l etters that come in mail.Encourage child to imitate  
saying 1,2,
Have child imitate 1,2 and add numbers one at a tim e after child masters imitation task.

Place 3 objects in front of child and point to each  one as you count to three. Ask him to repeat after  
you-pointing and counting.
March with child counting to three. Ask him to coun t along with you.

cards.title: Arranges objects into categories

Tasks.Action:
Mix in box objects one would find in a kitchen and a bedroom. Take one object at a time and ask child 
if it belongs in the bedroom or in the kitchen.(Sug gested items : Bedroom-pillow,hanger,sock,dresser 
scarf, Kitchen- fork, napkin , spatula, pan.)
Use pictures of animals, clothing and furniture. As k child to arrange pictures in correct categories.
Ask child which objects would not be found in kitch en, “ table, fork, bed.”

Show child how objects are usually arranged in cate gories in grocery stores, department stores. While 
in store as you go down aisles ask him what group t he things belong in.

cards.title: Draws a V stroke in imitation

Tasks.Action:
Show the child what do making one line at a ti me , i.e  “Let’s make a line down-then a line up.” 
2 Let him trace over the lines you made and then have  him make a V on his own. 
3 Let him practice with his finger in sand or on the table, then give him a pencil. 
4 Let him connect the dots to form a V such as .* . * …and praise success.Reduce the clues by making the 
dots lighter.Reward each improvement with smiles an d praise. 
5 Use a V shaped template to help guide child as he d raws.

cards.title: Draws a diagonal line from corner to corner of 4 inch square of paper

Tasks.Action:
Dot line for child to trace. 2 Physically guide pencil stroke from corner to corne r of paper, lessening aid as child gains in skill. 
3 Place a sticker on opposite corners of paper and as k child to connect them with a line. 
4 Fold paper diagonally. Have child trace over crease .

cards.title: Counts to 10 objects in imitation

Tasks.Action:
Place 10 like objects (blocks, toys, candles) on th e table and one by one count them for the child. Co unt 
as you put away your dishes, take out forks, etc.

Count for the child and then have him count after y ou and then count together. Start by counting to 2 
or 3, then after the child can do this, continue wi th 4, then 5 and upto 10
Have the child count a variety of objects, such as blocks, toys, candy, animals in the field.

If you are counting objects with the child and he i s unsure of the next number give him the initial 
sound of the number, like “th” for three, “n” for n ine. Let him finish saying the number word.

Fade out the initial sound clue, by mouthing the in itial sound but not saying it loud. Gradually reduc e 
all clues and praise the child as he improves.

Read nursery rhymes or sing songs to child with cou nting including, i.e. Ten Little Indians, One, Two,  
Buckle My Shoe.

cards.title: Builds a bridge with 3 blocks in imitation

Tasks.Action:
Show the child what to do---place 2 blocks side by side and the third one on top of the other two.Leav e 
your       “ bridge” for the child to copy.

Hand him one block at a time, showing him where to place it,if necessary. Withdraw help as the child 
improves and reward the improvements. Build a  “gar age” for the pencil. The pencil  serves to hold 
the blocks apart at the bottom.

cards.title: Matches sequence or pattern of blocks or bea ds

Tasks.Action: Use a set of blocks with several different kinds of  shapes.

Make a tower or bridge explaining the extra details ,. Encourage the child to imitate and give physical  
help and simple instructions. Gradually withdraw he lp as the child learns the skill. Reward 
improvement with praise.
If the child has number concepts, encourage him to count the number of blocks needed.
Sit next to the child when doing this activity so h e can see the object from the same view as the mode l.
Put a treat at the end of the line of blocks or bea ds for child when he completes his model.

cards.title: Copies of series of connected V strokes VVVV VVV

Tasks.Action:
Draw a series of V strokes. Encourage the child to trace over the letter first with his finger and lat er with a 
crayon or pencil. Help by guiding his hand.
Have him draw with you making one line at a time.

Make a row of connected V strokes. Then have the ch ild draw more rows as you give him verbal direction s 
“up, down, up, down.”

Have child make a row of V strokes on paper. When h e finishes make it into a picture of mountains, gra ss, 
trees, etc. for him.

cards.title: Adds legs and / or arm to incomplete man

Tasks.Action:
Draw a stick man leaving out 2 obvious body parts, for instance, a leg and an arm.. Ask the child to f ind which 
body parts are missing. Ask him to draw in the miss ing parts.
Take turns with the child talking about and finding  body parts on yourself and the child.
Draw several pictures of a man, leaving out a diffe rent body part for the child to identify and comple te.

Begin by drawing just the face and leaving off the nose. Ask the child “What’s missing?” If he needs h elp in 
identifying the missing feature, ask him, “Does the  man have eyes?” “Does he have a mouth?” “Does he h ave 
a nose?” If necessary help him draw the nose by gui ding his hand to the correct place on the face. Dra w 
several faces each with a different part missing. P raise improvements and success. Tape finished produ ct to 
refrigerator so the rest of the family can see and praise the child’s efforts.

Position felt pieces on felt board to make a man. H ave child imitate you and talk with child about eac h part of 
body as it is being put on felt board.

cards.title: Completes 6 piece puzzle without trial and e rror

Tasks.Action: Glue small knobs on puzzle pieces for easier handli ng.

Take out one or two puzzle pieces to begin with. Le t child watch you remove the pieces from the puzzle Then you 
replace them, take them out again and hand them to the child, one at a time, for him to replace. When he can do 
this remove 3 pieces, then 4 and finally all the pu zzle pieces. Reward success with praise and smiles.

Guide the child’s hand to help him fit the pieces i n the holes, once he has chosen the correct hole. G ive simple 
instructions like,  “Turn it around, move it a litt le.”Withdraw help as the child gains in skill. Prai se improvement.

Give the child a puzzle piece. Tell him to look at the puzzle to find where it goes before he tries re placing it. This 
will help avoid trial and error placement. Praise s uccess.
Have child feel the shape of puzzle pieces before t hey are placed.

cards.title: Names long and short

Tasks.Action:
Use pencils, pipe cleaners, draw lines, or cut out different lengthed strips of paper or material. Poi nt to 
the long one and say, “ This is long,” then ask whi ch one is long. Repeat again and say, “ Which one i s 
long;”—this one. Then have the child point to the l ong one. Change the position of the objects ans ask s 
the child again to show you the long one. Do the sa me with short.

In the beginning use very long and very short lines  and then reduce the difference gradually as the 
child gains in skill.

Line up whatever items you are using so that both b egin in the same place-----------. Explain to the 
child that one is long and onr is short. When child  can do this, line up the items------------and have  the 
child tell you that one is long and one is short as  he points to themh.

Have child count for you to find out how far he can  already count. Then say the next two or three 
numbers and have child repeat. When child can count  that far add the next three until child can count 
to twenty.

Put twenty items in front of the child. Let child p oint to each item and count. When he makes a 
mistake or stops tell him the next number or the fi rst sound of next number and let him continue 
counting.
Have child count his steps as he walks upto 20 step s.

Use 20 Styrofoam bits, bottle caps, Popsicle sticks , marbles, etc. as counters. Ask child to give you 
desired amount. If incorrect amount is given, have child recount aloud with you until correct number 
is reached.
Start with highest number child consistently counts  to. Add one more at a time.
Deal child 20 cards from a card game. Have him coun t them and tell you how many.
Deal more than 20—have him count them and give you twenty.
Hide number cards I-10 in one room. Ask child to fi nd cards and name numeral on each card.
Cut thick sponge into cubes. Write numerals 1-10 on  sponge. Toss in air as die and name numerals.

Use numerals cut from sandpaper or cards with raise d numerals. Have child trace numerals with 
finger as he names them.

Use cards with indented numerals or templates. Have  child follow outline with pencil as he names 
them.

cards.title: Says letters of alphabet in order

Tasks.Action: Sing alphabet song with child and encourage him to join in. A record or tape of song may also be used.
Ask child to say as much of alphabet as he can. Giv e help when needed to finish saying it.

Teach the alphabet in parts. Let child say first fi ve letters and you finish the rest. As child learns  the 
letter let him say more until he says entire alphab et unaided.
Alternate saying letters with the child A-Z.

cards.title: Prints own first name

Tasks.Action:
Use name cards at dinner table. Encourage child to find his name and sit at proper place. Put child’s 
name on his bedroom door or bed.

Print one letter of child’s name at a time and have  him imitate. Dot out letters for child to child if  he 
has difficulty.

Write part of a child’s name (Mar--- or __ary). As child learns one letter then have him write 2, then  
3(---ary,----ry,-----y).

Print the letters of the child’s name on individual  index cards. Have child name them and put them in 
the proper order. At first let child match them to a model of his whole name. Remove model and let 
child “peek” at it only when he needs help.
Use model of his name and have child trace it. Then  have child print name directly below model.

cards.title: Names five letters of alphabet

Tasks.Action: Work with letters in child’s name or those he is fa miliar with.
Have child trace and copy letters as you name them.

Use letters that are very different (O, T, M, B, A) . Name them for child then hold them in your hand 
and let child take them one at a time and name them . If child doesn’t know letter, you say the name an d 
have him repeat it.

Print letters on index card. Hide them around the r oom. As the child finds them, have him bring them 
to you and name them. Hide the letters and when chi ld finds them you name them for him if he is 
unable to name them.
Encourage child to look for familiar letters such a s letters of his name on signs and in stores.

cards.title: Arranges objects in sequence of width and le ngth

Tasks.Action:
Cuts strips of paper into various widths and length s. Have child sequence in imitation; then without 
help.

Collect straws,rope, and books of different width.C ut string, paper strips, and shoe-string licorice i nto 
various lenghts.

Initially use items that each are one inch longer o r wider than the next. Begin with only three items.  
You put out the first one and have child put the ne xt two in place. Increase the number of items to 10 . 
You put out every other one and have child put the remaining ones in the appropriate spot. Then put 
out every third one, etc. until child can sequence all of them unaided.
Gradually reduce the difference in length or width  to ½ “

cards.title: Names capital letters of alphabet

Tasks.Action: Present letters to child in random order and peaise  him for naming correctly.
Child must be able to point to letters upon request  before he is asked to name letters.
Hide letters and ask child to name them as he finds  them.
Use letters made from sandpaper. Have child trace a s he names.

cards.title: Puts numerals 1 to 10 in proper sequence

Tasks.Action: Have child match number cards to a model set up in a sequence of 1-

Remove one number from 
sequence and ask child to position numbers once mor e. Continue removing numbers from model 
sequence until child is positioning numerals. 1-10 in correct sequence without a model.

Put out some numbers (1,2,6,8,9,10) and let child p ut in rest. Gradually reduce the number you put 
out until child sequences all of the numbers himsel f.

If child can name numbers have him count as he puts  out the numbers. When he has difficulty have 
him count as far as he is able   and then find the one that comes next.

cards.title: Names position of objects first, second, th ird

Tasks.Action: Have 3 children stand in a line. Ask who is first i n line, etc.

Use terms first, second, and third with daily activ ities. First, I put on my sock. Second, I put on my  
shoe. Third I tie my shoe.
Have child sequence 3 pictures and name them as bei ng first, second, or third.

When walking down sidewalk ask him to count first, second, and third house from where you are . 
h
Hold letter cards in your hand. Ask child to pick o ne at a time and to name the letter.

Use cards that have the capital letter on one side and lower case on the other. If child does not know  
letter turn card over to give clue.

Use cards that have upper and lower case letters on  same side. Go through these several times until 
child is aquainted with letters.

Draw L shape double lines ½” apart, have child draw  line between them. Gradually increase the 
number of corners and decrease the distance between  the two lines.

Draw pictures of people or animals at the beginning  point and a picture of their home at the end. Ask 
child to find the road for them to get home.

If child has trouble drawing between double lines, let him first drive a little car down the “ road” o r 
trace with his finger.

Give child three blocks. Have him count them. Take one away and say, “ I took one away, now how 
many do you have?” Have child count again and tell you the answer. Repeat procedure with different 
numbers of blocks.
Use same procedure with candy or cereal bits. Give 1, 2, or

Have him eat one and count again to see  
how many he has.
Give child 1 or 2 blocks. Have him count them..Then  give him 1 or 2 more and have him count again.

Use a number line.1       2        3 
.Let child use this to help him figure out the answ er when not using real 
objects.
Use real objects, but have the child try to tell yo u the answer before counting them to find the answe r.

Use picture stories of common daily activities. Sho w the child part of it( taking bath, brushing teeth ). 
Ask child to tell you what happens next. If he can’ t show him the next picture and let him tell you (g o 
to bed)

In daily activities, let child guess what one would  do next; put plug in bath tub. Then -------------- -. 
Allow him to carry through with the next step.

cards.title: Repeats sound made by others

Tasks.Action: Make sounds that go with game or physical activity i.e. pop beads "p/p/p/p"

Say a sound like "ah" and tells the child, say "ah" . Say it with him and reward the child with a goodi e of 
praise. "Good aaah" (repeating sound). Click tongue , clap hands, puff cheeks, blow breath.

Say various vowel sounds to the child. Say each one  several times and allow child time to repeat. Init ially 
reinforce any approximation of the sound.
Smile and make the activity enjoyable for the child . Pick up, hug, rock while doing activity.
Use vowel sounds and sounds made with the lips (p, b, m) which are the easiest to produce and are visi ble.

Initially choose sounds, which the child has made s pontaneously in his vocal play. Say these to him an d have 
him repeat them. When child can do this, begin to h ave him imitate sounds, which he does not produce 
spontaneously.

cards.title: Repeats sound made by others

Tasks.Action: Repeat sounds over and over, loudly and then softly  in the child's ear.
Repeat a sound associated with a game activity or t oy-like "choo, chee", "bang, bang","whee, whee".
After the child repeats the sound, praise him and r epeat the sound he made.

When the child repeats one sound, i.e. "ma," quickl y imitate, repeating the sound twice and encourage the 
child to say the sounds with you.

cards.title: Responds to gestures with gestures

Tasks.Action:
To teach the child to imitate your gestures, show t he child what to do by taking his hands and helping  him 
wave bye-bye, clap hands. Reduce the help as the ch ild gains in skill and praise him each time he imit ates, 
with or without help.
As you say "no-no" to the child, shake your head at  the same time.

Show the child how you do an activity, help him do the activity by moving his hands or body and tellin g him 
what to do. Show the child the activity again and e ncourage him to perform without physical help, but tell 
him what to do. Show him what to do and say "you do  it" (without telling him what to do or touching hi m)

Once the child can imitate these gestures, encourag e him to use them by waiting for hime to extend his  arms 
to you to be picked up, when you extend your arms.
When offering an object hold it out to him and let him respond by shaking head or reaching for it.

Show the child how to follow the direction and then  physically walk him through the activity. Say "Lis ten, 
ready,” before giving the direction. After the chil d performs the directed activity say, "Good, you ca me 
here."

Other activities might include: a. "Give me your hands" and hold out your hands. b. "Throw the ball " and model activity and hold ou t your arms to catch it. 
c  "Close the door" and point to door. d.  "Sit down" and point to chair. e.  "Get the -----" and point to object.

cards.title: Stops activity at least momentarily when tol d 'no" 75% of the time

Tasks.Action: Say the word "no!" firmly, and with feeling.
Remove his hands or child himself from the object, as you say "no."
Gently slap the child's hand, as you say "no."

Praise the child when he does respond to "no." Let him know your are pleased with him for following yo ur 
direction.

Have other family member's model for the child touc hing or doing something that requires a "no" from t he 
parent. When that family member responds to "no," t hen provide praise. This gives the child a behavior  that 
he can imitate, and allows him to preview the conse quences.

cards.title: Combines two different syllables in vocal pl ay

Tasks.Action:
Say series of two different syllables to the child.  Begin by repeating the same set (ba ka) times and 
encourage him to repeat it. Reinforce with praise, hugs goodies when the child does. As he becomes 
more proficient change your syllable paires for eac h trial. Initially reinforce any approximation of t he 
sound and gradually require closer approximations f rom the child.
Combine the above activity with play activities suc h as toy noisemakers or physical activities.

Listen to the child's vocalizations as you're chang ing diapers or while he's in the crib, play pen, or  infant 
seat. When the child does combine different syllabl es, be sure to reinforce the behavior by praising, 
touching and repeating the syllables immediately af ter they are said.

Use 3,4 familiar objects (milk, water. Clothing, to y) Name them. Ask child to name them when your poin t to 
them. Hide objects in the room and have him find th em and name the object he's found. Accept 
approximationss of the word.
Clearly name items in daily care, i.e. milk, shirt,  shoe, cookie.
Name body parts : eye, nose, toes, teeth, etc. Have  child point to them and ask the child to name them .

As he is able to name the item in structured situat ions begin to require him to use the word to ask fo r the item. 
When he reaches for the item say the word and have him repeat it after you.

Use small toys that can be manipulated and moved ab out. Hide the object and bring it out. You say the name 
of the object. Repeat this action and allow time fo r child to say the name of the item.

Choose 3,4 items the child likes. Put them out of t he child's sight. Bring them out one at a time. Let  the child 
play with an item briefly. Then bring out another o ne and say" look, a ------". Name the item for him.  
Continue this procedure switching items frequently to see if the child will name the items when they a re 
presented again after you have named them several t imes for him.

cards.title: Vocalizes in response to speech of other per son

Tasks.Action:
Talk to the child as you carry out daily activities  - name objects, food, clothing. Name activities ca rried out 
by yourself and the child.
Look at objects and picture books. Ask the child to  show you objects and pictures. Read to the child.
Ask the child to tell what has happened- "Go bye,'" play ball."
Say "Hi" and "Bye" to the child when going in and o ut of sight.

While playing with the child reinforce the sounds h e makes by making more sounds and vocalizing back t o 
him.

cards.title: Asks for "more"

Tasks.Action:
When the child indicates that he wants more of some thing say the word "more" and have him repeat it be fore 
giving it to him. Discontinue modeling the word whe n the child begins to use the word himself.

Use toys that the child enjoys like blocks, bubbles , small animals, etc. Give him only a small number and 
have him ask for "more" before giving them to him i n activities like stacking blocks or blowing bubble s.

Use physical activities like swinging,  "horsey rid e", etc. Stop activity and require the child to ask  for "more" 
before beginning again.

Once the child uses "more" in his spontaneous speec h encourage him to combine "more" with another word . 
For example "more milk","more ball","more swing." W hen the child says "more" expand his utterance by 
saying "more milk" or whatever he wants and have hi m repeat it. Gradually reduce your help by asking 
"more what?" until the child spontaneously combines  "more" with other words.

cards.title: Follows 3 different one step directions with out gestures

Tasks.Action: Play a game using directions, i.e. rolling ball, ma rching, pointing, raising arms, etc.

Play "Simon says" game (Simon says, "Sit down, stan d up, come here, give me.") Show the child how to d o 
the activity, giving physical help if necessary.

Combine gestures with verbal directions, for instan ce, pointing to a chair and saying, "sit down." Pra ise the 
child when he follows the direction. Gradually redu ce the number of gestures given and continue to pra ise 
success.

As the child is able to carry out these simple dire ctions in structured situations, begin to give him similar 
directions involving his daily activities. For exam ple,"get your shoes." Initially you may have to tak e the 
child and help him get the shoes. As you continue m aking the request over several days allow the child  and 
help him get the shoes. As you continue making the request over several days allow the child time to i nitiate 
and carry out the activity before helping. Praise h im for completing the activity when he does.

Choose a set of 5 or 6 directions and only use thes e commands with him at first. As he becomes profici ent 
with these add one or two new ones.

cards.title: Can "give me" or "show me" upon request

Tasks.Action:
Choose 3 or 4 objects that you are sure the child k nows the name of. 
a:  Put out only one of the objects at a time in fo rnt of the child. Say "show or give me the -----." Then take 
the child's hand and physically guide him in pickin g up and showing or giving you the object. Praise h im. 
Continue until the child initiates the activity him self when you make the request. 
b:  Next put out 2 or 3 of the items at a time and ask him to give or show you each of the items. Rewa rd him 
with praise or a goodie when he does so.

Choose the child's favorite items to teach the skil l. Reward him for "showing" or "giving" by allowing  some 
time to explore or play with the item.

Use preferred food items that the child knows the n ame of. Ask him to show you the sucker for instance . 
When he does show you the sucker allow him to have a lick. Be careful that the child is learning "show " or 
"give" and is not confusing it with the eating of t he item. After the child shows you the item, say "g ood, you 
showed  (gave) me the -------. Now you may eat (lic k) it."

cards.title: Points to 12 familiar objects when named

Tasks.Action: Begin with just 3 or 4 familiar objects and ask the  child to "Pick up the spoon," or "Give me the ball ."
Ask the child to bring you familiar items within hi s room like blanket, teddy bear, or ball.
Use picture books, magazines, and catalogs. Ask the  chld to point to common objects.
When in a store have the child help you pick out it ems like "Bring me the milk, bring me the candy."

When walking outside talk to the child about what h e sees and then have the child find a tree, some st ones, 
flowers, etc.

Be sure to name everyday objects that the child has  contact with using simple sentences. Then after yo u name 
an object and point imitating you.

cards.title: Points to 3 -5 pictures in a book when named

Tasks.Action:
Begin with pictures of familiar objects. Use simple  books where there is only one picture on a page.  
      Then use of pictures of two objects on a page  for the child to choose between. Praise success.
Use toy catalog, old magazines and make a scra pbook of familiar objects.
Read nursery rhymes to the child which include fami liar objects.

If the child point to objects without difficulty bu t has problems pointing to pictures of the same obj ects, tape 
the picture to the object itself. For instance, tap ing a picture of an apple to a real apple may help him make the 
association.

To aid the child in going from pointing to three di mensional objects to pointing to single dimensional  
picutres, taping the object, if it's small to a pie ce of paper may help, i.e. taping a cookie to a pie ce of paper.
Take photographs of real objects in the child's env ironment aand use these.

cards.title: Points to 3 body parts on self

Tasks.Action:
Ask "Where is your ----------?" Take the child's ha nd and place it on the body part. Ex. Nose. Say, "T his is 
your nose." Say "Good, that's your nose." Ask again  "Where is your nose?" Gradually withdraw the physi cal 
and aid until the child points to the body part on request.

Have the child point to parts on mama. "Where's mam a's nose? " When child carries out activity, say, " Good, 
that's a nose?"  (Repeat the word.)

Use a mirror and stand next to the child. First hav e him imitate your movements as you name the body p arts 
for him to touch it.

Work on one body part at a time and add additional body partws only after he consistently knows the on es 
you've taught previously.

Name the body parts as you're bathing the child, th is will help him become familiar with the words and  their 
meaning.

cards.title: Says his own name or nickname upon request

Tasks.Action: Use photo or mirror-and asks, “Who is this?” Then tell the child his name and have him repeat it.
Name several names and when the child hears his ow n name he could clap hands or stand up.

Ask the child-“What is your name?” Point to him or  tap his chest gently. Say “Your name is ______.” 
Gradually withdraw help by telling him his name in a whisper or by saying the beginning letter of his 
name. Let him finish by saying his name.
When child says his name-say “Good Joe!” repeating the child’s name.

Be sure the nickname assigned to the child is one that you would be comfortable calling him when he i s 
older, and intermittently call him by given name as  well.
Use the child’s name frequently when giving direct ions, asking questions and in general conversation.

cards.title: Answers question "what's this?" with object name

Tasks.Action:
Use several familiar objects that you are sure the child knows the names of. Hold up the item and ask,  
"What's this?" Give the child time to answer. If he  does not, say the word for him and have him repeat  it. 
Continue until child begins to give answer himself.
Page through picture book, point to object and ask,  "What's this?"
Reinforce the child for naming correctly by repeati ng the name again after him and by praising.

cards.title: Names 5 other family members including pets

Tasks.Action:
Be sure to use each family member's name often so t he child will hear the names frequently. Encourage the 
child to distinguish between family members. "Give the ball to Sue." "Give a spoon to Johnny."

Have the family members stand in a row. Everydtime the child names one correctly they can throw a ball  to 
him.
Have the family members ask the child their names.

A good time to do these activities is during meal t ime when there are many opportunities for hearing n ames 
of family members and then saying them

cards.title: Names 4 toys

Tasks.Action:
Ask the child to pick up the toys, you name them fi rst and have him name them as he puts them in his t oy 
box.

Play a game of looking for the toys, and have the c hild search for the named toy, naming it. Ex. "I se e the 
ball."
Ask child to name the wanted toy before he can have  it to play with.

When you see the child playing with a toy he's sele cted, ask him wwhat he's playing with and reinforce  his 
naming by repeating it ---"good, that is a doll."
Be sure to name any new toys that the child gets.

cards.title: Asks for some common food items by name whe n shown  (milk, cookie, cracker)

Tasks.Action: Have the child name the food before it is placed on  his plate.
Say the name of the food,"This is ----------." Ask,  "What is this?""That's right, you can eat ------."

Find tand cut out pictures of familiar foods from m agazines for the child to name; let him match these  food 
pictures to the food he is eating.

When the child indicates he wants a snack, hold the  item out to him and name it for him. The child sho uld at 
least approximate the word before giving it to him.
At meal times serve the child very small portions s o he will have to ask for more.

Initially model the food name for him and have him repeat. As he becomes proficient at this level begi n to 
require him to say the name before you give him the  food item.

cards.title:
Asks questions by a rising intonation at en d of word or 
phrase

Tasks.Action:
Model one and two word questions for the child and exaggerate the rising intonation at the end of the 
word or on the last word. Point to some objects and  ask "ball?" or "Jimmy's ball?" Ask the child to re peat 
your words. Praise and reward him when he does. If the child does not respond, repeat the word/phrase 
several times.

When the child makes a request with one or two word s that you can tell is actually question (example 
"milk"when he wants milk) say the word back to him with rising intonation. Then tell him to say it lik e 
you did. Require at lesst an approximation before g iving the child the item. Praise his attempts.

Respond to rising intonation, even if said as a sin gle word as though a question were being asked. For  
instance, if the child holds up a ball and says bal l with a rising intonation, respond by saying, "Rig ht, that 
is a ball."

cards.title: Names 3 body parts on a doll or other person

Tasks.Action:
Begin by asking, "Where's the doll's nose?" When th e child points to the named part - encourage him to  name 
it by asking. "What is that?" as you touch the part . Praise all correct answers.

Let the child wash the doll in a sink. You name the  body parts for him to wash. When he can touch each  part 
named consistently, then you wash the doll having h im name the body parts as you do this.

If the child is having difficulty, Give him an addi tional clue that involllves a specific action to pe rform using 
the body part named. For instance, ask him to "Kick  the ball with your foot.""Shake hands,""close your  eyes," 
etc. When he can perform these movements, you do th e activities and say to the child, "I kicked the ba ll with 
my -------------," letting him name the body part u sed.
Alternately ask the child to point to his nose, eye , etc. and point to my nose, eye, etc

cards.title: Answers yes/no question with affirmative or negative reply

Tasks.Action:
Model asking and answering yes/no questions with an other adult in front of the child. Use questions ab out 
common people and experiences in the child's words (Is this a cup, child's name, etc. Are you hungry, tired 
etc.)

Ask the child simple questions related to his daily  experiences and needs. Model the answer either "Ye s"or 
"'No" and accompany it with shaking your head. Acce pt head shaking as an answer from the child.

When the child can do this appropriately in imitati on of you, stop modeling the aanswer for him. Ask h im 
questions during play like "do you want the ball?" Don't give it to him until he shakes his head or sa ys yes or 
no.

At meal times or when offering the child a snack as k him "do you want -----?" Wait until the child ans wers 
before giving or witholding the item. Be sure you a sk only questions about things you want the child t o have 
a choice in.

cards.title: Combines noun or adjective and noun in two w ord phrase (ball chair) (my ball)

Tasks.Action:
When the child says a single word like "ball" you c ombine another word with it and say it back to the child 
like "big ball, ball on chair." Encourage the child  to say the words together.

If the child says "more," "all gone," and his name,  try to have him combine these words with others in  the 
same manner as above.

When the child says these two words he may really m ean more than what he has said. "Ball chair" could 
mean the "ball is on the dhair" or "put the ball on  the chair." When the child does say the towo words  together 
expand what he has said, but do not require him to repeat it. For example, if the child says "milk cup " and 
points to his cup say "oh, you want milk in the cup ,""yes, there is milk in the cup" or whatever it is  you think 
the child ment by what he said.
Be sure to use simple sentences with the child when  conversing; use words you know the child understan ds.

cards.title: Combines noun and verb in two word phrase (d addy go)

Tasks.Action:
Say what the child is doing in daily activities-beg in with 2-3 word phrases. "Bobby eat,""Eat dinner" or 
"Bobby eat dinner."

Do activities as a game - comb hair, shut doorr, wa sh hands, kick ball, ask "What am I doing, what are  you 
doing?"
Begin to look at simple action pictures or draw sti ck pictures ask, "What is he doing?" or "What happe ned?"

Use events or experiences that happen during the da y naming them for the child using two word phrases and 
encourage and reinforce the child for imitating.

cards.title: Combines verb or noun with "there""here"in  2 word utterance (chair here)

Tasks.Action:
When the child uses one or two words and points to the object in either making a statement or asking a  
question say "here's the_____" or "there's the ____ __." Then ask, "Can you say it?" "Here _____." Prai se 
when he does.

Play a game with the child by hiding some of his pr eferred small toys or puppets and ask "where's ___"  pull it 
out and say "where's____?" Wait for the child to an swer. If he does not, you say "here/there ____" and  ask 
him to repeat it. Praise when he repeats or says it  on his own.

cards.title: Combines 2 words to express possession (dadd y car)

Tasks.Action:
Choose items that the child can readily recognize a s belonging to a particular family member. Tell the       
child "mommy's dress," "daddy's shoe" etc. Then poi nt to the item and ask "whose___(shoe) ___?" When the 
child says "daddy____ shoe   ___ " praise him. Do not expect the child to add the "s ". If he does not answer 
tell him again "daddy's shoe" and ask him to repeat .

Have two or more family members sit with the child.  Begin by naming items of clothing and say "mama's 
nose" or mama's shoe" or daddy's eye." After modeli ng these several times point and give the child the  
opportunity to tell you "mama’s nose" etc. If the c hild does not respond when you say the phrase and h ave 
him repeat. Praise or reward with goodie when he do es say the desired two words.

cards.title: Uses "no" or "not" in speech

Tasks.Action:
When the child shakes his head to indicate a negati ve response, shake your head and say "no". Then hav e 
the child repeat the word. Gradually withdraw aid b y saying to him "tell me" when he only shakes his 
head.

Hold up various objects and name them for the child . Then remove them from his vision and say "no----- - 
." Have the child repeat the phrase. Asfter modelin g this several times hide the object and let the ch ild say 
"no-----." If he does not say it, have him repeat i t after you.

Point to various objects or body parts and name the m as "not ------." For instance, point to your eye and 
say, "not nose" or point to a cup and say "not fork ". Then point to another object or body parts and a sk the 
child "hand?" If he does not respond say, "not hand " and have him repeat. Give the child the opportuni ty to 
say it ands encourage him to do so before you tell him.
Continue activities like this until the child begin s to usse "no" and "not"in his spontaneous speech.

cards.title: Answers question "what's ------doing?" for c ommon activities

Tasks.Action:
Name common activities occurring in the home for th e child. Describe what you are doing during the day  
to him such as eating, cooking, baking, sweeping, c ombing, swinging, riding, jumping, running, sleepin g.

Begin to ask the child "what am I doing, what are y ou doing?" If the child doesn't answer tell him the  
name of the activity. Do not expect the child to pu t the "ing" ending on the word but only to give the  basic 
verb form like run, jump.etc.
Look at pictures in books and ask him to tell you w hat the people are doing.

cards.title: Answers "where" questions

Tasks.Action:
Choose several containers such as box, cup and dish , and a small object. Tell the child to watch you a s you 
drop the object into vaarious containers. Then ask"  where's the --------" and have the child tell you.

When family members leave the house or room to go v arious places tell the child where they went. Then 
ask, "where's --------(daddy)?" and have the child answer.

Place several objects around the room so that the c hild can see them. Ask him, "where's the -------?" Have 
him first tell you and then retrieve the object.

cards.title: Names familiar environmental sounds

Tasks.Action:
Upon hearing a sound ask the child. "What is that?"  Then take the child to the source and discover wha t 
the sound was. Name the object or animal that made the sound.
Make familiar sounds and ask the child to name them .
Make a tape of sounds and have the child match pict ures of objects to the sounds.

cards.title: Gives more than one object when asked using plural form (blocks)

Tasks.Action:
Put out groups of several small objects. Ask child alternately for ball/balls, block/blocks, cup/cups.  Praise 
when corect. If not correct show him one item and s ay "block," then several and say "blocks" exaggerat ing 
the 's'.

Use pictures of a single item and a group of the sa me items. Ask the child to alternately show you the  
singular and plural form.

Mealtime provides a good opportunity for pointing o ut singular and plural objects. For example, "Mommy  
has one napkin but lots of napkins are on the table ."

cards.title: Refers to self by own name in speech

Tasks.Action: *Do not teach if the child is already using pronoun s "I, me, mine" to refer to himself

When the child asks for items by saying "want-----( cookie)----  ." Say to him "------(name)-----  wants ---(a 
cookie)------ and have him tell you.

Ask "who wants a --------" in response to his reque sts. Encourage him to tell you his name and say it with 
the rest of the phrase.

When dressing the child ask him "whose---- (shirt)- --- is this?" Have him respond with his name or his  
name and the rest of the phrase.
Use the child's favorite possessions and ask him wh ose (toy, blanket, etc.)

Stand in front of a mirror with the child, point to  and name yourself, then have the child point to an d name 
himself.

cards.title: Points to picture of common object described  by its use (10)

Tasks.Action: You name an object and have the child name its use.

Play a game of showing an activity such as brushing  teeth, washing hands, sweeping floor and have the 
child guess what you're doing.

Place several items such as a ball, a spoon, a cup,  soap, etc. on a table. Ask the child find the obje ct you 
eat with, bounce, drink from, etc.  When he can do this consistently you point to the objects and ask him 
what to do with each. Praise the child as he learns  to associate the object with its use.

Cut out pictures of common objects like cup, ball, hat, and others familiar to the child and paste the m on 
paper. Name a function or use and have the child po int to the correct picture. Praise all correct resp onses 
and help him correct errors.

cards.title: Holds up fingers to tell age

Tasks.Action:
First show the child -say" You are 3 years old" the n you hold up the correct number of fingers and cou nt 
them, have him imitate you or help him hold up the correct number of fingers. Gradually withdraw the 
help, then let the child show you how old he is by himself. Praise success.

Sometimes it's easier to begin with if the child us es both hands holding up two fingers on one hand an d 
one on the other.
It may be easier to teach the child to hold down un needed fingers with the other hand.

Once the child can do this, ask his age fairly ofte n to give him the chance to practice and be sure to  help 
him "update" on his next birthday.

cards.title: Points to picture of common object described  by its use (10)

Tasks.Action: You name an object and have the child name its use.

Play a game of showing an activity such as brushing  teeth, washing hands, sweeping floor and have the child 
guess what you're doing.

Place several items such as a ball, a spoon, a cup,  ssoap, etc. on a table. Ask the child find the obj ect you eat 
with, bounce, drink from, etc.  When he can do this  consistently you point to the objects and ask him what to 
do with each. Praise the child as he learns to asso ciate the object with its use.

Cut out pictures of common objects like cup, ball, hat, and others familiar to the child and paste the m on 
paper. Name a function or use and have the child po int to the correct picture. Praise all correct resp onses and 
help him correct errors.

cards.title: Holds up fingers to tell age

Tasks.Action:
First show the child -say" Your are 3 years old" th en you hold up the correct number of fingers and co unt 
them, have him imitate you or help him hold up the correct number of fingers. Gradually withdraw the h elp, 
then let the child show you how old he is by himsel f. Praise success.

Sometimes it's easier to begin with if the child us es both hands holding up two fingers on one hand an d one 
on the other.
It may be easier to teach the child to hold down un needed fingers with the other hand.

Once the child can do this, assk his age fairly oft en to give him the chance to practice and be sure t o help him 
"update" on his next birthday.

cards.title: Tells sex when asked

Tasks.Action: Provide appropriate toys and clothes to play with a nd wear.
Tell the child he is a boy like daddy or girl like mama. Then ask the child if he is a boy or girl.
Say things to the child such as you're a nice boy w ho can run fast, or you're a pretty girl in that dr ess.

Dinnertime is a good opportunity to provide some mo deling for the child by asking other family members  
name themselves as boy or girl.

Be sure to revrse the order when asking the child i f he/she is a boy or girl, otherwise the child may repeat the 
last word heard.

cards.title: Carries out a series of two related comands

Tasks.Action:
Make a game of carrying out simple comands. Begin w ith one direction and then add another. If child do es 
not carry out the directions, then go through it wi th him by physically helping him. Praise him as you  do this 
together.
Having the child repeat the directions given to him  before he begins doing them may help him remember.

To increase the child's abillity to remember things  in order, use clues such as "first drink your milk , then wipe 
your mouth." Later omit "first"and "then" and just give the requests.

Other activities:  
a.  Put the ball on the floor and kick the ball. 
b. Drink the milk and put your cup on the counter.  
c. Go to the window and tell me something you see outs ide.

cards.title: Uses "ing" verb form (running)

Tasks.Action:
Use activities you are presently doing or demonstra te some action for the child. Tell him your (look) ing and 
emphasize the "ing" ending. Then ask the child to t ell what you are doing or he is doing. If he does n ot put the 
"ing" on the end say "------ing, you say it, ------ ing".
Use the same procedure with pictured action.

Continue until child begins to use "ing" on the end  of verbs, which describes action-taking place in t he 
present.

cards.title: Uses regular plural forms (book/books)

Tasks.Action:
Show the child a block. Ask what he sees. Show him another block. Ask what he sees."2"blocks. "Yes, th ere 
are 2 blocks here-good." Here is a block (point to it) and here are 2 blocks. (While pointing to them)

Hold up 1 finger and say, "I see one finger," then hold up 3 fingers and say, "I see 3 fingers." Use a  variety of 
objects when doing this activity.

Whenever you see 2 or more of something mention it to the child, such as if you're riding in a car you  can see, 
houses, cars, cows, trees.
Slightly emphasize the /s/ sound at the end of word s.

Use groups of objects such as 2-4 blocks, balls, cu ps, forks, etc. Mix them up and ask the child to gi ve you a 
ball, balls, etc.

cards.title: Uses some irregular past tense forms consis tently (went, did, was)

Tasks.Action: The three verbs listed above are very commonly used . Model these past tenses for the child in your spe ech.

Set up situations so that the child observes an act ivity like someone leaving. Then tell him "went 
 to school 
""went to work". Then ask the child the question "where did he go" a nd have him tell you "went  ---------------- 
----". If he does not, have him repeat it after you . Set up similar activities using did and was.

Have family members sit in circle and each takes tu rns answering questions of who did, who was, who we nt 
by saying "I went to the store?" When interrogator asks "Who went to the store?" let child be last and  have 
him imitate response.

cards.title: Ask's question, "What's this  (that)?"

Tasks.Action: Model both the asking and answering of the question  for the child with an adult or older child.

Make a game of identifying objects in the room, ani mal to the sound made by the animal, objects hidden  in a 
sack by taking turns and asking, "What is this?"
Ask questions of the child such as, "What is this" as you point to a body part or to an object that is  his.

Place objects out on the table, cover them up, and let the child say, “What’s this” and remove the cov er and 
name the object.

cards.title: Controls voice vollume 90% of the time

Tasks.Action:
Play games using big differences in your voice so t hat the child listens to and notices changes of lou dness, 
softness, etc.

Read an exciting story to the child using expressio ns. Ask the child to tell you that part of the stor y again 
using the intonations you used.

Name the loud speech "outside voice" and the quiet speech "inside voice". Go indoors and outdoors and use 
the appropriate voice level and have the child do s o also.
Whisper "secrets" to the child and make a game of h aving him whisper to you, too.

Show pictures to the child or set up situations whe re loud and quiet voices are appropriate. Have him sort the 
pictures into piles for quiet or loud situations. I f using real situation have the child show you what  kind of 
volume he would use in that situation

cards.title: Uses " this" and "that" in speech

Tasks.Action:
Choose several objects that you are sure the child knows the name of. Put 2 at a time out and ask him "which 
one ----." If he only points to one say "this one" or "that one." Praise and reward him when he repeat s. 
Gradually require him to say the phrase without a m odel to be reinforced.

Give the child choices such as, which cup do you wa nt, which shirt, toy, food, etc. Require him to tel l you 
"this one" or "that one" before continuing with act ivity.
Continue with similar activities until the child sp ontaneously uses "this" and "that" in his speech.

cards.title: Uses "is" in statements (this is ball)

Tasks.Action:
Use a variety of objects and name them for the chil d using phrases like "ball is mine""dog is sleeping " and so 
on. Give the child objects and have him use similar  phrases with "is" to tell you about it. If he can' t tell you, say 
it, and have repeat.

Use toys such as farms, house, play village, boatho use that have several small items available. Play w ith the 
child and comment with statements containing "is" o n the activity you are doing. For example putting g irl in a 
chair and saying "girl is in chair." Give the child  one toy at a time and let him do something with it  and 
comment. Model and have hime repeat and expand what  he says. If child says, "is in chair" you say, "ri ght, the 
boy is in the chair."

It will be helpful, when modeling, to accentuate "i s" in your speech. This will help draw the child's attention to 
the word and its usage.

cards.title: Says "I, me, mine" rather than own name

Tasks.Action: Ask the child questions - Whose toy? Bed? Clothing?  Etc. Who wants a cookie?
Use your own keys, clothing with "mine." Point out,  "this hat is mine,""this shoe is mine."
Take turns handing items to one another, saying "gi ve it to me."

Play a game using "you," such as "you go to the doo r,""you hand it to me,"etc. when first doing this y ou 
might point to the person as you say "you." Then ha ve the child give you requests using the pronouns.
Listen to the child as he's talking and praise him when he uses these pronouns.

When modeling for the child, emphasize the pronouns  as you use them to draw the child's attention to t he 
words.

cards.title: Points to object that "is not -----"(is not a ball)

Tasks.Action:
Choose several items the child knows the name of. P ut one item out at a time and tell him "not-----". Then put 
two out and ask him to point to "not a -------". Pr aise and reward him when he does.

When you are doing something and the child is watch ing, use "not" in your speech. If baking, doing lau ndry, 
etc. say things like "where's the cup?" Pick up ano ther item and say, "that’s not a cup". Put it down and pick it 
down and pick up the cup and say, "this is the cup" .

cards.title: Answer's "who" question with name

Tasks.Action: Model asking and answering "who" questions with ano ther adult or older child while the child observes.

Use picture books such as "The Best Word Book Ever 
".  Ask the child "who's driving the car," etc. He can  
answer "the bear" or other animal name.

Use actual situations during the day and ask the ch ild "who is ------" naming the activity. Praise the  child 
when he tells you.

cards.title: Uses possessive form of nouns (daddy's )

Tasks.Action:
Use pictures of animals with objects or people he k nows. Point to the object or an item of clothing an d ask 
"whose -----?" Have the child answer using -------' s.
Point to various body parts and have the child name  them as ------ 's nose, etc.

Play a game with several children. Give each a few items. Point to one child's object and ask "whose - ------". 
Have another child answer by using "(_Mary's)  ______".

cards.title: Uses articles: the, a in speech

Tasks.Action:
Use the articles, the, and, a, in a short sentence for the child to repeat or say with you. Ask what i s this? Then 
say, "This is a 
toy or a book." Point to different objects and say, "This i s the  table, or the table is brown." After 
you've done this for a while, arrrange questions so  the child can use the  and a by himself, such as, "What color 
is the  sky, grass, sun?"

Point to objects, saying the table, the chair, the apple and let the child take turns pointing to and naming 
objects.

cards.title: Uses some class names (toy, animal, food)

Tasks.Action:
Mix up the pictures or items in various categories and ask the child to give you all the animals or fo od, etc. If 
he doesn't find all of them say "I see another ____ _____" and have him fing it.
Give the child choices. Ask him "is this an animal or food?" when you hold up the item or picture.

Use pictures, items, or toy objects, several from e ach class. Name each item saying "dog is an animal, " "bread 
is food" to demonstrate for the child. Then hold up  each item and have the child tell you if it is foo d, toy or 
animal.

cards.title: Says "can" and "will" occasionally

Tasks.Action:
Use "can" and "will" in your speech when talking to  the child to express future events and ability to do an 
activity.
As situations arise ask the child if he "can" or "w ill" do things, then have him tell you.

Put out pictures for the child and ask questions li ke "who can bark?" Have the child answer "dog can b ark." 
Use pictures of animals, people. Etc.

Tell the child about activities to occur in the nex t hour or two. Tell him "we will go to the store." Later ask 
him about the event like "who will go""where will g o" and have the child answer.
Listen to the child's spontaneous speech and praise  him when uses the words on his own.

cards.title: Describes items an open  or closed

Tasks.Action:
Use items such as jars, boxes, doors, and drawers. Demonstrate and name open and closed for the child with 
each item.

Open or close the items and ask the child "Is it op en or closed?" Praise the child when he is correct.  If 
incorrect say the answer and have him repeat.

Tell him to open or close the different objects. Pr aise when he is correct. Use two of each of the ite ms (one 
open, one closed) so he makes a discrimination to c omplete the request.

Play a game hiding a small item or treat in contain er. Have him tell you to open or close the various containers 
as he instructs you to fing the item. Let him have the treat as a reward when he has instructed you to  open the 
correct container.
Look for situations during the day and let the chil d tell you to open or close different things.

cards.title: Says "is" at beginning of questions when app ropriate

Tasks.Action:
When child indicates by rising intonation that he i s asking a question, but does not change word order , model 
the question form for him. If child asks, "daddy is  home?" you "Is daddy home? Yes, daddy is home." Ha ve 
him repeat after you.

With group of children or family members take turns  modeling and asking questions. For example, give e ach 
person several objects and ask, "Is this a ball?"

cards.title: Will attend for five minutes while story i s read

Tasks.Action:
Read a simple and interesting story to the child. E xplain the pictures to him. Ask him to describe wha t he sees 
in the pictures.
Ask simple questions about the story to find out if  he really did listen.
Give the child the questions you will ask before yo u start the story.

Read to the child daily and at the same general tim e each day. Make this a fun and relaxing time for b oth of 
you - and let him choose the story.

If child is unwilling to attend, use a kitchen time r and set it for a minute or two. If the child atte nds to the 
story until the bell rings, reinforce the child wit h praise and a treat. Very gradually, increase the amount of 
time the child is required to attend before receivi ng the reinforcer.

cards.title: Carries out series of two unrelated comands

Tasks.Action:
Give the child simple directions concerning objects  or ideas that he is very familiar with, such as "b ring your 
book to me and close the toy box," or "get the ball  and close the door." Reward the child with praise or a treat 
for following directions. If child does not carry o ut directions go through the activities with him pr aising him 
as you help him follow through.
Start with one direction and when the child is able  to carry out one direction, add a second direction .

Tell the child you want him to listen carefully and  do what you say just the way you say it. Make the 
activities fun and include hopping and jumping.
Have the child say what he's to do before doing it.

cards.title: Tells full name when requested

Tasks.Action:
Ask the child, "What's your name?" "What's your nam e, Bill?" "What's your whole name - Bill F---- What 's 
your name? Bill Fi--- What's your whole name? Bill?  Bill Who? Bill Fish--? Oh, Bill Fisher!

Take turns naming the family by using both names, s uch as "My name is Joe Jones, My name is Jane Jones , 
what is your name?" etc.
Call the child by his full name when talking with h im.

cards.title: Answers simple "how" questions

Tasks.Action:
When carrying out common daily activities ask the c hild questions such as "how will we get to the stor e, how 
will we open the door," etc. If child does not answ er, or uses gestures, say the answer for him. Child  should 
answer in 2 to 4 words.
Gradually increase the difficulty of questions aske d. Use examples that are less common.

Use stories with pictures. As you read story stop a t various points and ask questions like "how did __ _____ or 
how will _________?" Give the child cues by pointin g to the picture that shows the answer. Gradually 
withdraw the aid of pictures and have child answer independently.

cards.title: Uses regular past tense forms (jumped)

Tasks.Action:
Use regular past tense forms in your speech to the child when describing action that has already occur red. 
Slightly emphasize the "ed" ending.

Use words like jump, kick, hop. Have the child perf orm the action or you do it. Ask him to tell you wh at 
you/he did. If he doesn't use the "ed" ending say i t again and have him repeat it.

Plan some activity like going to park, store, on a walk. When you return have the child talk about wha t you 
did using past tense forms. Praise when correct. Mo del correct word for him if he is not correct.
