Use puppets to demonstrate activity and have child describe the activity afterward.

cards.title: Tells about immediate experiences

Tasks.Action:
While child is busy doing something, ask him what h e's doing. Then ask him what he just did, after he has 
finished.

If child is watching you or other family member do something, wait until they've finished and ask chil d what 
they were doing. Praise him if correct. If not corr ect, give child clues. For example, if Daddy was re ading a 
book, ask child, "What was Daddy doing with the boo k?"
If child has just watched a television program, ask  him to tell you about what happened.

cards.title: Tells how common objects are used

Tasks.Action: Show the child an object (hammer, ball, thread, sci ssors, etc.) and ask, "What do we do with this?"
Using the same procedure, present pictures instead of object.

If the child does not know the answer, tell it to h im. Then ask the question again. "What do we do wit h this?" 
a.  We cook on a stove, what do we do on a stove? We co ok on it. 
b.  What do we do with a car, cup, pencil, and chair?
Talk to the child as you carry out daily activities  naming what you're doing with specific objects.

As the child goes about his daily activities ask wh at he's doing with objects and be sure to praise ap propriate 
answers.

cards.title: Expresses future occurrences with "going to ," "have to," "want to "

Tasks.Action:
Use these words in your speech to the child. Five t o ten minutes berfore carrying out an activity tell  him "we 
are going to take a bath, go to the store," etc. Ju st before carrying out the activity ask the child t o tell you 
what's going to happen. If he uses the words, prais e. If he doesn't model the appropriate sentence for  him.
Use the same procedure with puppets or stories fami liar to the child.
Use a toy such as a jack-in-the-box and have child tell you what it's going to do.

When child indicates that he wants to do something,  model the phrase by saying, "you want to (go outsi de)." 
 
Require the child to either use the phrase or repea t it after you before allowing him to do or have th e desired 
item or activity.

cards.title: Changes word order appropriately to ask que stions (Can I, Does he)

Tasks.Action:
When child asks question by using regular sentence form with question intonation (I go to store?) Mode l the 
correct form saying, "Can you go the store?" "Yes, you can go to the store?"

Play a game with several family members or other ch ildren.  Give each person several objects. Take tur ns 
asking one another for items. In this way you can m odel the question form and give the child opportuni ty to 
ask questions. Give the item only when the queston form is used spontaneously or child at least repeat s the 
form after you.

Use similar procedure with "does" questions. Model the correct question form for him when he doesn't u se it. 
Take turns asking each other questions about pictur es or objects. "Does he have a jacket?" "Does he go  to 
school?" "Can fish run?" etc.

cards.title: Uses some common irregular plurals (men, fee t)

Tasks.Action:
Use pictures or real objects that have irregular pl ural forms. (Men, feet, mice, children, teeth, etc. ) Show the 
child one item and tell him the name, then show 2 o r more and tell the plural form.
Put out pairs of pictures and have the child show y ou man, then men.
Show pictures and have child name them using the co rrect plural form.

cards.title: Tells two events in order of occurrence

Tasks.Action:
Have the child watch you as you perform two activit ies. For example tap your head and then clap your h ands. 
Then ask the child to tell you the two things you d id. Aid him with cues such as "first I --- and then  I ---"
Instruct the child to do two things. After he does them have him tell you what he just did.

When child can tell you 2 events, which just occurr ed, have him tell about events that just happened 
progressively longer ago; for example telling about  things he did today. Or read the child a familiar story and 
mix up the order of events. Let the child correct y ou.
Take turns doing things and have child tell you abo ut them such as "You blew a bubble and I broke it."

cards.title: Carries out a series of 3 directions

Tasks.Action: If the child has difficulty with a 3 stage directio n begin with a 2 stage direction.
Ask the child to repeat the direction before he beg ins to follow it.

Begin with directions using one object, i.e. "Get y our shoes, sit down, and put on your shoes." Gradua lly 
increase the difficulty by adding unrelated activit ies to the request. Praise the child each time he f ollows your 
directions.

cards.title: Demonstrates understanding of passive senten ces (boy hit girl, girl was hit by the boy)

Tasks.Action:
Use puppets. Give each puppet a name. You demonstra te for the child and talk about what is happening. The 
dog chased the cow, the cow chased the dog, etc. In struct the child to demonstrate similar actions for  you. 
Praise when correct. If incorrect demonstrate the c orrect action for him.
Use same procedure with dolls or toy animals.
Use pairs of pictures depicting the same kinds of a ctivities and have the child point to the one named .
Use similar procedures with words like kiss, chase,  hit, feed, throwing.

cards.title:
Can find a pair 
 of objects/pictures on request

Tasks.Action: Use the word "pair" in your speech to refer to two identical objects; pair of shoes, mittens, cards, e tc.
Put out pairs of objects. Mix them up and then ask the child to find a pair of ____________.
Put out the assortment of paired objects and tell t he child to put all the pairs together.
Use the procedures in 2 and 3 with pairs of picture d items.

Use pictures of a single item and of pairs of those  same single items. Ask the child to point to or fi nd the one 
that shows a pair of _______.

cards.title: Uses "could" and "would" in speech

Tasks.Action: Use "could" and "would" in your speech when talking  to child to express possible activities.

Play verbal games such as: If I were a rabbit, I co uld hop, I could jump, I could wiggle my nose. Then  let the 
child choose the pretend object or animal and tell you what he could do. Do the same with would, i.e. If I was 
at the park I would swing, I would ride on the merr y-go-round, etc. Make sure the child prefaces each remark 
with " I could" or "I would."

Ask questions such as " Who could/would do this for  me?" Encourage the child to reply by saying " I co uld, 
Billy would," etc.

cards.title: Uses compound sentences (I hit the ball and  it went on the road)

Tasks.Action:
Listen to the child talking. When you hear where he  could have used a conjunction (such as "and" or "s o") or 
an adverb, repeat the sentence with the conjunction  or adverb inserted. EXAMPLE: We went to the store and  
we bought candy.
Talk and explain events to the child using compound  sentences.
Ask child to tell you 2 things he did at the ______ ____.

cards.title:
Can find top 
 and bottom  of items on request

Tasks.Action:
Initially choose objects that have a definite top a nd bottom (bottle, shirt, etc.)  Tell the child whi ch are the top 
and the bottom. Then ask him to point to the top an d bottom.
Instead of pointing, have the child place objects a t the top or bottom.
Use a picture of a ladder and have him place pictur es of people at the top and bottom.

Use a sheet of paper and make a picture by having t he child place or draw things at the top or bottom of it. 
Use various stickers to increase child's motivation .

cards.title: Uses contractions can't, don’t, won't

Tasks.Action:
Model replies by asking all people present who can ; i.e. "Who can fly?" and have everyone respond in turn. "I 
can't." Let child be last. Ask, " Who likes cod liv er oil?" or " Who will do the dishes?" Hopefully ch ild will 
imitate everyone elses' reply.
Use "can't""don't" and "won't" in your speech when talking to child.

cards.title: Can point out absurdities in picture

Tasks.Action: Have the child tell what is wrong with the picture.

Show the child the absurdity and ask a question abo ut it, i.e. "Do chickens lay red eggs?" "Do dogs fl y?" "Do 
houses have legs?"

cards.title: Uses words sister, brother, grandmother, gra ndfather

Tasks.Action:
Use above labels instead of their names when addres sing these people, also say, "Take this toy to sist er," or 
ask, "Where is your brother?" If child does not res pond, touch correct person and say, " Here is your brother, 
Tom."

Include above words in your conversation with child , saying things such as, "Look at your brother eati ng his 
dinner," or "See if your sister is awake."

cards.title: Tells final word in opposite analogies

Tasks.Action:
The child will correctly complete the following; 
a.  Brother is a boy, sister is a ________. 
b.  In the summer it is hot; in the winter it is ______ __. 
c.  We're awake diuring the day; we sleep at ________. 
d.  A tree is big; a bush is _______.
If child has difficulty with the above analogies be gin by using pictures while saying the analogies.
Change the order of presentation, i.e. Sister is a girl; brother is a _______.

If child has difficulty in answering the question, give him two choices (one correct, the other incorr ect.) 
Praise correct answers.

cards.title: Tells familiar story without pictures for c ues

Tasks.Action: As you read stories to the child, have him describe  the pictures to you.
Retell a story leaving out important words as you s how the pictures and have the child fill in those w ords.

Begin with a simple short story and repeat it sever al times for the child. Encourage him to retell it to you or 
his brother or sister. Praise the child as he remem bers more details. Gradually increase the complexit y and 
length of the stories read to him and encourages hi m to retell these to family members.

cards.title: Names picture that does not belong in parti cular class (one that's not an animal)

Tasks.Action:
Use either pictures or real objects. Put out 3-4 it ems: 3 that are dogs, animals, tools, food, or writ ing 
implements, etc. and one that is not. Ask child to find one that doesn't belong. Help him by asking wh at you 
do with, or what class, each item belongs to. Gradu ally withdraw aid until child can point to the item  
independently.

Initially have child point to all the ones we write  with, eat with, etc. and then ask which one don't we _____ 
with. Praise when correct: "Right, we don't eat wit h a pencil. It doesn't belong." Gradually change th e 
question to just asking, "which one doesn't belong? "

cards.title: Tells whether or not 2 words rhyme

Tasks.Action:
Rhyme words for the child. Say “cat, bat, hat, they  rhyme.” Use nonsense syllables also “oo, coo, boo,  do.”  
After demonstrating this for the child gradually ha ve him tell you that the words rhyme. Then follow s ame 
procedure including words that don’t rhyme.

Present pairs of pictures to the child. Use some pa irs that rhyme and some that don’t. Either you or t he child 
says words. Then tell if the words rhyme or not.

Use pictures of items. Put out one picture. Have ch ild name it. Then show him 2-3 more pictures and ha ve 
him find the one that rhymes with the one initially  presented. Encourage him to say the picture name a s he 
does so. Give clues as necessary, but gradually wit hdraw them.

cards.title: Uses complex sentences (She wants me to come  in because _______)

Tasks.Action:
Play a game of “you say what I say.” Ask the child to say complex sentences in imitation of you. If th e child 
has difficulty, repeat part of the sentence and ask  him to complete the sentence.

Look at pictures with the child and ask the child to describe the picture. Repeat child’s sentence by  saying,       
“Yes”…   adding words necessary to make a complex s entence.

cards.title: Can tell whether sound is loud or soft

Tasks.Action:
Use sound makers, musical instruments, or tap table  or drop items that make different sounds into coff ee can 
and have child tell you if it’s loud or soft.

Make loud and soft sounds for the child and name th em as such. Then make a noise and have the child te ll 
you whether it’s loud or soft. Give cues such as co vering ears, putting finger to mouth, or using init ial 
consonant sounds to help child answer. Gradually re duce cues until child answers unaided.

cards.title: Can point to some, many, several

Tasks.Action: Use words in your speech to the child. Choose only one word to teach at a time, as the terms are relat ive.

Put out groups of objects and describe the groups a s having some, many, etc. Have child point to group s as 
you name them.
Begin with groups of objects that vary substantiall y in number. Gradually make the groups closer in nu mber.

cards.title: Tells address

Tasks.Action: Tell child his address, have him repeat it after yo u.

Begin by requiring child to tell only part of addre ss. You say 319, let child tell you street. You say  town, let 
child tell State. Gradually require to tell you mor e of address himself.

cards.title: Tells telephone number

Tasks.Action:
Say telephone number to child. Have him repeat it b ack to you. Continue until child can tell you on re quest 
what his telephone number is.

Provide child with cues initially. You say the firs t three digits and let child tell you the last four . Gradually 
require child to tell you entire number.

If child can name numerals write telephone number o n flash cards. Let him use card for cues when he ne eds 
to. Gradually withdraw the clues until child can te ll number without looking.
Use play telephone. Have him tell you number and yo u dial. Let child do so if he is able.

With group of children let them take turns telling their phone number so someone else can call them on  play 
phone.

cards.title: Can point to most, least, few

Tasks.Action: Use the words most, least, few in your speech to th e child.
If child has difficulty work with only one concept at a time.

Set up groups of small items. Have child point to g roup that has most, least, few. Later have him name  the 
groups for you when you point to them.

With a group of children, take turns letting the ch ildren give each other a few, someone the least, et c. and 
then telling who has the most, etc.

Initially use groups that vary substantially in num ber of items. Gradually reduce to difference of 1-2  items 
for most and least.

cards.title: Tells simple jokes

Tasks.Action: Tell an elephant joke to the child. Encourage him t o repeat to friends and relatives.

Read Bennet Cerf’s Book of Riddles 
 to the child. Allow time for him to respond before  turning the page that 
shows the answer. Example of riddles –(1) Why do bi rds fly south? Answer: It’s too far to walk. (2) Wh at 
goes up when the rain comes down? Answer: Umbrellas . (3) What time is it when the hippo sits on the 
fence? Answer: Time to get a new fence.

cards.title: Tells daily experiences

Tasks.Action:
After carrying out an activity with child (going to  store, swimming, etc.) have child tell you or anot her person 
what he did. Initially provide him with cues if nec essary.

Begin by having the child tell you about immediate experiences. Gradually delay having him tells you w hat he 
did.

Establish a special time (before dinner, etc.) when  child can tell experiences to the other parent whe n he/she 
arrives home.

Initially accept short description of major events.  Aid the child with cues to give more details. Grad ually 
withdraw cues as the child gives details spontaneou sly.

cards.title: Describes location of movement through, away , from, toward, over

Tasks.Action:
Set up play situation, with card and trucks, gas st ation, tunnels, bridges, etc. Begin by describing t o the child 
where he is moving his vehicle. Then instruct the c hild to drive over  bridge, through  tunnel, away from, etc. 
Gradually have him tell you where he is driving.

Use same procedure with a variety of objects. Make a game of taking turns letting the child give you 
directions of where to move objects and telling you  if you’re correct.

cards.title: Answers why question with an explanation

Tasks.Action:
Model asking and answering “why” questions with ano ther child or adult. Later include the target child  and 
ask him questions.
If child gives partial answer like “because” give h im additional clues by asking him more questions.

Ask the child the question, provide him with part o f the information and let him finish. Gradually req uire the 
child to provide more and more information spontane ously.
Use puppets, act out a story, ask the child “why” q uestions about it.

Use pictured stories. Tell child the story. Ask him  “why” question. Show him the picture, which gives clue to 
the explanation. Gradually withdraw aid so child pe rforms independently.

When child is proficient answering “why” question i n structured situation begin to ask questions about  daily 
experiences. (i.e.why did mom go to store? Because we need some milk for supper)

cards.title: Can “tell me the opposite of ________ “

Tasks.Action:
Use several different sets of opposites. Tell the c hild the opposite of cold is hot, etc. Use pictures  and have the 
child match the opposite pairs. Explain to him as h e does so.
Ask the child “what’s the opposite of ___________?”  If he can’t tell you, use the pictures to correct him.

Use pictured opposites. Give the child one of each of a pair of 2-3 opposites. Ask him to give you the  opposite 
of _____ As the child gains proficiency discontinue s using the pictures.

cards.title: Answers question “what happens if.  .  .(Yo u drop an egg)?”

Tasks.Action:
Set up situations in which the child can observ e the results of an action, or choose things he has  had the 
opportunity to observe in his own environment: drop ping an egg, a glass, tipping over a glass, not fas tening 
pants. Then have the child tell you what would happ en if __________. If he can’t tell you or gives inc orrect 
answer, then perform the activity and have the chil d tell you what happened.

cards.title: Uses yesterday and tomorrow meaningfully

Tasks.Action:
Plan various special activities for several days in  a row. Before doing them, tell the child “tomorrow  we’re 
going ----“ The next day describe and discuss what you did yesterday and plans for tomorrow.
Have child tell you the things he did yesterday and  will do tomorrow.
Name activities and have child tell you whether the y happened yesterday or will happen tomorrow.

cards.title: Asks meaning of new or unfamiliar words

Tasks.Action:
When speaking or reading, ask the child, “Do you kn ow what that word means?” Then explain the meaning to 
the child and use it again another sentence.

Tell the child a story you feel would be very excit ing and interesting. Use unfamiliar words and see i f the child 
asks what the word means. Praise him when he does a sk, and then ask him to explain the new word to the  
family.
